story:
Who We Are

Fruitcake Theatre Company has been a passion project since our sophomore year. Just last year, we mounted a production of All My Sons by Arthur Miller and we sold out all four performances. This year, we are planning to do The Elephant Man by Bernard Pomerance and bring his work to life. With your help, we can create the vision we have for this play into a reality.

What We Need 

  • A venue
  • A set
  • Costumes
  • Food for actors/crew

What You Get

  • Free tickets
  • Signed program
  • Signed poster
  • Reserved seats

THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!!

THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!!

story:
Refugee Fund

Theatre is expensive and can be seen as exclusive. Many people don't think theatre is for them.  We are hoping, with your help, to make our play and the stories we tell, as accessible as possible to the people whose voices are represented on stage. 

The simple plan for our refugee fund is to pay for 100 refugees to come to see our play, pay for them to get there and get home and participate in a series of workshops designed to explore journey, authenticity and communication. 

The workshops will be practical and explore how we speak without language. We have experienced workshop facilitators and will provide a translator where necessary.

The show will run at The Space, London from 3rd - 14th April with the workshops taking place throughout that period. We will also travel to Brighton Fringe where we hope to continue this work.

 

What We Need

The maths for this is extremely simple. We need £3000 to pay the tickets, travel and workshop expenses for 100 refugees. The breakdown of this is as follows:

Ticket: £14

Travelcard: £6

Workshop Expenses: £10

Total for one person: £30

Our aim is to be able to pay for 100 people over the course of a the run. If we don't raise all the money, we will still be able to use whatever we have raised to fund as many people as we can.

Your contribution, however large or small, is absolutely crucial. 

There's also no need to stop at 100. Every pound we raise after our target will be used in exactly the same way! The more we raise, the more successful this will be!

 

The Sleeper

The Sleeper is a play by, about and for refugees. It uses real testimony, real experience and asks some very real questions. Over the course of three years we have put together an hour-long experience which evokes the harrowing experience of hundreds of thousands of refugees, stuck somewhere between leaving home and finding a new one. It also recognises that we all need to do more than just watch a play about a crisis and urges people to take positive action. It's also, we must say, a cracking piece of entertainment.

The plot: An overnight train, somewhere through Europe. Karina, a very British writer, naively reports a woman sleeping in her bunk. Then it happens again. Forever connected by this simple action, these two women are played and replayed in the mind of a writer who examines the stories we tell each other and how we choose to tell them. This provocative and poignant new play weaves together the real testimony of Syrian refugees and the personal experience of writer Henry C Krempels.

 

The best thing in Edinburgh

The London Review of Books

 

An exceptional piece of theatre-making

The Scotsman

 

Anima Theatre Company 

Anima Theatre Company is focused on the faltering line between fact and fiction. Working in the realms of experimental theatre and new writing, we came together through our mutual interest in inclusive theatre and giving voice to those who struggle to be heard.

The Sleeper (Theatre 503, Edinburgh Festival 2017, The Rosemary Branch Theatre, The Space and Brighton Fringe 2018) is a minimal portrait of a woman struggling to find refuge. But do we need to know someone in order to help them?

In each project we undertake, our aim is to promote cross-collaboration, conversation and connection while bringing new ideas and new audiences to theatre.

 

The Impact

Will be huge! Our experience working with people who have been affected by the refugee and migrant experience has shown us the enormous benefits of seeing people like them represented through art. So far, we have had feedback which has, at times, been overwhelming and driven us to go further than ever before. 

If we are able to reach out to 100 people, we are creating a new community of friends and a support network for people who need it. The impact of the play itself we hope will allow both people with different experiences to share a space, to develop a common language and appreciate our differences. 

If you pay for one person to get to the play, see it and participate in our workshop. You are building one more bridge. 

Our aim, as with all the projects, is to give a voice and a platform to stories that may otherwise go unheard. The simple reason for doing this play again is that we realised the positive impact it had on a small scale. We now need to reach farther and wider than ever before and, without this fund, we simply won't be able to do that. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Over the past year we have gone deep into this story. It is, in our opinion, the defining question of our generation and we feel like these are things need to be talked about.And now! Our play relies on refugees being in the audience. It is about them. It is for them. It is by them. If we can't get people who have been through the refugee and migrant experience experience into the room, we will feel like we have failed. 

We are already working with a number of charities who support refugees including The Refugee Women's Association. However, we can't rely on them. They are busy and have plenty on their plate. We have a dedicated 'outreach' strand to our production and the best way to ensure we can get to our goal is through there.

Fortunately, we have experience. We just need the funds!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD! SPREAD THE WORD! SPREAD THE WORD!

Did we say spread the word? We believe in this campaign (oh boy do we believe in it!) and we think others will too. If you can't give donate much, then you could end up funding three or four times that amount simply by spreading word far and wide about us and our campaign. 

Send it to friends, to family, to people who you think would appreciate our aims. Hell, send it to total strangers. 

There are all kinds of share tools built into Indiegogo. If you tweet about us, tag us in. Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, Instagram (all @animatheatreco). Link to our website (www.animatheatrecompany.com). Sharing the story can be as valuable as a donation.

With your help, we can get the word out there!

story:
Short Summary

"Common Man" is a work-in-progress dance theatre performance that has been accepted into the 5th Annual Sans Limites Dance Festival, a collective that prides itself in presenting edgy works which challenge audiences. 

This piece is from Louis DeVaughn Nelson, internationally renown for his works that are saturated with social commentary.

"I've been a multidisciplinary artist for 20 years and many of the works I produced had strong sociopolitical themes. Community outreach has always been a strong aspect of my work, utilizing satire to uncover underbellies of our society typically ignored and swept under the rug."

-LDN

------

"The Los Angeles LGBT Center, a health and resource center for the gay community, reports data collected from their patients that gay men who had used meth within the previous 12 months were five times more likely to test positive for HIV than those who did not use meth. Moreover, meth is so pervasive that 71% of gay and bisexual men who were surveyed said they have been asked to try crystal meth."

-"The Changing Face of Meth", The Huffington Post, 3/2/17

What We Need & What You Get

We need to pay our dancers!

The money will go directly to the salary of the performers and production costs: (8 in all, paid a $200 stipend)

  • 8 Performers $200 Stipend each = $1,600
  • 10 Hours Rehearsal Studio Rental = $200
  • 1 $200 Stipend to Hokum Arts to cover production costs = $200

The $200 stipend to Hokum Arts goes to the director/choreographer to cover the production fee (to the festival to rent the theatre).

We have several perks!

From mentions in the program and social media and exclusive background info and open rehearsal invites, we want you to be a part of the process. This is just the beginning of the work and we can't do it without you. The ultimate goal is to compose an evening of theatre based on the original script written by Louis DeVaughn Nelson. This festival will present dance excerpts from the larger piece. Help us develop this work by providing your feedback directly to us. 

Overall you'll be helping to raise awareness about a very important issue - and this piece could travel to community centers and organizations to help raise awareness and to prevent others from falling victim to this common problem. 

The Impact

With your contribution, all parties involved will be compensated and the work-in-progress will gain momentum for development of a larger work. 

This project is important because this is a specific epidemic that isn't getting as much attention as the opioid crisis is in mainstream media. 

Many of my works have had elements of sociopolitical issues and have raised awareness about topics including (but not limited to) domestic abuse/violence, eating disorders, bullying, sexual violence, racism, mental health issues and forms of discrimination based on gender and sexual orientation. 

Furthermore, the work will be disseminated to audiences proactively engaged in community building, as this is so much of what culture is about and much of the audience will be artists and members of the cultural community. 

According to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), crystal meth abuse and meth related deaths have been steadily on the rise for the past 5 years. 

And with recent pending (possible) legislation in regards to opening "safe injection sites" spearheaded by NYC Mayor De Blasio, many outreach organizations are reaching out to the community about reducing the stigma of substance abuse illness and the need for more programming to save lives. 

 

Risks & Challenges

The risqué subject matter is not the easiest to seek funding for though being excepted into a renown dance festival that has been running for five years gave me the courage and validation that this is an important work of merit and deserves a stage on which to be presented. 

Male dancers are a hot commodity and get cast by bigger companies and are paid a salary for rehearsals. It's imperative that independent choreographers secure funding to get high caliber dancers. 

The biggest challenge is finding folks who support the outreach aspect of this work (exposition of the tragedy of drug abuse amongst the gay community) in a meaningful way. 

Because this work was accepted to be presented under a larger umbrella organization (The Sans Limites Company) it creates a set of obstacles for gaining support directly. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you own a local business or know someone who does - we would love to connect with you! By offering discount or gift cards we can promote your organization. We would be happy to use any donations for ongoing fundraising efforts for silent auction or raffle prizes.  This could help us to produce a larger scale version of this work - that is the ultimate goal.

story:
bambule.babys: on our rite of passage, from the Bavarian hinterland to the world's biggest art festival

We are bambule.babys, a German performance collective founded in 2014. In our provocative work we depict the wounds we sustain fighting in the postmodern trenches in times of still existing patriarchy, neo-nationalism and fundamentalism. As ‘babys’ we reveal our vulnerability as humans.

And now we are ready to make our next big step into the international art world. Your support will make this step much easier for us.

We are bringing our immersive performance installation 'Baby Paradise' to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the biggest festival for independent performing arts in the world. The Fringe is a platform for free artistic expression, following its mission of 'defying the norm' since 1947.

Some people say that participating at the Fringe is a rite of passage for young artists. And yes, that's what it feels like: All will start with a road trip, when we travel the more than 1000km from Regensburg, Germany to Baby Paradise's new home in Edinburgh.

For the full 27 days of the festival a bizarre underworld of desire and oppression will come to life: each day we will perform two shows – 'Baby Paradise - Part One' and 'Baby Paradise – Part Two'. By the time we return, we will truly be warriors.

 

What we have to offer - Baby Paradise, a Barbie doll-playing playing prostitute in a surreal peep show

'Baby Paradise' is a challenging feminist piece about power, sex, control. In our immersive performance installation nothing is safe or pretty. Baby is a prostitute and every person in the audience becomes her customer. A surreal peep show begins: As a specialist in interacting with Barbie dolls Baby uses them in surprising ways, as dildos, as cigarettes, as women's razors, as a toothbrush or a microphone. Over the course of two hours, Baby performs a grotesque revue of female roles and stereotypes, until she becomes a doll herself.

'Baby Paradise' gives a voice to people that are marginalized in our society. Part of the inspiration for 'Baby Paradise' came from artistic director Anna's relationship with a sex worker.

Especially sex workers face difficult living conditions everywhere in the world. And the fight against patriarchy and the angry white man’s rulership is not over yet. With 'Baby Paradise' we are joining this fight.

'Baby Paradise' is a project we have been working on for the last three years. It all began, when Anna was attending a Master class for 'self-generated theatre' at Stella Adler Studio of Acting New York City three years ago. Since then we have been refining it and have also created the short film 'Baby Paradise'.

Meet 'Baby Paradise' at C venues during the Fringe

 

Why support us?

We ask for your support, because - apart from the challenges most independent artists have to face when it comes to funding their projects - we are currently cut off from any local funding.

After in March 2018 the Regensburg Department of Culture censored our performance ‘My home is not my home’, we have been heavily attacked by the local press and several institutions. Since then we have become outcasts in our own community, as reported by Regensburg Digital and Puls, Bayerischer Rundfunk.

 

 

 

 

 

 

In our current position we can only rely on the support of a community of like-minded people who believe in the freedom of art.

We will bring 'Baby Paradise' to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in any case, because this is our calling. To follow this vision, however, we will have to use up pretty much all resources we have left. Our friends and family support us in every way possible but this will only get us this far.

We have to pay for travel, accommodation, set and venue. At this point our helpers (and ourselves) have to work for free, although they deserve some compensation for the effort they put in.

By supporting ‘Baby Paradise’ you become a part of a unique artistic project that gives a voice to the ‘others’ in our society. Our promise is to make art that isn't there to be likeable, to be compliant, to please the needs of institutions or that compromises.

If you support us, you support freedom of art and people that fight for their vision, not only for ourselves but to share it with others. For a better world to come!

 

How you can help?

Every financial contribution you could make, however big or small, makes a big difference to our project. Spread the word and encourage your friends and family to back us.

If you support what we are doing but you aren't able to donate, you can still contribute in many ways that we would be most grateful for:

-Share our campaign via email or on your own Social Media

-Follow bambule.babys on Facebook, Instagram or Twitter to stay up to date with the show. In the next few weeks we are going to publish new video clips of 'Baby Paradise'.

- Because Baby is so special, she also has her own Instagram

-Get in touch with us, for example if you are a Fringe performer and have a show that matches with the themes 'Baby Paradise' deals with.

And if you come to Edinburgh, you can already buy tickets here:

Baby Paradise - Part One and Baby Paradise - Part Two

story:
What We Need & What You Get

  • After raising most of the capital from some very savvy investors who know a great play when they see one, Lenore Skomal has a little bit more to go to reach her capitalization.
  • Many friends and fans have wanted to invest but the minimum requirement of $5000 was just too much of a nut.
  • That's why we've birthed this crowdfunding campaign. It's an easy way to involve the most wonderful people in our lives and bring them into this project at financial levels that are comfortable for them.
  • Our gratitude is both copious and heartfelt. We've got some wonderful perks for you. Please check them out. We'd love for you to be a part of this.

About THE EXES 

What happens when two exes collide with their former wife? One word: Hilarity. 

Self-made billionaire Richard and his best friend Dick were both married to the same woman: strong willed Mavis. When she drops in uninvited on Christmas Eve--the day of Richard’s daughter’s wedding--all hell breaks loose. Reminiscent of The Philadelphia Story, this bromantic comedy of love and breakups is alternately irreverent, ridiculous and tender—reminding audiences why marriage and divorce make for strange bedfellows. If Neil Simon and Noel Coward had a baby, this would be it.

Check out our website for more clips and the history of the play.

We're looking at a 6 to 8 week run for the show on a very prestigious (and gorgeous) Off Broadway Stage in July of 2019. Our plan is thorough and our budget airtight. And you can be a part of all of it. 

The Impact

  • Your contribution puts us over the finish line in terms of our budget.
  • Your donation directly goes to taking care of expenses, such as the downpayment on the theater, publicity, marketing, even dry cleaning. No kidding. There's a line item for dry cleaning!
  • FYI: Lenore isn't taking a salary for her work as General Manager of the project. That's how much she loves what she does!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please like us on Facebook.
  • Promote this campaign on your social media!
  • Come to the show!
story_txt:
What We Need & What You Get

After raising most of the capital from some very savvy investors who know a great play when they see one, Lenore Skomal has a little bit more to go to reach her capitalization.
Many friends and fans have wanted to invest but the minimum requirement of $5000 was just too much of a nut.
That's why we've birthed this crowdfunding campaign. It's an easy way to involve the most wonderful people in our lives and bring them into this project at financial levels that are comfortable for them.
Our gratitude is both copious and heartfelt. We've got some wonderful perks for you. Please check them out. We'd love for you to be a part of this.

About THE EXES 
What happens when two exes collide with their former wife? One word: Hilarity. 
Self-made billionaire Richard and his best friend Dick were both married to the same woman: strong willed Mavis. When she drops in uninvited on Christmas Eve--the day of Richard’s daughter’s wedding--all hell breaks loose. Reminiscent of The Philadelphia Story, this bromantic comedy of love and breakups is alternately irreverent, ridiculous and tender—reminding audiences why marriage and divorce make for strange bedfellows. If Neil Simon and Noel Coward had a baby, this would be it.
Check out our website for more clips and the history of the play.
We're looking at a 6 to 8 week run for the show on a very prestigious (and gorgeous) Off Broadway Stage in July of 2019. Our plan is thorough and our budget airtight. And you can be a part of all of it. 

The Impact

Your contribution puts us over the finish line in terms of our budget.
Your donation directly goes to taking care of expenses, such as the downpayment on the theater, publicity, marketing, even dry cleaning. No kidding. There's a line item for dry cleaning!
FYI: Lenore isn't taking a salary for her work as General Manager of the project. That's how much she loves what she does!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please like us on Facebook.
Promote this campaign on your social media!
Come to the show!

story:
Help Us "Build The Box"!


With your help Creative Drama Children's Theater will build a 100 seat "Black Box" style theatre for kids in the community of Clemmons, North Carolina.
Creative Drama Children's Theater is a performing arts studio in the heart of Clemmons, NC.  We teach kids ages 3-18 Acting, Dance, Voice and Musical Theatre. Our mission is to inspire and empower kids with a quality Arts Education and to do so in a loving Christian environment.
We started in 2011  with dream and a dollar.  Well, maybe less than a dollar.  We had 37 devoted students and parents.  Now in 2015 we are close to 300 students that come through our doors during the week.  And we are out of space!  
Classes are over crowded and parents are squished in the lobby.  Opening the space next door will allow a variety of classes to be held both in the old studio and in the new addition.  It will alleviate over-crowding and give parents a little more breathing room while waiting for their kids.
This "Build The Box"  campaign will help us renovate the space next door into a 100 seat Black Box style theatre.  This type of theatre is different from your typical auditorium.  A Black Box Theatre is multi- use, multi-functional and seats can be used in different ways depending on the event.  Drama classes and future productions  will be held in the theatre and the space will be available for the community to use. 
We want the experience parents and kids have at CDCT to be joyful, exciting, and magical.  Because after all theatre is MAGIC!

What We Need & What You Get

Here is a breakdown of what we need and what you get:

  • We need $25,000 to renovate the existing space into a "Black Box" Theatre.
  • With your unique contribution you will receive special perks from CDCT.
  • Depending on the size of the contribution, you could receive:  a CDCT car magnet, ad space in our programs, complimentary tickets to shows, and more. 

The Impact

CDCT has made a huge impact in the lives of the kids we serve.  We build self-confidence, trust, problem-solving, literacy and we give them an appreciation and respect for the Arts that future generations need to thrive in the world.  With a new performing arts space in Clemmons, NC:

  • More kids can take classes at CDCT in Dance, Voice, Drama and Musical Theatre
  • Kids lives are changed because they find a place they belong and where they can thrive
  • Other performing arts clubs and activities will be able to rent the space
  • It adds to the draw and vitality of the Clemmons community.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to the campaign please do not worry.  Having your child take classes with us is enough!  We love and cherish each minute with your child and can't wait to continue their learning.  Besides taking classes and spreading the word about our studio, here are some other ways you can help:
  • Please spread the word about our need to renovate the space next door
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
New Uniforms

For almost a decade CSz Sacramento has provided top tier improv and sketch entertainment to tens of thousands of fans, taught thousands of students, and raised thousands of dollars for charities such as Toys for Tots, Albie Aware, The Sacramento Children's Home, and more. While we love what we do, it takes a lot to keep a theatre going.  Sometimes we need a little help. And that is what we are asking for from you.  

For over five years we have been using the same ComedySportz uniform jerseys, and they have became tired, torn, worn, and more. While we wouldn't change the memories we have had in them for anything in the world, we are looking to upgrade to spiffier new jerseys with the new ComedySportz logos adopted in 2014.

We have found a vendor and are now looking for the funding to purchase and hopefully roll out our new look by our anniversary weekend, November 13th and 14th. The venture will cost us $2,000.  But with your help, and some amazing rewards, we believe we can reach that goal easily.

Thank you for your time.  And  remember: we love to make you laugh!

Chris Crotty
General Manager and Artistic Director
CSz Sacramento

Cool Rewards

All donors will get their names on a special "We Made This Happen" lobby display featuring two new uniforms signed by all the players.  We're also offering some awesome thank-you gifts including:
  • Thank-you postcards with your choice of player in his/her new uniform
  • Be a guest performer in a ComedySportz match
  • Your own new uniform customized with your name
  • A private show for you and your friends
  • Your company name/logo on the new uniforms, on the pre-show slides, and in a lobby display.
  • Free CSz/ComedySportz tickets for life!
  • NEW!  Donate at least $10 and you'll be entered into a raffle for a new, personalized uniform.  Each $10 gets you one raffle ticket.

story:
Project

This is a very big year for Kybele Dance Theater (KDT) as it's a very important chance to leap from a small local-based company to more of an established, touring company. We are invited to perform at the Peridance Capezio Showcase at New York's Association of Performing Arts Presenters (APAP) in January 2016. This is the largest convention in the world where all the big companies, venues, presenters, and producers meet to find out about new companies they could be interested in to present in their upcoming festivals, events and performances for upcoming seasons. 

Beside performing at Peri Dance, KDT is producing 3 more half evening shows at City Center and Ailey Studios open to the public for FREE. 

Our campaign is to take KDT's 6 dancers and company manager to New York to perform and network.

Contributors are not only helping to get the company to travel to New York for the performances but also molding and shaping the future of the company ... and fulfilling an American dream

I'm Seda Aybay. I am originally from Istanbul, Turkey. I found my passion for dancing when I was 5 years old and began my journey with ballet, jazz and tap. After graduating from high school, I begged my parents to let me go to the States to continue studying dance/choreography and discovered modern and contemporary dance. After studying at Santa Monica College, UCLA, Alvin Ailey and performing with various companies and choreographers, I found my creative artistic voice and started to create contemporary pieces to tell stories by fusing Turkish imagery. I am the founder, artistic director, and choreographer of Los Angeles-based contemporary dance company Kybele Dance Theater (KDT) since 2003. These past 12 years I have created many works and have been refining my creative, unique vision. My works have been performed and toured thoughout different parts of the USA.


Our Goal

Our goal is $14, 615 to take the company to New York and be a part of the APAP Conference, January 15-19, by performing as well as attending the conference and its various workshops and sessions while also networking and spreading the word about this young, exciting, new dance company.

Airfare: $3200 

Hotel: $4000

Conference fee: $2495

Conference Badge Device: $500 

Showcase Listing: $70

PR materials: $1000 

Rehearsal: $1,500

Per diem: $1,850

————————————————————

$14, 615


Our stretch goal is $24,000 to pay the performers and everybody who worked so hard to create this project. It is sad that while usually the production's venue is supported, the dancers, choreographer, costume designer, lighting designer, and company manager who create the production are not. We believe everyone should be paid for their hard work. So if we can get past the bare bones of just getting to New York and performing, we would like to support all the artists who made that dream a reality.
If we don't reach our entire goal, we will use whatever funds we do get towards the airfare and conference fees. If we must couch-surf and spend 5 days ramen noodle-eating, it will still be worth it! Dance is the dream and every penny counts towards making that dream come true.


The Impact

Dance is living, breathing poetry. It is being created at that moment to be experienced live. Dance reflects the inner soul of the artist and mirrors the world we live in, giving meaning to our society and bringing beauty and depth to it and to all who participate in it. Contributors are not only helping to shape society's better self but by extension are also the audience for this piece. I live to dance but it cannot have meaning without the audience. My contributors are my audience and together we are breathing new life into the arts, keeping it fresh, modern and cutting edge.

KDT has produced full-evening programs, been invited to festivals, as well as commissioned to create pieces in Los Angeles, Long Beach, Fresno, Concord, San Jose, Palm Desert, San Diego, San Francisco, Seattle, and New York.


Bio

Born and raised in Istanbul, Turkey, Seda’s dance education started at the age of five with French & Russian ballet technique under Turkish Ballerina Suna Ugur’s tutelage. She later completed the rigorous exams of The Royal Academy of Dance in London, England. She has trained, performed and choreographed internationally in Modern, Jazz & Tap dance forms. Seda’s first dance company Les Chats de St. Michel in Istanbul-Turkey won her three national first place prizes in Milliyet Choreography competitions. She was the youngest and only student choreographer in the creative comity of Istanbul High-schools for Turkish National Holiday “19 Mayis Gençlik ve Spor Bayrami". After graduation, Seda came to the United States to continue her education in dance at Santa Monica College. She later graduated with Summa Cum Laude from UCLA World Arts and Cultures Department majoring in dance and choreography. Additionally, she completed the prestigious and incredibly competitive Alvin Ailey program in New York, before returning to Los Angeles to form her multi-media contemporary dance company, Kybele Dance Theater.


As KDT founder, artistic director and choreographer since 2003, Seda has produced and choreographed multiple works that have won her choreography awards from Dance Under the Stars Festival, MAD BAD Festival, the RAW 2011 Los Angeles Performing Artist Award as well as the 2015 Elite Original Choreography Award. Her works have been toured and presented in Los Angeles, Long Beach, Fresno, Concord, San Jose, Palm Desert, San Diego, San Francisco, Seattle and New York.


As an independent artist, Seda has been invited to choreograph and teach for Cal State Fresno, LACSA, Santa Monica Collage, Praxis Project, Cerritos College, Pierce College, Spectrum, Why Dance and LA Dance Festival. She performed with the Synapse Dance Theatre, Folklorico de SMC, Ney Nava Dance, Liliana de Leon Torsiello, Alex De Silva, Praxis Project, Lion's Pounce Theater, Lula Washington Dance Theater, Megan and Jeffrey Hornaday, Reggie Brown, Kin Dance, Bethune Theatre Danse, Paradigm Dance Theater and Clairobscure Dance Company. She was profiled and featured as a dancer on KTLA channel 9, Univision Kmex34, and twice on Fox 11 News with her unique global perspective and eclectic dance background.  She has also had several featured print articles appear in the US as well as in Turkey.


Along with creating and performing, Seda is currently producing new works for Kybele Dance Theater alongside teaching modern dance classes at Santa Monica College, Yuri Grigoriev School of Ballet (both the renowned ballet program as well as open adult classes), Your Neighborhood Dance Studio and various dance intensives. Additionally, she prepares young students for Spotlight, Youth America Grand Prix (YAGP), Elite dance competitions as well as college dance auditions with both training as well as original choreography. Her students have been invited to perform numerous times at YAGP finals in New York, and most recently won first place in Elite Dance resulting in her students receiving scholarships for various distinguished schools and intensive programs. Seda’s unique skills and background make her an invaluable and highly sought after teacher as well as a gifted choreographer and dancer. 


Other Ways You Can Help

You can contribute many ways. By choosing our perks, spreading the word out through sharing this project with your friends and your social media connections.  You can also make tax deductible donations here: https://drc.nationbuilder.com/kybele_dance_theater

story:
WHO WE ARE:
Our names are David Morrissey, Joe Rubino, and Andrew J. Beck, and we need your help.

We are Bluebox Theatre Company. We are a relatively new theatre and performing arts company founded in Long Island, NY. Our goal is to bring new visions and people to live theatre with original content and unique takes on classic and contemporary works. 

Our styles and practices reflect the needs not only of artists, but for the community as a whole. We want to create more creative work opportunities for the artists around us, and above all, we aim to present a unique opportunity to bring new audiences to the theater. 

Our campaign is important because it means more fair job opportunities for artists, as well as more exposure to live performance to people who might not usually enjoy theatre. We as a company pick nontraditional shows. Our target is young adults ages 16 to 35, which is also the market that is most lacking in even multi million dollar Broadway shows. We want to help fix that by exposing people to something different, and our next show Night of the Living Dead.

In 2013, we produced the New York premiere of Night of the Living Dead on stage for the Performing Arts Studio in Port Jefferson, NY. Since then we've put on five shows, including the thriller “Bug” by Tracy Letts and the haunting "Down the Road" by Lee Blessing. After Night of the Living Dead, we are going to produce Art, a christmas one act festival, and a Star Wars themed AIDS benefit to close out the season. We wanted to bring back Night of the Living Dead, the show that started it all for us, due to popular demand.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:
Fresh off of a successful adaptation of Down the Road, the plan is to produce Night of the Living Dead. The play has a built in audience that are more than familiar with the legendary film. Bluebox's stage production will be the only one in the Greater New York area, but also one of the only productions ever staged in the United States. We need YOUR help to make this show the best it can possibly be. 


Theatre is a costly venture, and we need you to help fund our dream so the Long Island community can be aware of the top notch shows we put on. We have already raised a lot of our funds, but are looking to raise $1000 more to cover the costs of:

-Rehearsal/ performance space
-Performance rights and Licensing
-Actor stipends
-Professional sets/props
-Marketing solutions and advertising
-Playbills, scripts, and show posters.

SYNOPSIS:

A disparate group of individuals takes refuge in an abandoned house when corpses begin to leave the graveyard in search of fresh human bodies to devour. The pragmatic Ben does his best to control the situation, but when the reanimated bodies surround the house, the other survivors begin to panic. As any semblance of order within the group begins to dissipate, the zombies start to find ways inside -- and one by one, the living humans become the prey of the deceased ones.

story:
Help us tell the stories of 13 inspirational women!

Please help ensure these amazing stories have a life after the Edinburgh Fringe!

"Valiant is a reminder of some of recent history's most terrible moments, a way to give permanent public voices to women who nearly became only whispers in history” (Talking Broadway) 

VALIANT chronicles a century of war as seen through the eyes of women from across the globe.  Actor/writer Lanna Joffrey adapted this documentary theatre piece from Sally Hayton-Keeva’s book of interviews, VALIANT WOMEN IN WAR AND EXILE.  Joffrey’s critically acclaimed play takes these verbatim interviews to create a compelling portrait of what women do in a time of war. VALIANT tells the story of 13 women who have fought in, suffered through, and survived war in Japan, Afghanistan, Northern Ireland, Russia, the United States, Armenia, Hungary, El Salvador and the Philippines. "War seen through women’s eyes makes a different kind of war story.” - Sally Hayton Keeva

VALIANT was developed by Lanna Joffrey after she witnessed the events of 9/11 in New York City in 2001. It was her way of trying to gain control in a hopeless situation.

"I attended a Town Hall discussion with Eve Ensler and Gloria Steinem where my feelings of absolute helplessness and fear were transformed into action. They inspired and unstuck me in one short afternoon. I left that discussion in late September of 2001 with a percolating idea.  In 2002, I contacted Sally and asked for her permission to adapt her book for the stage.  I was convinced that as a theatrical piece, these women’s stories could reach a broader audience because these women’s experiences are “a crucial link in understanding not only the process of warfare, but the human condition itself.” What also compelled me to start this project was the idea that most of these women had never shared their stories until they spoke to Sally. So many of them have been silent for so long and this play breaks their silence." - Lanna Joffrey

VALIANT was previously performed in 2005 at the New York International Fringe Festival, where it received rave reviews, as well as being nominated for The New York Innovative Theatre Award and won The New York International Fringe Festival Overall Excellence in Performance Award. This UK debut, 10 years after the world premiere, will once again star writer/actress Lanna Joffrey. 

VALIANT is going to the Edinburgh Fringe for a full month and will have two previews at Theatre 503 on July 23rd and 24th. We are also trying to raise funds to ensure that the play has a life after the Fringe. It is our aim to tour the piece around the UK and Europe, to share these women's stories with as many people as possible. Please help us make this happen!


What We Need & What You Receive

  • We are looking to raise £8000. 
  • This will go towards marketing costs for the Fringe, assisting the actors with living costs during the Fringe and transferring/touring the show from the Edinburgh Fringe
£700 - Travel Costs
£1000 - Marketing Costs
£300 - Printing Costs
£2,500 - Living costs to support the wonderful women giving a voice to these stories for all 27 days of the Edinburgh Fringe!
£3,500 - Transfer costs - To allow us to spread the stories of these empowering women to wider audiences. 


The Impact - Why support Valiant?

  • Previous productions of Valiant have already been very well received by American audiences, receiving a Fringe First at the New York Fringe in 2003.

  • The play toured for three years across the United States and has the potential to do the same in the UK, which means large audience numbers and ticket sales.

  • The subject matter is accessible to a wide variety of audiences from fringe and theatre audiences to charities, universities, cultural groups and organisations, lending to strong touring prospects and opportunities. This would give sponsors exposure to large audience demographics across the country.

  • The play is issue based it could be workshopped and delivered to participants in a wide capacity of circumstances.

  • It would generate endorsement from war charities and feminist organisations meaning further support and concentrated interest in the piece.

  • VALIANT details events from 8 wars and 13 specific conflicts, spanning almost 100 years. This means there are 13+ anniversaries in which the piece could be performed for, lending not only a supportive audience but also a wide possibility for programming.

  • Its exposure of the role women that have played in war is crucial to raising awareness, promoting education and understanding.


Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways you can help us:

  • Word of mouth! 
Please talk to people about VALIANT! We want to get people talking about this important subject. Share, tweet, Facebook, blog for us!

  • Know someone who can help?
If you know of anyone who might be interested in supporting VALIANT in any way, big or small - please put them in touch with us!
story_txt:
Help us tell the stories of 13 inspirational women! 

Please help ensure these amazing stories have a life after the Edinburgh Fringe!





"Valiant is a reminder of some of recent history's most terrible moments, a
way to give permanent public voices to women who nearly became only
whispers in history” (Talking Broadway) 



VALIANT chronicles a century of war as seen through the eyes of women from across the globe.  Actor/writer Lanna Joffrey adapted this documentary theatre piece from Sally Hayton-Keeva’s book of interviews, VALIANT WOMEN IN WAR AND EXILE.  Joffrey’s critically acclaimed play takes these verbatim interviews to create a compelling portrait of what women do in a time of war. VALIANT tells the story of 13 women who have fought in, suffered through, and survived war in Japan, Afghanistan, Northern Ireland, Russia, the United States, Armenia, Hungary, El Salvador and the Philippines. "War seen through women’s eyes makes a different kind of war story.” - Sally Hayton Keeva
VALIANT was developed by Lanna Joffrey after she witnessed the events of 9/11 in New York City in 2001. It was her way of trying to gain control in a hopeless situation.
"I attended a Town Hall discussion with Eve Ensler and Gloria Steinem where my feelings of absolute helplessness and fear were transformed into action. They inspired and unstuck me in one short afternoon. I left that discussion in late September of 2001 with a percolating idea.  In 2002, I contacted Sally and asked for her permission to adapt her book for the stage.  I was convinced that as a theatrical piece, these women’s stories could reach a broader audience because these women’s experiences are “a crucial link in understanding not only the process of warfare, but the human condition itself.” What also compelled me to start this project was the idea that most of these women had never shared their stories until they spoke to Sally. So many of them have been silent for so long and this play breaks their silence." - Lanna Joffrey

received rave reviews, as well as being nominated for The New York Innovative Theatre Award and
won The New York International Fringe Festival Overall Excellence in Performance Award. This UK debut, 10 years after the world premiere, will once again star writer/actress Lanna Joffrey.

programming.

Word of mouth! 


Please talk to people about VALIANT! We want to get people talking about this important subject. Share, tweet, Facebook, blog for us!

If you know of anyone who might be interested in supporting VALIANT in any way, big or small - please put them in touch with us!

story:
Hey!

Hello! I'm Kyle, a soon-to-be graduate of NYU Tisch's drama program.  My play and we will all be cordially invited is being produced at Dixon Place for their 24th Annual HOT! Festival this coming August! Yay! As making a play can get expensive, myself and the rest of the team are looking to YOU for help in offsetting production costs.  If you can donate anything at all, please help! It will be greatly appreciated. 

What We're Making!

a small boy.  his accidents. his lost stuffed dog.  his body.  his becoming.

and we will all be cordially invited tells the sexual-coming-of-age of a small boy who is Not Quite Like His Peers. through memory, accidents, and copious amounts of shame, we watch the small boy debate with himself how to evolve when there's been no template before him.  we watch him develop and actualize a potential - one that's not quite successful, not quite traditional, yet still self-fulfilling.

Who We Are!

Antonio Barrera (the other boy/first kiss/a butler) is a filmmaker/actor based in New York. He stars in the short film Blitz that will be premiering at Tribeca Film Festival this year, and has recently finished production on the feature film Martingale.

Cassidy Dawn Graves (props) is a writer, a theatre artist, a doer of many other things, and a drama student at NYU Tisch. In addition to creating and producing the Am I Write, Ladies? performance series, she has designed costumes and props for NYU shows, helped create an original theatre piece with German high schoolers in Berlin, had her play about a BDSM dungeon bathroom featured in The Radium Girls’ female writers festival. Cassidy recently created Back in Times Square a show about Times Square peep shows. She is also a staff writer for NYU Local, where she writes about things like porn festivals, weird art installations, and wacky Brooklyn variety shows.

Eliana Mullins (set) is a bi-coastal, multi-dimensional artist and performer working primarily on/with paper/pens and stages/bodies. She likes speaking in codes (sort of) so what she means is she is into visual art and theatre (performance/design/directing). In New York, Eliana has been seen on stage at Dixon Place, The Bushwick Starr Reading Series, Cloud City, The Bohemian Grove and NYU. She has presented her own theatrical works at the latter three. In the spring of 2013 Eliana interned for the Ontological-Hysteric Theatre/Richard Foreman for his production OLD FASHIONED PROSTITUTES (the Public).

Emma Dolhai (costumes) is a designer, writer and activist currently studying at NYU Tisch. Most recently she costumed Tall Trees in a Dark Forest and Eurydice at Playwrights Horizons Theatre School. One time she also made a corset out of shower curtains that looked pretty cool.

Jaye Hunt (stage manager) is a director, diva, and witch, and a fourth year directing student at Playwrights Horizons Theater School at NYU, where she recently directed Lucas Hnath’s About A Woman Named Sarah. Previous stage management credits include The Grapes of Wrath and A Number, both at NYU, and Yin Yang in the 2015 Venus/Adonis festival. She dedicates her work on this production to Cher.

Jordan J. Baum (the small boy) is a writer, performer, and T.A. He is a recent graduate of NYU Tisch, which produced his new plays Agoraphobes, Videodromes, and Threepenny Hoes, and The Three Sullen Outtakes of the Teletubbies Who Stood Outside, Smoking. Recent credits include performing in an excerpt of Ariel Stess' play Horseman’s Haven at Little Theatre and assistant directing her production of Heartbreak at the Bushwick Starr this past May. 

Kyle Rogers (playwright, sound design) is a sound designer/composer, writer, and performer based in Brooklyn, NY. He is a soon-to-be graduate of the Playwrights Horizons Theater School program at NYU Tisch. Recent performance credits include Yallerybrown/the Brownie in the Skriker (PHTS) and BB#6 in #MAMAMILK (PHTS) and backup dancer in Eterniday (LaMaMa). Recent/upcoming sound credits include Corner's Grove (Planetary Connections Festival), Recursion (ETW), and Blessing (PHTS).

PENT UP [studio] (media) is a creative work space in Brooklyn, NY, specializing in visual arts, media, and live events. We want to make you feel something.

Ry Szelong is a NYC-based director, writer, performer, and designer, and recent graduate from Playwrights Horizons Theater School at NYU Tisch School of the Arts. Credits include The Skriker (director), Night of the Assassins (director), The Museum is Closed for a Private Function (writer/director, performer), and One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (director) at NYU; Vodka Flavored Water at Triskelion Arts (writer/director, performer); Miami is Sinking / Pastelito Guerreras at Dixon Place (sound design); and Pan Pan Theatre's The Rehearsal Playing the Dane (Player 3).

Why We Need You!

Here's a basic outline of where your money is going to:

Costumes! - $300 - as #cute as our cast is, we don't want them to be naked the whole time.
Props! - $250 - we would love our cast to be able to hold things and interact with things rather than tell the audience about them.
Set! - $150 - Dixon Place has blessed us with their beautiful space! We'd love to make the most of it.
Media! - $300 - this production has a heavy video component. video involves a lot of equipment! renting that can make a wallet very sad. 
Stipends! - $500 - we'd love to pay everyone who is working so hard to make this production a reality.

story:
Current Work

For its fourth performance, TREES-The Rhythm Encompassing Every Sound, acknowledges the hopes and disappointments of life in everyday New York City. It is  the city in which we live, play and work.We are New Yorkers. Here is our New Work. 

The TREES 

 An artist whether dancer, musician, actor or singer uses his or her body to communicate. 

TREES joins these expressions in innovative collaborations performed throughout New York City.We seek to bring together these individuals and to create connections of artistic communication while establishing opportunities for artists to speak their voices, in any form, to any audience.  

Hopes

  • To create relationships among musicians and dancers for further artistic works.
  • To ignite a sense of collaboration for artists to feel inspired to make art works of all types. 

How you can join

Your money makes our music stronger in these ways:

  • Supporting the artists monetarily.
  • Providing for costs of production.
  • Publicity needs such as postcards and fliers. 

We've had three performances since our premiere last summer at venues including the Bowery Electric and Spike Hill, and they are the first notes to the beginning of a beautiful song. 

Your donation will not only support this premiere performance, but it will also create a foundation for TREES to further our artistic endeavors with more performances throughout this summer and this year. Share this link with friends and family everywhere so they too can join the rhythm and feel the music. 

View an excerpt of our premiere performance at Spike Hill above with Sarah Esser and Nathan-Ellman Bell.

story:
The Ubumuntu Arts Festival

The Dream:

Rwanda, home of the Ubumuntu Arts Festival--a creative and collaborative celebration where artists, dancers, actors, producers, innovators, writers, singers, poets, thinkers and dreamers from all around the world gather to celebrate and elevate our collective humanity. This is our dream.

'Ubumuntu' means 'Humanity' in Kinyarwanda, the native tongue of Rwanda. The Festival will be the first of its kind in Rwanda-a signature event-that will hopefully change the landscape of art in East Africa and the world. 

 An annual event, the Ubumuntu Arts Festival will take place from the 11th to the 12th of July. These dates are significant because they occur during the last week of the 100 days of the Rwanda Genocide of 1994--the last week of the annual Month of Mourning in Rwanda.  

The arts have played an incredible and critical role in tackling Rwanda's immense post-genocide challenges. They have been a transformative medium of healing and reconciliation, channeling the pain, anguish and horror of our national experience into song, dance and theatre. It became the lens through which we saw and understood our humanity and the way through which we expressed our love, our hopes, our dreams and the promise for a bright future. For so many people, art became a way of life.

However, it has only just begun and we have a long way to go. We, as a country, have only just begun to realize the arts as a creative industry with the potential for employment.

The Festival not only hopes to be a gathering of creatives from around the world but also a springboard for aspiring Rwandan artists to launch their dreams- a platform for creativity, innovation, networking, ideas and collaboration. 

We believe that the unique relationship between art and social transformation in Rwanda positions us perfectly to host an international event that will bridge nations in the quest to empower and equip people with the tools to spearhead the healing process in their countries. A forum for and of unity in the name of humanity!

And who is 'we'?

The Team

The Ubumuntu Arts Festival is the dream child of Hope Azeda, the director of Mashirika Performing Arts and Media Group in Rwanda. Hope Azeda founded Mashirika as a pioneering professional group in 1997 with the purpose of using art as a tool for social transformation and healing in Rwanda. Under Hope's leadership, Mashirika has produced over 10 major original productions and has taken its message of humanity across the world to such places as the United Kingdom, Sweden, Poland, Belgium, Germany, the United States and others. 
To see more about the Ubumuntu Arts Festival team, check out the Sneak Peaks at the bottom of the page!
About Me:

My name is Jonathan Kubakundimana and art changed my life. 

I was born 6 months before the Genocide in Rwanda began and my family was marked for slaughter. We escaped to Scotland and after living there for almost 10 years we returned to Rwanda. I returned to a home that I had never known and that I struggled so painfully to understand. How could the genocide have happened? Why did it happen? Could it happen again? Where was the international community? In face of what happened in 1994, what was the meaning of humanity? At the age of 12, I was blessed to join Mashirika Performing Arts Group and the rest, as they say, is history. Through Mashirika I learned about my culture, my history and more importantly, I learned about myself. Music, dance and drama woke me up to a deep and profound understanding of humanity and the role we all MUST play  (no pun intended) to recognize, affirm and love all humanity. 

My name is Jonathan Kubakundimana and art saved my life. 

How Far We've Come in the Project:

Our current line up for this year is looking AMAZING! Artists and performing groups from Sri Lanka, USA, Canada, Serbia, Lebanon, Egypt, Ethiopia, Burundi, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Zimbabwe and Rwanda have all committed to the Ubumuntu Arts Festival . 

Scripts have been written, dances have been choreographed, poets have been inspired, artists around the world are rehearsing furiously and now we need YOUR help! 

How YOU Can Help:

While dreams are great, realizing them usually costs a pretty penny and this project is no exception! We hope that we can use the incredible resource of the internet to connect the global community of art and humanity lovers to our project and help make this dream a reality!

Your money will go to the protection of intellectual property, the hiring festival staff and production teams, the development of training material, renting fees, festival publicity and professional recording equipment!

Sneak Peaks:



Artistic Director for Zvishamiso Arts Trust in Zimbabwe, Brian is a dance choreographer and artivist. He is also a Mandela Washington fellow, a program initiated by President Obama in 2014.

Brian will also be collaborating with Eliane Umuhire , Arthur Nkusi and Simon Iyarwema from Rwanda's Mashirika Performing Arts and Media Group in creating the opening act for the Ubumuntu Arts Festival.




Jerry King and his wife Laura are the creators of the musical "Imbabazi", a musical adaptation of the feature film "Imbabazi" ( The Pardon) by Rwandan director Joel Karenzi.
Jerry King will also be directing Mashirika's original production, " Bridge of Roses".

Jerry King and his wife Laura are the creators of the musical "Imbabazi", a musical adaptation of the feature film "Imbabazi" ( The Pardon) by Rwandan director Joel Karenzi.Jerry King will also be directing Mashirika's original production, " Bridge of Roses".

story:
Your support helps us reach thousands of kids in Metro Atlanta schools each year through physically integrated dance.

In school performances by Full Radius Dance are designed to reinforce curriculum, such as character education and science, and can also serve as a meaningful way to get students of all ages involved in discussing critical issues such as negative beliefs about self-image/identity and disability awareness. PLUS it’s very entertaining to watch!

What We Need 

As we ramp up for the 2015/16 school year, we need your support to help us reach our goals to reach kids through dance in the following ways:

  • Studio space rental for choreographing and rehearsing our programs for the 2015/16 school year
  • Props and costumes for performances
  • Transportation funds
  • Outreach materials to raise awareness of our school performances

The Impact

 In the 2014/2015 school year, our two programs reached well over 2000 students.  We are on track to triple that number next year.  "The Legend of the Dragon," designed for K -5, provided a message of cooperation and empowerment, featuring audience participation and conflict resolution techniques.  Our second program "Let's Get Physics, Y'all!", developed in partnership with the Georgia Institute of Technology, illustrated basic principles of physics in an unforgettable way, while also demonstrating the power of teamwork and diversity.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute monetarily, you can still support Full Radius Dance!

  • Spread the word about our mission of educating students through the art of dance
  • Attend Full Radius Dance performances throughout the year


We thank you so much for your contribution!

story:
NEW!!! If we get 1000 people to give 10 euros, or 500 people to give 20 euros, we reach our goal!! AND we'll give out special gifts to everyone who donates! Join us in reaching our goal!!

If you would like to give more and mix and match the perks, that's possible! Simply let us know which perks you would like! :)

Don't have credit card or Paypal? Let us know and we'll find a solution! 


Modern Troubadours presents

"Fiesta de los Muertos" at Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2015

An original music-theatre-storytelling show with folktales from around the world, inspired by the Mexican festivity Day of the Dead

Fiesta de los Muertos is an original music-theatre-storytelling show, with harp, flute, percussion, singing and dance. The show is inspired by the Mexican festivity Day of the Dead, and explores the meaning and intricacies of life and death in different cultures, through folktales from around the world.

The performance takes you on a mythical journey, discovering the ancient Aztec traditions and their Queen of the underworld, meeting two old men who argue about who is right, a soldier who tries to outsmart Death, a beautiful woman whose extreme jealousy drives her to madness, and a young girl whose dream helps her surpass her sorrow.

During the Mexican Day of the Dead, friends and family gather to honour those who have passed. It is a positive affirmation of the cycle of life and death, where people can reconnect with the spirits of their loved ones. Join us in celebrating the Mexican year in the UK, and discover this beautiful and profound festivity.

The Modern Troubadours has a very international team, based in the Netherlands, with origins from Wales, Zimbabwe, France, Mexico, New York, Costa Rica and Philippines. The mix and appreciation for different cultures is at the heart of their shows. Since 2013, they have performed in Nepal, Romania, Festival Des Mots Des Maux in France, HIFA Festival in Zimbabwe, South Africa, and in the Netherlands at venues like Korzo Theater, De Nieuwe Regentes, Leidse Hofjes Concerten, and collaborating with former dancers of the Nederlands Dans Theater (NDT). The members of the Modern Troubadours are highly trained musicians and have individually performed at major festivals such as Festival d’Avignon and Arhus Festival, and worked with artists such as Jan Fabre, Asko-Schoenberg ensemble, Heiner Goebbels and Placido Domingo. 

This production was premiered in November 2014 at the Korzo Theater in The Hague (Netherlands) to a sold out audience.

This summer, we are bringing the show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, the largest performing events festival in the world and the premiere platform for launching new and innovative productions. 

We will be performing at the award-winning venue TheSpace UK, Surgeons Hall, from the 7th to 22nd August 2015. 


What We Need & What You Get

Despite being an incredible opportunity, Edinburgh is an expensive undertaking, which is why we are asking for your help. 

Your contribution will go towards covering some of the following expenses:

  • rent of the venue
  • travel expenses (from the Netherlands to Scotland)
  • accommodation for 6 people
  • hiring of instruments
  • promoting the show (printing of flyers and posters, buying publicity space, etc.)

Your generous contribution will help us bring this show to life in Edinburgh, without putting us in serious debt. And most of all, you will help us spread our philosophy of connecting people from different cultures through stories and music. 

This is your opportunity to not only sponsor a unique, independent production, but to be a part of a worldwide movement to celebrate the diversity of cultures. 

Gifts for you!

We have a number of gifts to offer you in return for your generous contribution: 

  • CDs from the Modern Troubadours and harpist Sarah Nichols
  • a Modern Troubadours certificate 
  • beautiful Mexican crafts brought directly from Mexico!
  • 2 for 1 vouchers for delicious fair-trade Moyee Coffee (http://moyeecoffee.com/)
  • unique illustrations from Pratham Books (http://prathambooks.org)
  • a private performance by the Modern Troubadours
  • free tickets to our shows

These are just a few of the perks we would like to offer you. They are different, unique, and best represent the story we want to bring about - the love of cultures! 

And don't worry, if we don't reach our goal, we will still offer you the perks, because you deserve it!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, you can still help us achieve our goal. Please spread the word!:

  • Share our Indiegogo campaign on Facebook or on Twitter using: #MuertosAtFringe
  • Tell your friends about our production and why it's important to share it with the world.  

LINKS

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/MuertosAtFringe

Twitter: @ModTroubadours https://twitter.com/ModTroubadours

Website: www.moderntroubadours.com

Trailer of the show: https://youtu.be/3EwJIG-A46c

Tickets to the show: https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/fiesta-de-los-muertos

Thank you to all those who have supported us over the years, and thank you in advance to all new supporters!

story:
[ai], A Workshop Production at the Brick

http://bricktheater.com 

I am thrilled to have an opportunity to present [ai] again soon after its initial presentation at Dixon Place. I have received a residency opportunity at the Brick Theatre in Brooklyn so that this production can continue to grow. The residency will be between Aug 3rd to 22nd, during which we will strive to polish the material, improve the staging, and quite simply, bring you a new and improved [ai] 2.0.

We want to tell the story of Anthem, originally created by Russian novelist Ayn Rand, and give it more perspectives, and welcome the spectators to explore different possibilities and outcomes of the hero's choices. The story, in which the protagonist Equality 7-2521 denounce the system of the society he lived in, and went on a quest to reclaim the meaning of individuality, is a tale timeless in nature, and has never been more relevant than it is now, as we enter the age of anonymity as a result of technology and rapid globalisation. During his journey, Equality 7-2521 discovered not only the meaning of "I", but also his desire for knowledge, for progress, and most importantly, for love. 
Anthem raised the complex question of how it is that we define concepts we seem to be familiar with: equality, liberty, community, etc. Human beings are social animals, and we struggle on, trying to find the best way to live in harmony with the rest of the world. This is a story about the tyranny of the majority, and the danger of the extremes. it is a metaphor, a caricature, a reflection of a reality we dare not to face, yet with a theatrical rendition, we hope to shed some light on such questions we all ask: how do we develop a sense of self-awareness? How do we connect with others on a personal level? What is the relationship between individuals and the community? The list goes on, and we hope you leave the theatre with some form of answers, or maybe, start asking even more questions. 
The story is nothing without the people telling it. The goal of this campaign is to raise enough so that my cast and crew will be compensated for their hard work, and that the show can meet its potential without being held back because of financial obstacles.  

And with Your Help 

  • Your contributions will help cover the cost for the residency, namely the space. There's a minimum Box Office requirement that will go to the Brick. 
  • More importantly, you are helping secure compensation for the actors and production team.   
  • If you came to our Dixon Place presentation, you'd remember that we had minimum set and no costume. In the next stage, we plan on bringing you a more enveloping experience with enhanced design elements. Your contribution will help make that possible. 
  • With your contributions, (depending on different levels), you will get a variety of perks from us. See the perks section for details. 
  • No matter how much we end up raising, first and foremost, the fund goes to cover the cost of the space as well as condensations for the cast and crew.
  • You will be part of a team making this world premiere production possible, for which I will be eternally grateful. 
  • Every little bit helps, for a forest is the sum of every single leaf. 
  • Help us spread the word even if you cannot make a contribution at this time.

story:
We're excited to let you know about the world premiere of Never Never, a play by Alexandra Petri that Barabbas Theatre is producing  in the 2015 Capital Fringe Festival. This will be the first play produced by Barabbas Theatre!

Known for past Capital Fringe hits such as Miss Emma’s Matchmaking Agency for Literary Characters and Tragedy Averted, and for her humorous opinion pieces in the Washington Post, playwright Alexandra Petri takes a dark turn with Never Never. The play, which draws parallels to J.M. Barrie’s Peter Pan stories, is about a man with deviant tendencies. He’s worked hard to keep from acting on his predilections but now faces his greatest temptation. It’s a poignant, troubling drama, but, like all of Alexandra’s writing, it’s also hysterically funny. To perform Never Never, we’ve cast four of the best young actors in the DC area: Lizzi Albert, Seth Rosenke, Matthew Sparacino, and Latia Stokes.

Barabbas Theatre has set itself a high bar for artistic excellence. To live up to that standard we need your help. Our expenses for Never Never will come to about $4,600. About 35% of that goes to paying stipends to the actors and production team—we can’t create great art without great artists. Another 35-40% will go to marketing the play—theatre is nothing without an audience. About 20% is taken up by fees paid to Capital Fringe—they provide the venue, technical equipment, box office, some marketing, and insurance. The remaining 5-10% is what we have left for the set, props, and costumes.

We’re trying to raise $3,750 to help meet these expenses and are asking you to consider making a donation to our project. Never Never is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non‐profit arts service organization. That doesn’t mean that Fractured Atlas gives us money, but it does mean that contributions for the charitable purposes of Never Never are tax‐deductible (less the value of  offered perks) to the extent permitted by law.

We know you receive many requests for money for many worthy causes. But we're asking you to recognize the intrinsic value of great theatre by supporting the world premiere of Never Never. Barabbas Theatre puts artistic merit above all else, and we’re going to prove that with Never Never. I hope you agree that this mission is worthy of your support.
