story:
Off the Rails is a black comedy about a chance meeting between two strangers. Tim Alexander was a well-respected and well-loved children’s TV presenter until one mistake turned the world against him; derailing his career, and his life, leaving him with no other option but to end it all. Carefully planned, with a note in his pocket, Tim makes his way to the abandoned station, train times memorized, ready to die. One thing he hadn’t planned for however is the arrival of Jack Fuller, a man with the exact same plan.


Off The Rails debuted at The Common Grounds festival, a four day run festival held at the University of Huddersfield as part of our final assessment at the end of our degree. We decided to extend our play, being previously restricted to 40 minutes, to a full length piece. Having received a 1st for this piece and such a fantastic reaction from members of the audience it is our intention to take our show to small theatre venues and festivals throughout the UK, and eventually taking the show to the Edinburgh Fringe.


Help us get the funds so we can; 

  • Design and build a more efficient set for transporting to multiple venues
  • Purchase more theatrical equipment e.g. lighting and smoke machine
  • Purchase costume
  • Hire out venues (inc The Guildhall Theatre in Derby, The Green Room in Carlisle and The Carraigeworks in Leeds) to get the ball rolling
  • Hire rehearsal spaces
  • Print the programs
  • Print the posters
  • Transport the equipment to and from each venue
  • Hire our technical staff
  • Get the rights to the music needed

But don't just take our word for it, here's what our audiences have to say;

‘A highly entertaining show, with excellent comedic moments and heartfelt dialogue, this show will take you on a roller coaster of emotions leaving you overwhelmed with joy and inquisitiveness. Did he jump?’ –Lee Brown

 ‘A fantastic dark comedy giving a no holds barred account of life, suicide and the decisions that go in between’ –Pancham Bansal

 ‘I have never been on such a journey of emotion as I did when watching this show. It is incredible! Having seen it twice was an honour, the lads did very well!’ –Hayley Vercammen

 ‘Hauntingly funny, a brilliant take on some serious subject matters. That said I literally laughed till my sides hurt, absolutely brilliant script, set and two cracking actors! Dean and Kristian have really outdone themselves with this one! Definitely a must see show!’ –Jess Dickinson

 ‘This play is both as funny as it is tragic. In such a short space of time I think I experienced all the human emotion a human can experience. I’ve never seen a play like it. It’s one of those plays that will leave you wondering, thinking about it for ages afterwards. Laughing at the absurdity and worrying about whether I should feel guilty for it. I can’t really explain why it had such an effect on me but I can only thank the two guys who wrote and performed such a brilliant play. I wish them all the luck in the future. I look forward to seeing more from them. I think the world of theatre might just be on the brink of something amazing.’ –Mark Allen

‘Two very talented artists, what they've done with this show is genius! Best thing I've seen in a long time.  Amazing show, these guys did so well! I went to see it twice and could watch it one hundred times! Right up my street! Fantastic.’ -Annie Holmes

‘I never expected to laugh at a show about suicide but the clever writing and comedic timing from two rare talents had me giggling all the way through. Every emotion was felt whilst watching, and it’s a pleasure to have such a sensitive subject handles in a way that makes people laugh but then also think.’ –Melissa Brayshaw

‘Off The Rails is incredible. I laughed and I cried, this astounding piece brings a sensitive subject right to the front of our consciousness, and makes us think. In this piece suicide is thought about in a heart-wrenching way, but the relationship between the two characters brings a hilarious twist to a play with such a fragile subject. I am sure Off The Rails will effect tonnes of people as much as it affected me and hopefully it will help to educate people about suicide’ -Danielle Chesney

‘There were moments which made me laugh hysterically along with moments that left a lump in my throat’ -Raisa Malika

'Off The Rails... What can I say? It's magic in a show. Very funny, very classy and very well performed. It has been made by a crew of two; that's not to say there's any less talent involved. Kris McJames and Dean Greer are a duo of fantastic creativity.’ -Jack Midgley

‘This show is both heart wrenching yet heart-warming, a perfect balance of comedy and drama to create such a beautiful masterpiece. A stunning piece of writing that ticks all the boxes. One of the most thought provoking and well scripted pieces of theatre that I have ever seen.’ –Veronica Finney

‘The brilliant show Off The Rails written by Dean Greer and Kris McJames is honestly still one of the best shows I've ever seen, professional or amateur, beautifully written and performed, brilliantly directed and hilarious throughout.’ –Billy Larkin

‘An absolutely phenomenal piece of work’ –Sean Sewell

‘Off The Rails is an absolutely stunning play and is so funny I recommend anybody to see it’ –Ryan Metcalfe

‘I found the show very thought provoking and fantastically funny but emotional all at the same time. People should go to see this show to watch the brilliance of these two very talented people.’ ­–Hannah Midgley

‘This is an amazing show that was written, directed and performed by two talented actors. One of the best shows I have seen and it deserves more recognition.’ –Sammie Ross

‘Off The Rails is truly brilliant show that deserves to go on tour... not just around the UK but the world!’ –Chloe Connett

‘These guys have conjured one the funniest plays and performances I have seen to date. They've worked incredibly hard in creating a fantastic piece of comedy drama, I would seriously recommend you catch their show where & when you can!’ –Jak Bowler


The Development Process

When approaching this project we were undergoing training in the Alba Method by attending workshops held by Dr Eric Hetzler of the University of Huddersfield. The Alba Method was developed in the 1970s by psychologist Susana Bloch. Alba presents the actor with a combination of breathing patterns, postural attitude and facial expressions, enabling the actor to have access to these six basic emotions; Tender Love, Anger, Sexual Love, Fear, Joy and Sadness. Exploring these six emotions with a different intensity, on a scale of 1-5, enables the performer to access a wide variety of emotions. The actor can also explore combinations of the 6 in order to find a wider range. Alba is believed to give the actor more control over their emotions and leaves the actor with more mental stability, Alba requires the actor to portray the emotion physically which will then enable the actor to feel the emotion inside. Wanting to explore Alba even further we had the idea to create a piece of theatre using Alba as a starting point. The idea we had was to get ourselves into a workshop space, put ourselves into an emotion of our choosing, by using the Alba technique, then improvising a scene while in that emotion. The pure reason for this being our initial idea of creativity is that we had researched a lot about actors using Alba in TV, film and theatre as a way of them approaching a text and portraying their character's emotions within the text, but we had never come across any use of Alba as a creative and writing tool. So that is exactly what we wanted to do. I’d say 80% of our final performance was created this way, the rest being written without the aid of Alba in order to link certain parts together to enable them to flow. As we are both stand-up comedians the show, through improvisation, naturally became a comedy.


For more updates about the progress of the show and for more images of the production don't forget to like our Facebook fan page!
story_txt:
Off the Rails is a black comedy about a chance meeting between two strangers. Tim Alexander was a well-respected and well-loved children’s TV presenter until one mistake turned the world against him; derailing his career, and his life, leaving him with no other option but to end it all. Carefully planned, with a note in his pocket, Tim makes his way to the abandoned station, train times memorized, ready to die. One thing he hadn’t planned for however is the arrival of Jack Fuller, a man with the exact same plan.Off The Rails debuted at The Common Grounds festival, a four day run festival held at the University of Huddersfield as part of our final assessment at the end of our degree. We decided to extend our play, being previously restricted to 40 minutes, to a full length piece. Having received a 1st for this piece and such a fantastic reaction from members of the audience it is our intention to take our show to small theatre venues and festivals throughout the UK, and eventually taking the show to the Edinburgh Fringe.Help us get the funds so we can; 
Design and build a more efficient set for transporting to multiple venues
Purchase more theatrical equipment e.g. lighting and smoke machine
Purchase costume
Hire out venues (inc The Guildhall Theatre in Derby, The Green Room in Carlisle and The Carraigeworks in Leeds) to get the ball rolling
Hire rehearsal spaces
Print the programs
Print the posters
Transport the equipment to and from each venue
Hire our technical staff
Get the rights to the music needed

But don't just take our word for it, here's what our audiences have to say;
‘A highly entertaining
show, with excellent comedic moments and heartfelt dialogue, this show will
take you on a roller coaster of emotions leaving you overwhelmed with joy and
inquisitiveness. Did he jump?’ –Lee
Brown
 ‘A fantastic dark comedy giving a no holds
barred account of life, suicide and the decisions that go in between’ –Pancham Bansal
 ‘I have never been on such a journey of
emotion as I did when watching this show. It is incredible! Having seen it
twice was an honour, the lads did very well!’ –Hayley Vercammen
 ‘Hauntingly funny, a brilliant take on some
serious subject matters. That said I literally laughed till my sides hurt,
absolutely brilliant script, set and two cracking actors! Dean and Kristian
have really outdone themselves with this one! Definitely a must see show!’ –Jess
Dickinson
 ‘This play is both as funny as it is tragic.
In such a short space of time I think I experienced all the human emotion a
human can experience. I’ve never seen a play like it. It’s one of those plays
that will leave you wondering, thinking about it for ages afterwards. Laughing
at the absurdity and worrying about whether I should feel guilty for it. I
can’t really explain why it had such an effect on me but I can only thank the
two guys who wrote and performed such a brilliant play. I wish them all the luck
in the future. I look forward to seeing more from them. I think the world of
theatre might just be on the brink of something amazing.’ –Mark Allen
‘Two very talented
artists, what they've done with this show is genius! Best thing I've seen in a
long time.  Amazing show, these guys did
so well! I went to see it twice and could watch it one hundred times! Right up my
street! Fantastic.’ -Annie Holmes
‘I never
expected to laugh at a show about suicide but the clever writing and comedic
timing from two rare talents had me giggling all the way through. Every emotion
was felt whilst watching, and it’s a pleasure to have such a sensitive subject
handles in a way that makes people laugh but then also think.’ –Melissa Brayshaw
‘Off The Rails is
incredible. I laughed and I cried, this astounding piece brings a sensitive
subject right to the front of our consciousness, and makes us think. In this
piece suicide is thought about in a heart-wrenching way, but the relationship
between the two characters brings a hilarious twist to a play with such a
fragile subject. I am sure Off The Rails will effect tonnes of people as much
as it affected me and hopefully it will help to educate people about suicide’ -Danielle Chesney
‘There were moments which
made me laugh hysterically along with moments that left a lump in my throat’ -Raisa Malika
'Off The Rails... What can
I say? It's magic in a show. Very funny, very classy and very well performed.
It has been made by a crew of two; that's not to say there's any less talent
involved. Kris McJames and Dean Greer are a duo of fantastic creativity.’ -Jack Midgley
‘This show is both heart
wrenching yet heart-warming, a perfect balance of comedy and drama to create
such a beautiful masterpiece. A stunning piece of writing that ticks all the
boxes. One of the most thought provoking and well scripted pieces of theatre
that I have ever seen.’ –Veronica Finney
‘The brilliant show Off
The Rails written by Dean Greer and Kris McJames is honestly still one of the
best shows I've ever seen, professional or amateur, beautifully written and
performed, brilliantly directed and hilarious throughout.’ –Billy Larkin
‘An absolutely phenomenal
piece of work’ –Sean Sewell
‘Off The Rails is an
absolutely stunning play and is so funny I recommend anybody to see it’ –Ryan Metcalfe
‘I found the show very
thought provoking and fantastically funny but emotional all at the same time.
People should go to see this show to watch the brilliance of these two very
talented people.’ ­–Hannah Midgley
‘This is an amazing show
that was written, directed and performed by two talented actors. One of the
best shows I have seen and it deserves more recognition.’ –Sammie Ross
‘Off The Rails is truly
brilliant show that deserves to go on tour... not just around the UK but the
world!’ –Chloe Connett
‘These guys have conjured one the funniest plays
and performances I have seen to date. They've worked incredibly hard in
creating a fantastic piece of comedy drama, I would seriously recommend you
catch their show where & when you can!’ –Jak BowlerThe Development ProcessWhen approaching this project we were undergoing training in the Alba Method by attending workshops held by Dr Eric Hetzler of the University of Huddersfield. The Alba Method was developed in the 1970s by psychologist Susana Bloch. Alba presents the actor with a combination of breathing patterns, postural attitude and facial expressions, enabling the actor to have access to these six basic emotions; Tender Love, Anger, Sexual Love, Fear, Joy and Sadness. Exploring these six emotions with a different intensity, on a scale of 1-5, enables the performer to access a wide variety of emotions. The actor can also explore combinations of the 6 in order to find a wider range. Alba is believed to give the actor more control over their emotions and leaves the actor with more mental stability, Alba requires the actor to portray the emotion physically which will then enable the actor to feel the emotion inside. Wanting to explore Alba even further we had the idea to create a piece of theatre using Alba as a starting point. The idea we had was to get ourselves into a workshop space, put ourselves into an emotion of our choosing, by using the Alba technique, then improvising a scene while in that emotion. The pure reason for this being our initial idea of creativity is that we had researched a lot about actors using Alba in TV, film and theatre as a way of them approaching a text and portraying their character's emotions within the text, but we had never come across any use of Alba as a creative and writing tool. So that is exactly what we wanted to do. I’d say 80% of our final performance was created this way, the rest being written without the aid of Alba in order to link certain parts together to enable them to flow. As we are both stand-up comedians the show, through improvisation, naturally became a comedy.For more updates about the progress of the show and for more images of the production don't forget to like our Facebook fan page!

story:
--ladyfestCLT 2019-- 

ladyfestCLT (previously Women's Showcase) was started in January of 2015. Since its inaugural performance at the Neighborhood Theatre, ladyfestCLT has returned to perform at Goodyear Arts, the Patricia McBride and Jean-Pierre Bonnefoux Center for Dance at Charlotte Ballet, and c3 Lab, an artist event and co-working space in Charlotte's South End District. In  total, ladyfestCLT has presented 45 Artists representing 18 Cities and 11 States.  This year for our 5th anniversary performance, we will be showcasing artists, both new and from previous seasons, to celebrate the collaboration and presentation of female makers in the southeast.

ladyfestCLT 2019 will take place Saturday, January 12th, 2019 at Goodyear Arts.

ladyfesstCLT is comprised of a diverse range of artists and mediums.  In addition, this year we are curating a ladyfestCLT Zine to act as a program. Poetry, prose, and visual art by our female makers will be curated alongside the program information for the performance to create an interactive and cross-discipline experience, exposing the audience to even more female driven art.

With your contribution, we invite you to be a part of our 5th anniversary performance!

 

-- WHAT WE NEED --

We are raising funds to allow our artists the space to create without worrying about having to pay to perform. 

Our costs to bring this festival to the community include: 

chairs and risers for audience space

advertisement and programs

stipends for traveling artists

refreshments

payment to videographers/photographers

In an effort to pay the choreographers and performers for their work, ALL PROCEEDS FROM TICKET SALES WILL GO TO THE PARTICIPATING ARTISTS. By contributing to this campaign, you allow more of the ticket sales to go to the artists, rather than offsetting the cost of the production.

You, the contributor, will also be recognized as a supporter of ladyfestCLT, PLUS we have some awesome perks for ladyfest VIPs!

 

-- MISSION --

ladyfestCLT seeks to draw the public's eye to the important work of female performing artists and choreographers by facilitating a cross-disciplinary festival featuring the women leaders of the Charlotte arts community and beyond. Gathering for an evening of sharing, we aim to create a space that celebrates the accomplishments of female creators, bringing diverse artists together, and facilitating dialogue between audience and performers concerning work that is made through the female lens.

 

-- CHALLENGES --

While we do not aim to discredit or exclude the accomplishments of our male partners, we desire to draw attention to the voices of the women in our field and give them the opportunity to share their own stories. This is an event by women celebrating the diversity of our work and creative voices.

The costs  associated with creating a performance are intimidating for one artist to bear alone. By working together and forming a community evening, we are able to support each other in our endeavor to show our work. We hope you will join us as a part of our creative community and support the art you wish to see!

 

-- OTHER WAYS TO HELP --

ladyfestCLT Fundraiser

December 15th at Goodyear Arts | 8-10pm

$5 donation to ladyfestCLT Dance Party | BYOB

Any amount of donation to our Indiegogo will get you into the dance party. We will have a costume sale and encourage all in attendance to come dressed up. We believe that dancing as a community is a powerful way to come together for a cause, and we don't get enough opportunities to move together. Come dance and support ladyfestCLT with us!

AND

Come see the show! We would appreciate your support and would love to see you there. Bring a friend, have a drink, and talk to the artists about their work!

If you would like to further volunteer or help with ladyfestCLT 2019, contact us at ladyfestCLT@gmail.com.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT AND WE WILL SEE YOU AT THE SHOW!

story:
Short Summary

  • We represent Karin scientific center, which is founded in Karin educational cultural NGO, which was founded on the base of Karin folk dance and song group in 2015. The founder is honoured figure of culture of RA Gagik Ginosyan. The group has gathered a number of ancient dances and songs and raised them on the stage. But there are a number of material which are needed to be digitalized. Now the Scientific Center wants to this work.
  • Saving Armenian ancient folk dances and songs - the mission of this people, gathered all together, who wanted to save their own culture. The group was founded in 2001 and is doing that hard work just based on the idea that only by mastering our culture we can be worth children for our homeland.
  • We have a huge material gathered, which needs to be digitalized. We hope to do that work with your help, after which we will process the all material and raise it back to the stage.The next step will be giving that songs and dances to Armenian people by helping them to study what we already master. Also we have a hope to go to Armenian far villages and gather new samples.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Your help is needed to buy some instruments for materials digitalization, also for employees who will do the work. And for the next step - walking in far villages and gathering new materials.
  • In far villages in Armenia are living people who are heirs of 1915 genocide survivors. That people have a knowledge which we need, but unfortunately, they are old-aged. In this case we don't have much time to rescue the last samples of Armenian culture.
  • If we will not reach the goal we marked, the collected amount will help to do the digitalization partly.

The Impact

  • This project is very important for our nation, because we will finally partly master our culture and help the growing generation to study it. And as the Armenia is a small, but yet very important part of the world, the project is also important for the world, because Armenian cultural heritage is world's cultural heritage too.
  • We have done the same kind of project with financial help of US embassy in Armenia. That time we walked in 4 Armenian regions and gathered about 50 samples of dances.
  • Also we made 2 DVD-dance teachers with HAY ASPET foundation and JINISHYAN memorial foundation. DVD-dance teachers are made from a book with dance stories and DVD with dance performances and also dance teaching videos. 
  • At the end of the work we will represent you a short film about the project process and results.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you cannot donate, you still can share this project with your environment. That would be a huge help too, because maybe one of your acquaintances can help us with donation.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
Short Summary

We represent Karin scientific center, which is founded in Karin educational cultural NGO, which was founded on the base of Karin folk dance and song group in 2015. The founder is honoured figure of culture of RA Gagik Ginosyan. The group has gathered a number of ancient dances and songs and raised them on the stage. But there are a number of material which are needed to be digitalized. Now the Scientific Center wants to this work.
Saving Armenian ancient folk dances and songs - the mission of this people, gathered all together, who wanted to save their own culture. The group was founded in 2001 and is doing that hard work just based on the idea that only by mastering our culture we can be worth children for our homeland.
We have a huge material gathered, which needs to be digitalized. We hope to do that work with your help, after which we will process the all material and raise it back to the stage.The next step will be giving that songs and dances to Armenian people by helping them to study what we already master. Also we have a hope to go to Armenian far villages and gather new samples.


What We Need & What You Get

Your help is needed to buy some instruments for materials digitalization, also for employees who will do the work. And for the next step - walking in far villages and gathering new materials.
In far villages in Armenia are living people who are heirs of 1915 genocide survivors. That people have a knowledge which we need, but unfortunately, they are old-aged. In this case we don't have much time to rescue the last samples of Armenian culture.
If we will not reach the goal we marked, the collected amount will help to do the digitalization partly.


The Impact

This project is very important for our nation, because we will finally partly master our culture and help the growing generation to study it. And as the Armenia is a small, but yet very important part of the world, the project is also important for the world, because Armenian cultural heritage is world's cultural heritage too.
We have done the same kind of project with financial help of US embassy in Armenia. That time we walked in 4 Armenian regions and gathered about 50 samples of dances.
Also we made 2 DVD-dance teachers with HAY ASPET foundation and JINISHYAN memorial foundation. DVD-dance teachers are made from a book with dance stories and DVD with dance performances and also dance teaching videos. 
At the end of the work we will represent you a short film about the project process and results.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, you still can share this project with your environment. That would be a huge help too, because maybe one of your acquaintances can help us with donation.
You can use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Hello, I am Charlotte Johnson a Dance Artist here in the St. Petersburg and Tampa Bay area of Florida. I was blessed to grow up in a community that supported the education of young dancers, however when it comes to thriving as a professional dance artist, we have a long way to go. After Studying in New York City and returning back to my hometown, I believe my purpose and desired obligation it to help build the professional dance community. My gift has always been to draw the audience into my world and the world that I create while on stage. I know that God has called me to evoke a shift and a movement in someone's life which is my true heart's desire with the vision of Journey to Freedom. This project will also offer more opportunities for the professional dancers and performers in the area.

As a backer your contribution will help bring this passion project to life and really aide the artist and audience members who are desperate for a change, and a shift in their lives.

What We Need 

We are asking for $5,000 dollars to help Bring Journey to Freedom to the Stage.

  • Dancers
  • Spoken Word Artist
  • Musicians
  • Costumes
  • Lighting/Props/Set
  • Marketing/Promotions
  • Studio Rental/Rehearsal Space

All of these components cost money and are a necessity for this work. JTF may struggle moving forward with out your help.

The Impact

I know that JTF will have a positive impact on the community because I believe that this is a project that speaks to one's own personal battles, and struggles and literally portrays life on stage. Whether they are apart of the work in a creative way or someone in the audience, this work will not only plant a seed but actually begin to evoke a movement in their lives.

Journey to Freedom was first performed on Sarasota Contemporary Dance Company in December of 2018 and prior to that it was work shopped on SCD's summer intensive dance students. In both of the creative opportunities some dancers and audience members shared with me the impact that it had on them emotionally and what it meant for them to be apart and/or a witness to this work.

This is my hope for all who are evolved.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to provide any financial backing, there are other ways that you can help.

  • Please Support by spreading the word about the campaign
  • Please Share with friends and your personal networks by using the Indiegogo share tools!
  • If you are in the St. Pete/Tampa Bay Area Show up by volunteering your time or coming to a night of the production.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Amelia Sciandra, I founded the company Borderline Confrontational, and I need your help to make my dream come true. I wrote a play that is an adaptation of the Trojan War myth. An LGBT love story between Achilles and his companion Patroclus, Glorious, but Brief is a collision of the classics with seemingly modern themes. 

The show will have its world premiere at the Bread & Roses Theatre in Clapham. They're a great space for showcasing new work because they don't charge companies with rental fees. But they do take a split of the box office. So we need your help to fund the show. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise £5000. 

You will fund: 

  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Set pieces
  • Marketing materials
  • The talent**

**We firmly believe that actors, designers and stage managers should never have to work for free. By helping us hit our goal, you'll ensure that our creatives are fairly compensated for their hard work. 

By donating, you're eligible for perks! 

You could receive:

  • a mention in the program
  • a Glorious, but Brief  sticker
  • a postcard from our actors
  • a signed copy of the script
  • and more! 

Your Impact

Glorious, but Brief frames a familiar story in a "modern" way. LGBT transparency is important as we continue the fight for tolerance and acceptance. Our story aims to remind audiences that love is love and has always been. By donating to our campaign, you'll ensure this vital story is told in the best way it can be. You'll be a part of the start of what we hope is a big journey for our little show.

Borderline Confrontational has a track record of success. Indiegogo contributions helped us make our show Fugitive Songs a great success at the Royal Birmingham Conservatoire, and helped fund our terrifically successful run of Godspell  at the Edinburgh Fringe in 2016. 

Risks & Challenges

Producing theatre isn't cheap. We have an incredible costume designer who is going to build togas and chiton from scratch for our actors. We have a stage manager who will make the entire process run smoothly. We have 6 supremely talented actors from all over the world who will bring thi story to life. These people need to be paid. No one should work for free, and this is our greatest challenge: ensuring a fair wage. Help us make art that pays artists.

In my wildest dreams, we would cover our stage in sand and build a huge canvas tent. We would have live music and a thousand lighting cues. But we're limited by a pub theatre stage and our finances, so your contributions ensure we can create a little bit of theatre magic in the space we can. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't flush enough to donate (and trust us, WE UNDERSTAND!), please consider letting your friends, colleagues and any strangers you meet know about our campaign.

Share us far and wide on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, Reddit, Tumblr, and any other social media portal you use. Email our campaign to your great aunt and your third cousin and your old fishing buddy. We appreciate any noise about us out there, so thank you in advance for shouting us from the rooftops!

story:
Our Collective: 艺族 STRANGER

艺族 STRANGER is a Singapore theatre collective. We are six artists who graduated from the second cohort of ARTivate, the youth wing of Drama Box. As theatre-makers working in an increasingly fractured society, we strive to find common ground while celebrating individuality. With a keen interest in social issues, we aspire to make art that reflects social reality and resonates with our audience.

We are Angelina, Melody, Pei Si, Chun Long, Wee Peng & Yi Kai.

Our past works in ARTivate include:

  • 《㗝呸店》KOPITIAM (2016) - Co-produced by Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay & Drama Box, featuring ARTivate

  • 《告白》CONFESSION (2015) - Presented as part of Drama Box's SCENES: FORUM THEATRE

 

Our Project: 《化十言吾》KNOTS

《化十言吾》KNOTS is our first major project as a collective. It is an original work to be presented through the Singapore Chinese Language Theatre Alliance (SCLTA)'s New Works Initiative. The play seeks to explore the nature of the Singapore Chinese identity and its inherent contradictions.

 

Our Request

Truth be told, we have been very fortunate to be selected to be part of the SCLTA's New Works Initiative. We are thankful for the funding and mentorship provided to us thus far. However, being the ambitious youths that we are, we think it is possible to stretch ourselves more.

If you believe in us, we invite you to contribute to our fundraising efforts. Your generosity will go a long way in helping us better finance the production, ensure more equitable pay for all parties involved, and ultimately realise the vision we have for the play. We will also channel unused funds towards our future productions.

The details of our performance are as follows:

  • Dates: 13 & 14 September 2019 (Friday & Saturday)
  • Time: 3pm (Saturday only) & 8pm
  • Venue: Esplanade Theatre Studio

For more updates on the collective, 《化十言吾》KNOTS, and other upcoming projects, do follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/yizustranger/

 

Thank you,

Angelina, Melody, Pei Si, Chun Long, Wee Peng & Yi Kai

story:
Overview

 

Thread is the new play by provocative playwright Freya Alderson. Directed by Veronica Quilligan and produced by The XV Theatre Company.  At the heart, Thread is about family ties and how they sometimes weave a tangled web of conflicting emotions, particularly when the family is fractured by the ricochet of dementia and secrets from the past. A story about those who suffer from dementia and those who care for them. 

A personal piece of theatre for many of the creatives involved, as they have family members suffering with dementia. We aim to educate and challenge perceptions, whilst providing an evening of electric theatre with some of the best talent the UK has to offer. 

We are delighted to have been offered a 3 week run at the award winning The Hope Theatre, Islington, but we need your help to truly bring this important piece to life.

We need your support!

Helping support this piece will allow us to achieve the following:

  • We're raising funds to pay all our actors the Equity Minimum Wage, so we can bring as much awareness about the disease as possible. 
  • We set a target goal of £4500 (though we'd love to raise even more!)
  • The productions costs will be approx £7000 but we are investing in this project ourselves. 
  • Whilst we are confident the box office will be a success, £4500 will ensure that all our creatives are paid Equity Minimum Wage, something the XV Theatre feels passionate about. 

The Theatre Company is not aiming to take any profits from the show. After covering costs all the profits will be reinvested into future productions. 

Why are we performing this play? 

  • Around 850,00 in the UK have dementia, though those suffering stories are rarely heard
  • Unpaid carers supporting someone with dementia save the economy £11 billion a year. This is driven by their love and friendship for the sufferers -  something that is honoured and highlighted in this play. 
  • Research and understanding is vital. This play aims to show solidarity to carers and seeks to educate those who have misjudged those with the disease. 
  • We aim to raise awareness for this vital cause. 

Why Us?

We are an emerging theatre company and have already managed to produce some plays with some lovely reviews: Here are some reviews of our previous works:

“Baby Mine is a quiet show with stewing, building suspense. A bona fide
thriller... ” Broadway World 

“ Her final decision right before the blackout, hit the audience like a
powerful wave, and I even shed a tear. Baby Mine Is a good show, but
what’s more important is that it truly has the potential to be outstanding.” Fringe Review

“Beautifully nuanced and complex writing about sex, love, power and
obsession.” Simon Nelson, BBC Writers Room

"The set is beautiful,"The set design of Erini Kariori is quite masterful. The use of Umbrellas is brilliant." Richard Brain, London Pub Theatres (Perfect Pitch, The Tabard Theatre 2018)

"A smashing production!" Penny Flood, ChiswickW4.com (Perfect Pitch, The Tabard Theatre 2018)

Why You?

Any help you can offer us will be so gratefully received. We are passionate about theatre, writing, and paying our artists a fair wage. We feel this play is an important comment on the dementia crisis that is too often hidden behind closed doors.

Spreading this message will make a huge difference in the fight against dementia.

story:
Ryerson Musical Theatre Company (RMTC) is Ryerson University’s only extracurricular musical theatre group. Comprised of five teams (executive, production, creative, cast and orchestra), we give musical theatre opportunities to over 100 students in all faculties at Ryerson. As a completely student-led group, we rely on community support to ensure we have the necessary means to produce quality shows year after year.  Our past sold-out shows include Thoroughly Modern Millie (2015-2016), The Drowsy Chaperone (2016-2017), Into the Woods (2017-2018), and Disney's Newsies (2018-2019). 

RMTC is delighted to present Big Fish as our fifth show from March 11-14, 2020. Based on the novel by Daniel Wallace and motion picture directed by Tim Burton, Big Fish tells the story of Edward Bloom, a travelling salesman who tells grand, larger-than-life stories. Edward’s son Will is determined to find the truth in his father’s stories, culminating into a heartfelt story about love, loss, friendship, family, and being the hero of your story. 

“Big Fish” is presented through special arrangement with and all authorized performance materials are supplied by Theatrical Rights Worldwide, 1180 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 640, New York, NY 10036. www.theatricalrights.com. 

Due to increasingly limited student group funding, our goal is to raise $3,000 to acquire our venue, set, costumes, orchestra equipment, and marketing materials. To make this production a reality, we ask for your support in any way possible. 

Based on your contribution amount, you will be eligible to receive perks, such as RMTC merchandise or a pair of tickets to one of our shows in March 2020. 

Regardless of which team our members are a part of, RMTC is a safe haven to create, collaborate, and share their passion for musical theatre. Our annual production is a direct result of hard work, devotion and countless hours of rehearsing, building, designing and planning. Your support helps us make our show the best it can be, allowing us to share our love of musical theatre with the world!


RMTC greatly appreciates any form of support you can give. If you are unable to contribute to our campaign, help us spread the word by sharing this fundraiser on social media and buying tickets to our show (tickets launch in early 2020 via our website)! 

If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us at ryersonmt@gmail.com.

Follow us on Facebook and Instagram for updates and a behind-the-scenes look at our production.

story:
the Phoenix & Why You Should Support It

  • I'm currently trying to secure the former Catastrophic Theater space near downtown Houston.
  • My name is Leighza Walker and if you've heard of me, that's all you need to know.
  • If you haven't heard of me, Hi! and thanks for thinking about supporting my newest project, the Phoenix Theater. Let me convince you that it's the right thing to do. I have a proven background in managing a theater space and 40 years of theater experience. 
  • By contributing to the Phoenix, you're helping Houston, Texas grow by one more performance arts venue. What does that mean to Houston and to its residents? MORE ART!
  • Houston is desperately in need of more venues. New theater companies are in need of more places to perform. 
  • I've done this before and I can do it again. My old theater became one of the most popular places to be within six months. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Money. That's what we need. For tools, materials, lighting and sound equipment and renovations to our space. I wouldn't mind paying people for their expertise, either.
  • People. Your skills, energy, experience, imagination and dedication to Houston theater are necessary to the creation of the Phoenix. 
  • Stuff: Do you have some building materials or tools laying around your garage? Did you own a theater once and you still have those dimmer boxes and lighting instruments cluttering up your attic? Plywood, 2x4's, BLACK PAINT! 
  • What do you get? Satisfaction isn't good enough! How about tickets, t-shirts, your name in the program or on the lobby wall (why not both?), a free weekend rental? How about we name the dressing rooms or the box office after you? 
  • Every penny we raise goes into the theater. Our needs are broken down into Immediate, Soon, A Little Later, and Some Day. This campaign covers all the way through Soon and into A Little Later. Some Day is always around the corner!

What Can Stop Us?

  • Only one thing: lack of support. Money, manpower, and me. That's what it will take to make this happen. Am I sure about that? Yes. I'm certain I can do this, if you will stand behind me. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Volunteer: can you use power tools? Paint? Sweep?Sew? Build sets or hang lights or act or direct or produce theater? How about tend bar? 
  • Share this campaign!!

story:
"Welcome onboard the year 2015. It's dark, disturbing but often very funny. Please sit back and try to relax as five new playwrights guide you through the trials and turbulences of the 21st century. There are no emergency exits."

We are Robert Holtom and Simon Jay, who were originally contracted by IdeasTap to produce prize winning plays for their 2015 festival. After the sad demise of IdeasTap Robert wanted to continue the project under his own steam and Simon was more than happy to get onboard. So, the show will go on!

To make it happen we need your help! We're working with charities and other sponsors to ensure costs are low but we need a small amount to incentivise and respect the actors, to cover marketing costs and making set/costume look the best it can be. That's what the £1000 fundraising target will go towards. Meanwhile, all proceeds from the play will be donated to Mind, the mental health charity.

Thank you in advance for your support! The arts wouldn't be the same without you.

If you can't give any cash there are other ways in which you can help, please do tweet and share the campaign/event with others (find it on facebook), do get in touch if you can help with props sourcing, marketing, costume lending. If you wanted to volunteer your time on the project, even an hour flyering, or knowing someone on a local newspaper who could cover the show, everything helps. 

As for the play itself: it will be performed at The Bread & Roses Theatre in Clapham from 13th - 17th October, 7.30pm. Directed by Simon Jay and written by five new voices of British theatre:

  • Hole by Marietta Kirkbride - Josh is alone. The whole world is against him. Only Steve understands. Sit with Steve and listen as one man unburdens his woes.
  • The 7–11 Butterfly Effect by Don Grimme - A teacher in the distant future tells their young students about the dark days of the early 21st century, a time shrouded in myth.
  • Fat by Robert Holtom - A lone woman sits in a Tesco’s car park whilst contemplating her favourite foods, sexual predilections and a super sized coffin.
  • Three Sides of a Fence by Atar Haradi - An old man, a young Arab and a Hassidic Jew all reveal their side of one painful, historic story.
  • Universally Speaking by Conor Carroll - Watch as one man’s grim reality is played out in three different ways. A dark take on celebrity and crime.


Following is more information on the show and fundraiser:

  • Each Actor (they'll be at least 6) will be paid £100 as well as the tech person, the remaining money will be spent on advertising and props (a lot of which we hope we can source very cheaply).
  • Luckily working with such talented and creative people, there are no end of original, creative ideas we have come up with to fund our project. From personalised poetry, greetings cards and plays that can be performed in your living-room. 
  • If we unfortunately don't raise our funding target, the money we do raise will still be divided fairly between the creative team.
  • We feel that it is important to support the arts in Britain, and with IdeasTap closing, it has become harder than ever for emerging artists to showcase their work and build on their career.
  • Robert and Myself have produced over 20 plays between us here are some examples: http://itssimonjay.co.uk/scrinium/directing-credits/  and https://humanconditioned.wordpress.com/writing/
  • The producing team are working completely for free, and we are happy to, but we feel that it would be unfair to make a large group of people that will have to make this project come alive, to be asked to work for nothing to, as in working for us, they will inevitably give up paid work.
  • Since 2010, Simon Jay has produced plays with little or no budget. By not relying on arts council funding or other funding bodies, a lot of ingenuity had to be learnt and applied very quickly. Jay has managed to put on full-scale musicals with meagre budgets or political pieces in London with the reliance of charity groups such as Amnesty International. With a real work ethic and an ability to adapt quickly to any problem, Simon ensures that a production will go ahead, even if actors fall ill, venues fall through or any other of the myriad problems that can befall a theatre production. 
  • We have a contingent to continue the project if any of the perceived risks to the production occur. (Venue change, Actor dropping out), we have covered ourselves pretty tightly, with back-up venues, understudies and so on.

Jay has managed to put on full-scale musicals with meagre budgets or political pieces in London with the reliance of charity groups such as Amnesty International. With a real work ethic and an ability to adapt quickly to any problem, Simon ensures that a production will go ahead, even if actors fall ill, venues fall through or any other of the myriad problems that can befall a theatre production.  We have a contingent to continue the project if any of the perceived risks to the production occur. (Venue change, Actor dropping out), we have covered ourselves pretty tightly, with back-up venues, understudies and so on.

story:
About This Project.

Hello From Natasha & Dave and thank you for visiting  our page!!

Natasha Mansell working through some choreography with Carly Psutka

Dave Mansell checking the framing - photo Pat Kinnee
Natasha and Dave, who both have an extensive history of production and creative projects, formed Tilted Arts as a way of combining their shared passions for dance and cinema. Since the formation of the company, they have worked hard over the last year to conceptualize what has now become this dance and film project.  As a result, they are more than excited to announce V (five) - a short film for dancers.  
The five-movement film explores the complex stages of grief, in reference to the Kübler-Ross model, which is perceived by Carly Psutka's character.  The technical concept is rooted in the unique way that Natasha's choreography and Dave's camera techniques will work in collaboration to move the dancers beyond their natural kinesphere into cinematic frame.  A wide range of movement and special cinematography techniques, thanks to stabilization technology, allow for limitless possibilities for the dancers and the camera.  We are also thrilled to be working in a lovely old theatre in the heart of Kitchener, Ontario called the Registry Theatre where we have access to an incredible lighting array and a fantastic open space for the dancers.

The wonderful Registry Theatre in Kitchener.  

Making an independent film is a massive financial and technical strain, especially when working with dancers, since you have to be careful of fatigue and injuries. Your help, however small, can go a long way!  You will get a stunning widescreen HD copy of the film, which is set to be released this fall.  If you are fortunate enough to have more means at your disposal, please consider an executive producer option, which will earn you a producer credit on our team.

One of the hardest challenges is when the work is completed and the submission to a growing number of international film festivals begins.  It can be difficult and emotionally taxing when repeatedly submitting a work like this for review, even though it is a known part of the process.  We believe strongly in this project and we'd like to share this film with as many people as possible and submit it to international film festivals.  Dave & Natasha are experienced producers and are not only prepared for these challenges; they are fully committed to seeing that this project gets as much attention as possible in the right venues.  The support of financial backers, and even social media, help makes a massive difference to the cast and crew in helping us achieve even higher goals.

Other Ways You Can Help.

If you love this project and don't have money to contribute, that's okay!  We would love it if you supported us by way of twitter, instagram, Facebook and other social media shares.  Follow us @TiltedArts and post the video and photo links as we release them and help spread the word about this beautiful art form and our Company's dedication to producing quality content.

Download as many graphics as you want and post them like crazy!

Thank you so much, 

Natasha & Dave

Natasha and Dave, who both have an extensive history of production and creative projects, formed Tilted Arts as a way of combining their shared passions for dance and cinema. Since the formation of the company, they have worked hard over the last year to conceptualize what has now become this dance and film project.  As a result, they are more than excited to announce V (five) - a short film for dancers.  
The five-movement film explores the complex stages of grief, in reference to the Kübler-Ross model, which is perceived by Carly Psutka's character.  The technical concept is rooted in the unique way that Natasha's choreography and Dave's camera techniques will work in collaboration to move the dancers beyond their natural kinesphere into cinematic frame.  A wide range of movement and special cinematography techniques, thanks to stabilization technology, allow for limitless possibilities for the dancers and the camera.  We are also thrilled to be working in a lovely old theatre in the heart of Kitchener, Ontario called the Registry Theatre where we have access to an incredible lighting array and a fantastic open space for the dancers.
The wonderful Registry Theatre in Kitchener.  Making an independent film is a massive financial and technical strain, especially when working with dancers, since you have to be careful of fatigue and injuries. Your help, however small, can go a long way!  You will get a stunning widescreen HD copy of the film, which is set to be released this fall.  If you are fortunate enough to have more means at your disposal, please consider an executive producer option, which will earn you a producer credit on our team.
    
One of the hardest challenges is when the work is completed and the submission to a growing number of international film festivals begins.  It can be difficult and emotionally taxing when repeatedly submitting a work like this for review, even though it is a known part of the process.  We believe strongly in this project and we'd like to share this film with as many people as possible and submit it to international film festivals.  Dave & Natasha are experienced producers and are not only prepared for these challenges; they are fully committed to seeing that this project gets as much attention as possible in the right venues.  The support of financial backers, and even social media, help makes a massive difference to the cast and crew in helping us achieve even higher goals.

Other Ways You Can Help. If you love this project and don't have money to contribute, that's okay!  We would love it if you supported us by way of twitter, instagram, Facebook and other social media shares.  Follow us @TiltedArts and post the video and photo links as we release them and help spread the word about this beautiful art form and our Company's dedication to producing quality content.
Download as many graphics as you want and post them like crazy!  Thank you so much, 
Natasha & Dave

story:
Help us at banished? productions bring our beloved performance of Into the Dollhouse on tour! First stop? The Akimbo Dance and Movement Arts Festival in Baltimore. 

Into the Dollhouse is an original devised-movement performance that explores girlhood, nostalgia and looking back in order to walk forward. Using dance, songs from yesteryear, collaged text, and a sculptural set, the performance allows the audience member to interrogate their own memories and past selves. Who did we think we would become? Are we there? Will we ever get there? 

Into the Dollhouse premiered in 2012 as part of CulturalDC's Mead Theater Lab, and then went on to Arena Stage's Inaugural Kogod Cradle Series. Last year, we re-imagined Dollhouse for an intimate rowhouse setting and filmed it (see the trailer above!). Now, we hope to bring this immersive performance experience on tour - first to the Akimbo Festival, and later to cities like Philadelphia and NYC. 


banished? productions has been producing avant-pop, interdisciplinary work in the District since 2005. We hope that this tour will not only allow us to share this special performance with a wider audience, but will also highlight Washington DC as a city of emerging, high-quality interdisciplinary work.

Into the Dollhouse was brought to life by an extraordinary team of DC artists. We're thrilled that our original team of devisers and performers will be presenting the work at Akimbo: Carmen Wong (Concept, Direction), Ronee Penoi (Touring Direction, Creative Producer), Carrie Monger (Asst Touring Director, dancer/deviser), Jennifer Rivers, and Stefanie Quinones Bass (dancer/devisers), Nicola Duval (performer), and Travis Flower (music). 

$4,000 will allow us to pay our artists for their time and travel when further developing Into the Dollhouse for its Akimbo Festival debut on September 12th. Funds raised beyond this amount will provide seed money for future tours, such as to Philadelphia in the fall of 2016. 

If you aren't able to give, we hope you'll support us by SPREADING THE WORD and attending the FREE performance of Into the Dollhouse at the Akimbo Dance and Movement Arts Festival on September 12th from 4pm-6pm.

story:
There is still a way to donate!  Click below to be taken directly to Paypal!

DONATE NOW!

Aloha and mahalo nui loa for your interest in our campaign! Our wahine competition team of Hula Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa consists of 8 spirited, motivated women from various walks of life, brought together by our love for Hawaii, the art of hula, and our determination to perfect our craft in order to preserve a thriving culture. 

What is E Hula Mau® and Why is it Important?

E Hula Mau® is Southern California’s only Hula and Chant competition. It takes place annually over Labor Day weekend (Sept 2, 3, & 4 2016) at the Terrace Theatre at the Long Beach Performing Arts Center. Various hālau will perform in multiple categories including solo and group performances in both the ancient kahiko and modern ʻauana styles of hula. It is important for our wahine to represent Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa this year so that we may honor our esteemed lineage and our fellow Nā Mamo ʻohana while perpetuating and preserving the art of hula.


Past Awards and Recognition at E Hula Mau®

E Hula Mau® 2014

  • Mākuahine Soloist - 1st Place

  • Mākuahine Group - 1st Place

  • Maiki Aiu Lake Award - Highest Points, Group Mākuahine ʻAuana

  • Kāne Kahiko - 2nd Place

  • Kāne ʻAuana - 2nd Place

E HULA MAU® 2015

  • ʻOli Soloist - 3rd Place

  • Mākuahine Group - 2nd Place


What We Need

Based on our calculations, expenses will total $20,000 for us to compete at E Hula Mau® 2016. We are hoping to raise at least three quarters of our budget, $15,000, through your generous donations (or maybe even the full amount!)


What are these funds for?

  • Transportation, performance fees, and accommodations for musicians flown in from Hawaiʻi

  • Construction and fabric costs for costumes

  • Fresh flower adornments from Hawaiʻi

  • Lodging and rehearsal space for duration of competition weekend


What you get
As added incentive we hope to provide you with some exciting perks for your donations. Whether at the Liko level or the ʻŌhiʻa Lehua level, all contributions are humbly accepted with the utmost appreciation! Perks may range from facebook shout-outs to tickets to (and other bonuses at) our upcoming Ho’ike, May 14, 2016, so you can get to know our hālau and get a sneak peek of what you might expect at E Hula Mau®. This year we have a special guest, Nā Hōkū Hanohano award winning hula musician, Mark Yamanaka who will be flying in from Hawaiʻi to perform exclusively with our school. 


Meet Our Wahine!

(Wahine Soloist & Wahine Group) Kehaulani has been dancing hula since the age of five and has loved every moment of it and considers the hālau a part of her ʻohana. Dancing with this group of amazing women under Kumu Keoki's care and guidance holds a special and sacred place in her heart. Kehau hopes to honor our kupuna, our lineage, and Kumu as we perpetuate the hula at E Hula Mau®. Mahalo to the whole hālau for their support and aloha.  We hope to make you proud!

(Wahine Group) When Kamanu first discovered the beauty of hula she had believed it was a gift reserved for the natives of the land. Sadly pushing away any dreams of learning hula, she went on to study jazz, ballet, tap, hip hop, modern dance as well as her native Chilean Cueca dances. It wasnʻt until she settled into an acting career in Los Angeles that she reconnected with an old college friend Kehaulani who was studying to be Alakaʻi at Hula Hālau Nā Mamo O Panaʻewa. It was there she learned that hula was for anyone with a passion to learn it and perpetuate the culture.  After over 20 years of dance and 2 years of papa hula, she finds herself in her second E Hula Mau® competition and just as in love with the art as she was as a child. Mahalo nui to Kumu, Kehau, her husband and ʻohana for this great gift.

(Wahine Group) Stephanie Noelani: What started out as a casual search for more technique-based instruction turned into a full immersion in, and falling in love with hula. Considering the cultural depth and gravitas that is demanded by the study of Hawaiian hula, Noe thinks of it as her favorite 4 unit class (unofficially). It is an active form of meditation for her and she has found a wonderful community led by a respected and knowledgeable Kumu. It has taught her invaluable lessons about building character, constructive attitudes, and being compassionate with others. She firmly believes hula is healing and empowering for all involved, and thanks each and every person for their support of this precious art! Mahalo nui loa! 

(Wahine Group) Newbie to hula and the Nā Mamo ʻohana, Keanu is honored and excited to represent such an elite group and to contribute in the preservation of such a beautiful tradition and culture. Keanu came to the hālau with 26+ years dance experience and directly off of a 5 year run as lead choreographer for an LA-based dance company, before discovering hula. Despite her vast experiences in the larger dance world, Keanu proudly boasts “this is the most supportive, most dedicated group of women I’ve ever worked with!" I hope I make you wahine, our Kumu, and the entire hālau proud!” #panaewastrong

(Wahine Group) Lokelani has been dancing with Nā Mamo since 2011 and loves every minute of it.  Loke has always had a place in her heart for hula.  Ever since her first trip to Oahu at age 3, she has forever been touched with the spirit of aloha.  It is with great honor to represent the lineage of Nā Mamo and to be a part of such a wonderful ʻohana. May the journey continue...Imua.

(Wahine Group) Kayla Nalani: Has been dancing hula since she was six years old, although she is fairly new to the Nā Mamo ʻohana, hula is and will forever be her passion and aspiration. There is not another group of amazing women I would want to go through this journey with. 'A 'ohe Hana Nui Ke Alu 'ia

(Wahine Group) Makana has been dancing with Na Mamo for the past 2 years.  She has wanted to be a hula dancer ever since she was a little girl.  Her mom used to watch Elvis Presley movies set in Hawaii, which started her passion. Makana is excited about being part of the competition team because " when you're a part of something bigger than yourself, it makes you better." She honestly has never been this happy until joining the hālau. She loves her hula ʻohana. They are the most kind, loving and supportive group of people she has ever known.  Makana is thrilled for this opportunity to share her aloha with all of you. 

(Wahine Group) Since the age of 12, dancing has been a important part of Lei'ohu's life. She watched her family immerse into hula, igniting her journey and passion with hawaiian culture. Dancing with Hālau Nā Mamo O Panaʻewa has been an amazing experience! This is her first competition and she is ready to dance her heart out with the support of Kumu Keoki and her haumāna. Mahalo Kumu Keoki for the time and dedication you've spent with us, my hula girls, and my family.

About Our Hālau

Located in sunny Southern California (Glendale), and established in 2010, Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa (The Cherished Offspring of Pana’ewa) and Kumu Hula (Teacher of Hula) Keoki Wang continues the traditions and legacies of his award-winning teachers including Kumu Hula Sonny Ching, Kumu Hula Noelani McIntosh and Kumu Hula Kunewa Mook through dance, songs and traditional Hawaiian chants. More information can be found at www.hhnmop.com


Risks & Challenges

Although this is not Hālau Nā Mamo O Pana’ewa’s first year competing at E Hula Mau®, we are even more ambitious, striving to do our best to represent our lineage. This will be the largest wahine line we have ever performed with, and with more people comes larger costs. In order to ensure that all 8 women are able to perform, without sacrificing the quality of costumes, adornments, musicians, or other elements, we really do need to meet our projected budget of $20,000. We would like the opportunity to concentrate solely on putting all our aloha into our hula over worrying about expenses, We have a respected lineage and reputation to uphold and we want to make everyone proud!


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand times are tough and not everyone is able to contribute financially. We appreciate your interest! Here are some other ways you can help!:


    • Share our indiegogo page to your various social media sites!

    • Spread the word any way you can!!!

    • Stay tuned for our fundraising events and contribute while getting something in return.

    • Donate an item to our ho’ike to be raffled off or bid on at our silent auction

    • Promote your business or service by placing an ad in our program for ho’ike (Must provide information by April 25, 2016 to wahinenamamo@gmail.com)

story:
Theatre Anon take you into the world of Hans Christian Andersen with their acclaimed adaptation of The Snow Queen. Join Gerda as she journeys through a strange land in search of a little lost boy, her best friend Kay. All brought to life with music, imagination and an ensemble cast. A show for all the family that will inspire the child in all of us. 

Bringing the show to Edinburgh is just the first step. With your help we can use the International platform of The Edinburgh Fringe Festival as a launch pad to take The Snow Queen on a UK tour and then global. You can be a part of it. All contributors will get their name in the program. Those who wish to give greater financial support will get all the perks, tickets to the show and a Producer credit (unless they wish to remain anonymous).


Reviews and Interviews:

"Ultimately, by the end of the evening, the show had us smiling, humming a few new tunes, and feeling just a little bit warmer inside. If producing higher quality theatre is on the agenda, The Snow Queen might just signal Theatre Anon’s own coming-of-age." Eastern Independent , December 5th, 2015. Full review at http://eastindie.net/review-theatre-anon-the-snow-queen/?from=timeline&isappinstalled=0

"It’s a story about friendship, loss, heartbreak and the extraordinary lengths that we go to for love."
http://eastindie.net/theatre-anon-the-snow-queen/

“We found Anon to share our passion for theatre and to take people on beautiful, moving and thought provoking journeys.”
http://www.thatsmags.com/shanghai/post/11662/the-snow-queen

Julien Bertrand's interview with the director and cast of The Snow Queen. http://shanghaicomedycorner.podomatic.com/entry/2015-11-24T06_03_28-08_00


Venue, The Gilded Balloon:

The Snow Queen will be at The Gilded Balloon. The Gilded Balloon was established in 1986 and is now one of the largest and well known venues at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. Balloon’s position as a premier venue is based on intriguing, imaginative, adventurous and international programming covering exciting dance and physical theatre, spine chilling plays, challenging drama, children’s shows and comedy from around the globe!

The Troupe

Arran R Hawkins - Director/Producer/Actor

Arran is an actor/director/artist from Cornwall in the UK. He has been heavily involved in the Shanghai theatre scene since 2009. His first collaboration with Artistic Director Natasha Portwood & Musical Director OJ Ryan was on 2010’s The Snow Queen. He helped set up Theatre Anon in 2013, co-producing and acting in Harold Pinter’s Betrayal and has spent the last few summers touring with Play The Spotlight Theatre’s acclaimed one-woman show Black Is The Color Of My Voice, which he directed, in Shanghai, New York, and at the Edinburgh Fringe. Most recently he adapted L. Frank Baum’s classic The Wizard Of Oz for the stage. OZ was the 2nd Theatre Anon show and collaboration with Natasha Portwood & OJ Ryan, and played to full houses in April 2015. 

Natasha Portwood - Producer/Actress

It was during the Nativity Years that Natasha Portwood fell in love with all things theatrical and has indulged her passion ever since. Throughout her 9 years in Shanghai, she has worked with EWT, SRT and Urban Aphrodite. In 2013 she helped launch Theatre Anon, playing Emma in Betrayal, followed by The Witches, Good and Wicked, in their adaptation of Oz. Since childhood, Natasha has delighted in the stories of Hans Christian Andersen and studied The Snow Queen for her BA Honours degree in Illustration - breathing life into this magical adventure on stage for a second time is the realisation of a dream.

OJ Ryan - Actor

OJ Ryan studied Musical Theatre at the Australian Institute of Music with scholarship honours. He has performed in the dramatic and musical spheres in both Shanghai and Dubai over the past 8 years. This is his third time as Musical Director collaborating with Arran R Hawkins andNatasha Portwood, the first being The Snow Queen in 2010 and most recently in OZ where he also appeared as the Cowardly Lion.

Violet Mount - Actress

The Snow Queen, marks Violet Mount's (of Toronto), third stage production of 2015, that has included playing a drunken disheveled bridesmaid in 5 Women Wearing the Same Dress and a Mandarin speaking Jewish refugee in Shalom Shanghai / 苏州河北.  On the small screen check her out as Marissa in the web series, Floating City. 

Laurie Padgett Frolic - Actress

Laurie Padgett Fralick holds a BA in Theater and Music. She can be found singing in Chinese on stages across Shanghai. Past Shanghai productions include Much Ado About Nothing (Beatrice), Twelfth Night (Feste), Snow Queen (SRT 2010), The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe (Assistant Director), Christmas Carol, and Drift at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. 

Richard Bochniak - Actor

A San Diego born clown and physical comedian whose Shanghai acting resume includes Much Ado About Nothing and OZ. He is director and mainstage performer of the Zmack Comedy Improv troupe and works for an educational based company: Early Birds, developing and facilitating Creative Drama programs for local school campuses here in Shanghai. He spends his free time searching for those ‘banana peels’ to slip on in life.

Expenses

Expenses to get there and stay include:

  • Edinburgh Fringe Registration Fee £300 GBP
  • Fights for 7 cast and crew £8000 GBP
  • Accommodations £10,000 GBP
  • Venue Fees £6000 GBP
  • Cast Stipen £3000 GBP
  • Advertising £1000 GBP
  • Marketing £1700 GBP

Risks & Challenges

Getting this ragtag group of international thespians to the Edinburgh Fringe 2016 from Shanghai and putting them up for a month in Edinburgh is the biggest challenge financially.

Changing and adapting the format of the show to make it work at the Edinburgh Fringe has also had its challenges, such as condensing the show without losing any of its impressiveness, using the stage in an original way without the physical boundaries of a backstage area,  transforming from character to character with flawless costume changes before the audiences eyes, incorporating original songs and music to narrate the story, all add to helping our audience believe in make-believe. 

The original show was set and cast heavy. Director Arran Hawkins has reduced the cast to an ensemble of 6 actors (+ one technician), and minimalized the set to make it tourable.
