Andersen with their acclaimed adaptation of The Snow Queen. Join Gerda as she journeys
through a strange land in search of a little lost boy, her best friend Kay. All
brought to life with music, imagination and an ensemble cast. A show for all
the family that will inspire the child in all of us. 
Bringing the show to Edinburgh is just the first step. With your help we can use the International platform of The Edinburgh Fringe Festival as a launch pad to take The Snow Queen on a UK tour and then global. You can be a part of it. All contributors will get their name in the program. Those who wish to give greater financial support will get all the perks, tickets to the show and a Producer credit (unless they wish to remain anonymous).







Reviews and Interviews:
"Ultimately, by the end of the evening, the show had us smiling, humming a few new tunes, and feeling just a little bit warmer inside. If producing higher quality theatre is on the agenda, The Snow Queen might just signal Theatre Anon’s own coming-of-age." Eastern Independent , December 5th, 2015. Full review at http://eastindie.net/review-theatre-anon-the-snow-queen/?from=timeline&isappinstalled=0
"It’s a story about friendship, loss, heartbreak and the extraordinary lengths that we go to for love."
http://eastindie.net/theatre-anon-the-snow-queen/
“We found Anon to share our passion for theatre and to take people on beautiful, moving and thought provoking journeys.”

http://www.thatsmags.com/shanghai/post/11662/the-snow-queen

Julien Bertrand's interview with the director and cast of The Snow Queen. http://shanghaicomedycorner.podomatic.com/entry/2015-11-24T06_03_28-08_00




Venue, The Gilded Balloon:The Snow Queen will be at The Gilded Balloon. The Gilded Balloon was established in 1986 and is now one of the largest and well known venues at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. Balloon’s position as a premier venue is based on intriguing, imaginative, adventurous and international programming covering exciting dance and physical theatre, spine chilling plays, challenging drama, children’s shows and comedy from around the globe!

The Troupe




Arran R Hawkins - Director/Producer/Actor
Arran is
an actor/director/artist from Cornwall in the UK. He has been heavily involved
in the Shanghai theatre scene since 2009. His first collaboration with Artistic
Director Natasha Portwood & Musical Director OJ Ryan was on 2010’s The Snow
Queen. He helped set up Theatre Anon in 2013, co-producing and acting in Harold
Pinter’s Betrayal and has spent the last few summers touring with Play The
Spotlight Theatre’s acclaimed one-woman show Black Is The Color Of My Voice,
which he directed, in Shanghai, New York, and at the Edinburgh Fringe. Most recently
he adapted L. Frank Baum’s classic The Wizard Of Oz for the stage. OZ was the 2nd
Theatre Anon show and collaboration with Natasha Portwood & OJ Ryan, and
played to full houses in April 2015. 



Natasha Portwood - Producer/Actress
It was
during the Nativity Years that Natasha Portwood fell in love with all things
theatrical and has indulged her passion ever since. Throughout her 9 years
in Shanghai, she has worked with EWT, SRT and Urban Aphrodite. In 2013 she
helped launch Theatre Anon, playing Emma in Betrayal, followed by The Witches,
Good and Wicked, in their adaptation of Oz. Since childhood, Natasha has
delighted in the stories of Hans Christian Andersen and studied The Snow Queen
for her BA Honours degree in Illustration - breathing life into this magical
adventure on stage for a second time is the realisation of a dream.


OJ Ryan - Actor
OJ Ryan studied Musical Theatre at the Australian Institute of
Music with scholarship honours. He has performed in the dramatic and musical
spheres in both Shanghai and Dubai over the past 8 years. This is his third
time as Musical Director collaborating with Arran R Hawkins andNatasha Portwood, the first being The Snow Queen
in 2010 and most recently in OZ where he also appeared as the Cowardly Lion.



Violet Mount - Actress
The Snow Queen, marks Violet Mount's (of Toronto), third stage production of
2015, that has included playing a drunken disheveled bridesmaid in 5 Women Wearing the Same Dress and
a Mandarin speaking Jewish refugee in Shalom
Shanghai / 苏州河北.  On the small screen check her out as Marissa in the
web series, Floating
City. 


Laurie Padgett Frolic - Actress
Laurie Padgett
Fralick holds a BA in Theater and Music. She can be found singing in
Chinese on stages across Shanghai. Past Shanghai productions
include Much Ado About Nothing (Beatrice), Twelfth Night (Feste), Snow Queen (SRT 2010), The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe (Assistant
Director), Christmas Carol, and Drift at the Edinburgh Festival
Fringe. 

Richard
Bochniak - Actor
A San Diego born clown and physical comedian whose Shanghai acting
resume includes Much Ado About Nothing and OZ. He is director and mainstage
performer of the Zmack Comedy Improv troupe and works for an educational based
company: Early Birds, developing and facilitating Creative Drama programs for
local school campuses here in Shanghai. He spends his free time searching for
those ‘banana peels’ to slip on in life.





Expenses
Expenses to get there and stay include:


Edinburgh Fringe Registration Fee £300 GBP


Fights for 7 cast and crew £8000 GBP

Accommodations £10,000 GBP
Venue Fees £6000 GBP
Cast Stipen £3000 GBP
Advertising £1000 GBP
Marketing £1700 GBP



    

Risks & Challenges Getting this ragtag group of international thespians to the Edinburgh Fringe 2016 from Shanghai and putting them up for a month in Edinburgh is the biggest challenge financially.
Changing and adapting the format of the show to make it work at the Edinburgh Fringe has also had its challenges, such as condensing the show without losing any of its impressiveness, using the stage in an original way without the physical boundaries of a backstage area,  transforming from character to character with flawless costume changes before the audiences eyes, incorporating original songs and music to narrate the story, all add to helping our audience believe in make-believe. 
The original show was set and cast heavy. Director Arran Hawkins has reduced the cast to an ensemble of 6 actors (+ one technician), and minimalized the set to make it tourable.

story:
Pits: The Unauthorized Holes Musical

The Yelnats family has been having a string of bad luck. Well, that’s putting it mildly. They’ve been cursed since Elya Yelnats forgot to carry Madame Zeroni up that dang mountain. Elya didn’t realize that someday his mistake would send his great-great-grandson Stanley to a youth correctional facility in the middle of a seemingly endless desert. Now, an innocent Stanley has to dig holes for eighteen months - all the while dealing with antagonistic juvenile delinquents, a devilish warden, and a mysterious search for a lost treasure. And don’t forget the yellow-spotted lizards!  What a riot!

PITS: The Unauthorized Holes Musical is an original show that pays hilarious tribute to Louis Sachar’s brilliant story while simultaneously celebrating the weirdness, passion, imagination, and innovation of our creative team. We’ve assembled an amazing cast of triple-threat superstars to create the musical we’ve all dreamt of since middle school. On April 15, the show will finally come to life - and we hope you’ll be there to see it.

CHECK OUT ALL OUR SHOW DATES BELOW!

Friday April 15th - 8:00PM

Saturday April 16th - 2:00PM & 8:00PM

Sunday April 17th - 2:00PM & 8:00PM

Our location will be announced soon! Keep your eyes and ears open!


Where the Money is Going

You might be thinking, “That budget sounds wild. How long have you been stranded in the desert, deliriously eating sploosh?” But we thought it out, I swear. Our primary expense is theater space; our goal is to put the show on in a professional theater. You might be thinking “Just put it on at NYU! You go to school there, right?” RIGHT! But NYU only gives performance space to theater clubs. Even then, the spaces available are not fit for musical theater. Unfortunately, we are not a registered theater club and have no way of getting to that point without waiting out a very long process. The most inexpensive space available  for our performance schedule costs about $3,000.

In addition to that, we have to pay for costumes, props, set design, lighting, and sound equipment, all of which puts us back another $2,000. Thus, we arrive at our budget of $5,000.

Admission to the show will be totally FREE! I said it, FREE! But by donating, you can land yourself a guaranteed reserved ticket to the performance of your choice!

If we don’t reach our intended goal, our funding will go entirely to performance space.


The Impact

I first saw Holes in movie theaters when I was eight. It immediately became my favorite movie. My obsession didn’t falter through middle school, and in high school it was something my friends wouldn’t let me live down.  So when junior year rolled around, no one surprised when I waltzed into school on Halloween dressed as Stanley Yelnats, blasting the movie’s theme song from speakers in my backpack.

                     

When I got to college, as a film major, my late nights were filled with cliché philosophical conversations and the occasional snooty film question of “What’s your favorite movie?” I avoided the classic answers like The Shining and the blatant lie of Citizen Kane. Instead I embarrassingly blurted out, “Holes!” before thinking of a lie that would have given me more credit.

I wrote the first song of the show my junior year of high school. Not long after, my writing lost steam and the song was left alone for four more years.  But on one magical day last year I nostalgically remembered my experience in high school musical theater and sat down at the piano to finish what I started.

I ended up with a show that pays tribute to one of my favorite stories of all time, while also poking a good deal of fun at it. It's a show that can make any millennial feel nostalgia for their days of Tamagotchis and  middle school crushes. We hope to make you fall in love with Holes all over again.

- Noah Rauchwerk, Writer/Director


Risks & Challenges

Preparing and performing a full-blown musical production is no easy task. Although we've started with a great story and wonderful characters, there are literally MILLIONS of hurdles we have to jump.

From creating an original score, to choreographing complex dance numbers, to working out budgets and creating an interesting set with authentic props, the process of creating a show of this magnitude is rife with difficulties.

Over the course of the next month, the amazing cast and crew of Pits is going to be toiling tirelessly away to bring to life a truly unique and delightful musical. The challenges along the way will (hopefully) only make the final product that much better!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't chip in here because you've blown all your cash on trying to find a cure for smelly feet, there are still so many ways you can help!

First and foremost, come check out the show! It's going to be a blast, and we know you'll love it. Also, if you want to help spread the word, tell some friends about the project. You never know how quickly news can spread!


Finally, if you really want to help out, you can get involved artistically in your own community. This is a story about friendship, camaraderie, and overcoming the roles that society has thrust upon you. Music and theater have an incredible power to make the world a better place, so do your best to spread it around!

_______________________________________________________
“When you spend your whole life living in a hole,” he said, “the only way you can go is up.” 
- Louis Sacher, Holes

story:
Your donation to Onstage Repertory Theatre Company may be a tax deductible charitable contribution. Onstage is a 501c3 Non-Profit Corporation.

The Play…

After her release from a shell on the ocean floor, Esperanza is delivered to a Spanish galleon brimming with pirate potential.  But before she has a chance to meet her pirate lover, Esperanza awakens to find she is really Maggie Parsons, a 21st century travel writer engaged to a man she doesn’t love. Anxious to re-enter her dream, Maggie borrows characters she meets in a romance writing class, particularly reluctant instructor Jim, and recasts them in Esperanza’s pirate romance.  Esperanza!  Spanish for “hope,” is a must-see for anyone who ever dreamed of living the lives we were meant to lead, not the ones we sometimes settle for. 

The Players…

The writing team of Gretchen Givens and Linda Gregg collaborated on their new musical, Esperanza!, because of a shared belief that the world can always use uplifting music, especially when it is sung and danced by swashbuckling heroes and pirates.  The writers also feel that the theatre-going public could use a romantic getaway back to the 17th century Spanish Main.  Help support our labour of pirate love by contributing to Helen Means’ OnStage Theatre production of Esperanza! opening at the Martinez Campbell Theater May 20th thru June 5th, 2016. Givens/Gregg also collaborated on a musical stage adaptation of “The Ballad of Cat Ballou,” and are the authors of “Canyon Road,” "We Don't Know Jack"and “Leaving Limbo.”

The Promise…

If you can help us become the best musical we can be, the Esperanza! Production team will reward your patronage with at least two hours of heart-touching romance and sexy swashbuckling musical escapism.  Join us in realizing Esperanza’s dream by contributing to the exciting World Premiere of Esperanza!...A Pirate Romance.  We deeply appreciate your kindness and generosity.  Ahoy!

story:
Elemeno Pea, by Molly Smith Metzler, is the first production for the new Misfits Theater Company, featuring artists from New York, Boulder, Denver and Chicago. 

The Misfits Theater Company was created as an inclusive, alternative to more traditional theater: combining artists from all over the United States, we are creating work for all those who have ever felt on the fringe, misunderstood, or like their light just shines a little too bright.  Our mission is to include all those who have sought a community filled with strength and beauty, and a for those who possess a creative drive that fills their souls.  The Misfits' mission is to create bold, edgy work reflective of our community.

Elemeno Pea (our premiere play) is a beautiful piece first produced at the Actors Theatre of Louisville for the 2011 Humana Festival, and written by the incomparable Molly Smith Metzler.  It has been produced all over the United States.  The Colorado premiere of Elemeno Pea (directed by the fabulous Thadd Krueger) is playing mid May through early June at the Voodoo Comedy Club in Denver, CO.

Coming from New York, and being new to the Denver and Boulder Theater scene, this theatre company is a way to combine different types of artists (of all ages, nationalities and backgrounds) to collaborate and bring their various experiences and passions to the table.  Unfortunately, bringing artists from the East and Central coasts to Colorado makes it tougher to get grants and funding for this new theatre company.  Please help us get the word out and help us fund this dream so that we can create great work to share with this wonderful community!

story:
The Story

Three seemingly disconnected characters search for a sense of community in London's rapidly disappearing gay scene. Ian refuses to leave his flat and is greeted with a new office worker typing millimetres away from his bedroom window. Louie sleeps on the circle line all day in-between finding work as a male prostitute. Sue is struggling to delete Sid and has instigated a war with the builders outside her front window. The gay community has vanished, but what happens when all three characters are thrown out of their comfort zones and forced to find solace in one another. 

'A Boy Named Sue' examines the need for a sense of community in an oppressively hetero-normative world. It looks at how humans can form friendships in the most unlikely of places and love one another despite all the odds. It's a story about loneliness and being who you were meant to be. 

Why this show would suit The Edinburgh Fringe

It’s current. It’s about contemporary issues that are affecting people right now. With 25% of London LGBT venues having shut since 2009 the play attempts to foresee what could happen if London's gay scene disappears at the current rate.

The play not only examines this crisis in relation to the increase in London property prices but also the rise of gay social media. Since London was the most popular city in the world for Grindr in 2013 (with 947, 000 users) we feel the play is not just current but urgently needs to be told.

With two characters in their teens and one in his late 50s the play depicts the changing faces of London’s gay scene and how ‘normal’ means of communication have been replaced with instant messaging, photos and unsolicited offers of sex. The age difference between the characters also seeks to capture the contrast between old and new attitudes towards HIV and the play foregrounds this within the current refugee crisis, considering how migrants could so easily be denied HIV treatment given Nigel Farage’s comments in the build up to the 2015 election.

However the play also tells a very personal story. It is a story about society’s outsiders, their battles with loneliness and their search for belonging in a world that does not want to necessarily accommodate them.

We want to create a piece of theatre that is as educational as it is engaging. Tracing one character's transition from male to female, the play is heavily grounded in LGBT activism and based on research undertaken as part of a new writing programme at the Bristol Old Vic. Our writer was lucky enough to interview young people living with HIV and meet the founder of the Terrence Higgins Trust, Sir Nick Partridge. We feel this research anchors the play in current issues that will not only be educational but also thought provoking.

Told in three-part monologue the play creates an abstract, dystopic world in which current social concerns are displayed in heightened form. We feel that this show would therefore be perfect for The Fringe since it is not only a new story, but a new story that is told in a new way. 

As an organisation that was set up due to the exclusion of those not included in the 1947 International Festival, The Fringe appeals to us as the perfect place to perform this play. It is a festival that tells untold stories, that represents the under-represented, and we feel the characters in this play fulfil that category.

story:
Short Summary

In 2012, Oh Dragon Theatre Company set out to make its mark on theatre in Austin, Texas. From humble beginnings to swings and misses to shining accomplishments, we have shared it all with our audiences with the same passion and drive that has inspired us from day one. 

Over three years, nine plays, and over fifty performances later, we are about to embark on our most important season yet. This season will feature Oh Dragon's first foray into musical theatre, Jason Robert Brown's "Songs For A New World," opening this September. 2016 will also see our production of Christopher Durang's "Durang/Durang." A hilarious, satirical look at the American Theatre. 

DURANG/DURANG - April 7th-24th, 2016 @ City Theatre

SONGS FOR A NEW WORLD - September 1st-17th, 2016 @ Trinity Street Theatre

What We Need & What You Get

Producing theatre in Austin can be tricky. With escalating rental prices and performance venues closing, it can be difficult to fully realize a production without emptying your bank account. We are asking for a $5,500 investment to fund our season. That investment will go to cover the cost of:

Don't think you're going home empty handed! We have a smorgasbord of "Backer Only" perks. Everything from a custom season graphic to a private in-home concert provided by the cast of Songs For A New World! Check out all options listed on this page.

The Impact

Though Durang/Durang and Songs For A New World are excellent shows, they are seldom done in our area. Our season would open audiences to different, engaging theatre that has inspired the theatrical world for decades. Brown and Durang have experienced popularity in Austin with productions of their shows "The Last Five Years," and "Vanya and Sonya and Masha and Spike," done by other theatre companies in the last year.

With our season, we hope to reach a wide group of people from Austin's diverse culture. We also aim to reach out to our community in the form of free performances and workshops. All of this is possible with the support of theatre lovers and the Austin community. 

Risks & Challenges

Finding theatre venues and reliable people is always the biggest hurdle, however, we are extremely thankful to be working with two established theatres in Austin. We also have a dedicated bunch of creative people just bursting with ideas on how to bring these shows to life onstage and how to solve problems when they arise. Now we just need YOU to complete our team!

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't get involved! Spread the word! Please use the tools below to link others to our Twitter and Facebook. With your involvement, we can keep creating and performing through 2016. 

THANK YOU!
story_txt:
Short Summary In 2012, Oh Dragon Theatre Company set out to make its mark on theatre in Austin, Texas. From humble beginnings to swings and misses to shining accomplishments, we have shared it all with our audiences with the same passion and drive that has inspired us from day one. 
Over three years, nine plays, and over fifty performances later, we are about to embark on our most important season yet. This season will feature Oh Dragon's first foray into musical theatre, Jason Robert Brown's "Songs For A New World," opening this September. 2016 will also see our production of Christopher Durang's "Durang/Durang." A hilarious, satirical look at the American Theatre. 
DURANG/DURANG - April 7th-24th, 2016 @ City Theatre
SONGS FOR A NEW WORLD - September 1st-17th, 2016 @ Trinity Street Theatre
What We Need & What You Get
 Producing theatre in Austin can be tricky. With escalating rental prices and performance venues closing, it can be difficult to fully realize a production without emptying your bank account. We are asking for a $5,500 investment to fund our season. That investment will go to cover the cost of:



Don't think you're going home empty handed! We have a smorgasbord of "Backer Only" perks. Everything from a custom season graphic to a private in-home concert provided by the cast of Songs For A New World! Check out all options listed on this page.


The Impact
 Though Durang/Durang and Songs For A New World are excellent shows, they are seldom done in our area. Our season would open audiences to different, engaging theatre that has inspired the theatrical world for decades. Brown and Durang have experienced popularity in Austin with productions of their shows "The Last Five Years," and "Vanya and Sonya and Masha and Spike," done by other theatre companies in the last year.
With our season, we hope to reach a wide group of people from Austin's diverse culture. We also aim to reach out to our community in the form of free performances and workshops. All of this is possible with the support of theatre lovers and the Austin community. 
Risks & Challenges
 Finding theatre venues and reliable people is always the biggest hurdle, however, we are extremely thankful to be working with two established theatres in Austin. We also have a dedicated bunch of creative people just bursting with ideas on how to bring these shows to life onstage and how to solve problems when they arise. Now we just need YOU to complete our team!   Other Ways You Can Help
Sometimes you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't get involved! Spread the word! Please use the tools below to link others to our Twitter and Facebook. With your involvement, we can keep creating and performing through 2016. 
THANK YOU!

story:
Help Shakespeare Return to Western New York

Shake on the Lake is in its fifth season bringing affordable theatre to rural places throughout Western New York. We know Shakespeare has fans - he is, overall, much more popular than even One Direction! 

Courtney Bennett as Ariel and Chad Bradford as Prospero at Silver Lake, New York (Wyoming County) Picture: JMS Studio & Gallery, Perry, New York

Who is Shake on the Lake? 

  • Professional Shakespeare Outdoor Festival and company based on Silver Lake, New York
  • Founded by Josh Rice, a theatre artist born, raised, and practicing are on Wyoming County's Silver Lake
  • Produced four seasons of live theatre: The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged), The Comedy of Errors, A Midsummer Nights Dream, and The Tempest
  • Host a cast and artists from Little Rock, Chicago, New York City, Nashville, Jacksonville, and Perry
  • Donations from people like YOU! help us bring Shakespeare's Twelfth Night to Western New York this summer!
What is Shake on the Lake planning for 2016?
Twelve Shows of Twelfth Night! That's right, we are producing the fantastic fête of Twelfth Night a dozen times in Western New York. With your support, we can share this magical party throughout the region.

Help bring Shake on the Lake back to our rural venues by contributing to this campaign!

Shake on the Lake visits Arcade, New York (Wyoming County)

What We Need & What You Get

What do we need with this holiday fundraiser?

  • We need at least $2,000 to fund our traveling show: production costs, travel costs, sound system, marketing, and staffing!
  • Shake on the Lake pays its theatre artists. We not only believe that art contributes to the quality life of our festival towns, but also believe artists should be paid for their craft. 
  • Shake on the Lake is launching educational programming and needs support with programming costs and artists fees to develop curriculum and our first ever student actor "Green Shows" that will premiere before some of our Twelfth Night shows.
  • No matter if we meet or exceed this goal, the funding will go towards festival expenses. 

We travel to perform rain, shine, and extreme heat! The Tempest at Mt. Morris, New York (Livingston County)

The Impact

Your contribution will impact:

  • Our local residents: some seeing Shakespeare on stage for the first time in their communities
  • Our communities: Shake on the Lake draws audiences from the immediate community as well as regional and national audiences making towns a theatre destination while we are in town increasing traffic to local businesses and visits to the wonderful communities and venues we perform in
  • Our company: we host several actors from throughout the country who temporarily call Silver Lake and Western New York their home. 

Challenges & Opportunities

Chad Bradford as Prospero. Letchworth State Park (Wyoming/Livingston Counties, New York) Picture: CB Goodman

We rely on your donations to fund Shake on the Lake. Other funding sources include: government and foundation grants, individual donations, corporate sponsorship, and organizational partnerships. Our crowdsourcing campaigns help us grow and produce the quality of theatre that our audiences expect from Shake on the Lake. 

We have numerous opportunities when we have a successful crowdsourcing campaign. We are excited to explore:

  • Educational programming with K-12 students including our Groundlings Theatre Company
  • Theatre Artist Lectures that delve into the scholarship of our cast helping to enrich our local communities with their knowledge
  • Increase partnerships with local visual artists to showcase their works at our venues
  • Alternative theatre arts programming to even more communities in our region including musical shows with our house band The Mooncalves

Chad Bradford and Matt Duncan host "Tempest Talk" about Music and Language in Shakespearean Plays. Silver Lake Institute (Wyoming County). We'd love to increase programming like this that help put our productions in context of Shakespearean studies in theatre and language. 

We hosted metalwork artist Ryan McDanel from Perry, New York (Wyoming County) at our Silver Lake performances. We would like to increase the opportunities for visual artists to collaborate with us. Title: Marengo

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about this campaign! Other ways to help:
  • Visit our shows! More information on showtimes will be available in the Spring at www.ShakeontheLake.org

Thank you so much for your interest and support of Shake on the Lake.

story:
My name is Chad Brady, I’m 19 years old, and I was born and raised in Massachusetts. I have been dancing mainly hip hop but training in other styles also for 10 years. This campaign is extremely important to me because I want to move to Los Angeles to follow my dreams. The main reason I want to move more then ever is to make my brother proud and the rest of my family. My brother was always proud of me, but I want to be able to accomplish all of the things I always told him I would do. I’d also like a platform to explain the situation of my brother. His life was taken on New Years Day 2015 and ever since then, I've pushed harder then ever to just get myself out there. I really think living out there will give me a fresh start and allow me to do everything I've always wanted to since life is so short. I just want to be positive and do the right thing. There has been so many obstacles setting me back financially. My car (his old car) has been having a lot of issues which I had to take money out of my savings to keep it going. I left one of my jobs after it happened because my boss was NOT understanding through my grieving process and have yet got into a good company that's understanding with the situation till just recently. I have been having a tough time managing to save enough money to move cross country to follow my dreams not that I'm bad with money because I save everything I can and don't go out much because it's more important to me to focus on my career.  Basically, you would be investing into my future. I’m just looking for a chance. I genuinely believe I can take it from there. Thank you and I appreciate your consideration.




What We Need & What You Get

I need $10,000 because soon as I get there I'm going to need first and last rent which will be around 3 grand then I will need to pay for a plane ticket and for some of my stuff to get shipped out there so I have clothes. Then I'll need transportation which will cost me around2,000 wether I ship my car or buy a new car or nike.After all expenses I'll probably have a few thousand which is gonna be my emergency money if my hours are short and I'm gonna be short on rent or I didn't make enough money to by food for the week because at first it's gonna be tough no easy so even working hard I'm sure I'm going to experience struggling. If I don't reach my goal they will be saved until I can come up with the remaining.

  • The Impact

I feel like I can impact the dance community in a very positive way through my life experiences and can bring emotions and stories to the table that others can't. Last year I raised money for my brothers funeral and this time I wanna raise it for a new start for me. It would mean the world and I feel like it would help to get away from everything where I live.

Risks & Challenges

I know its gonna be hard and there will be a lot of obstacles but the thing about me is I never give up I got to much to fight for to give up. I will work through every challenge and make my brother proud.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand not anyone can donate money but one of the other things that is huge in making me reach my goal is spreading the word and that to me would mean a lot also. Use indiegogos share tool!

story:
Hi, my name is Taylor Dawson and I am 15 years old. I am a ballet dancer and company member at North Central Ballet in Texas.  I auditioned and was accepted into several Summer Intensives and have decided to attend Orlando Ballet. It's a great fit and an amazing 5 week program but very expensive. At the coaxing of family members, I have decided to ask for help from friends, family, and lovers of the arts. 

     I am babysitting every chance I get to raise funds but with a challenging advanced placement course load at school and 15-25 hours of dance a week, my availability is very limited. My donation goal is only a portion of the total costs because I really am trying to earn as much of my way as possible on my own. 
   
       Attending a summer intensive will improve my strength and confidence as a dancer, challenge me to reach my full potential as a ballerina, and allow me to meet, learn from, and be inspired by world renowned dancers and instructors of the ballet world. It's also an awesome experience and opportunity to be away from home and gain independence and life-long memories. 
     Donations will go towards tuition, room, and board. I would also like everyone to know any money donated above my goal will help me to afford the extras required ( pointe shoes, dance wear, transportation, food, etc;)  Thank you for all of your help and encouragement! No amount is too small!

story:
Once upon a time, a band of weirdos found each other in the muck and tumble of San Francisco.  They built themselves a cardboard palace called Circus Automatic.  In this palace, they created terrible things, beautiful things, things that had never before seen the light of day.  Stories too real to be true, and feats too rare to exist.  Circus Automatic is stirring with a new creation for the Great Star Theater that challenges you to delve further into the labyrinth of the Raised by Wolves series.

If you’re local to the Bay Area, perhaps you have joined us for some of our previous creations.  

For our newest show we are pulling out some big ideas that have been years in the planning; this is definitely our most ambitious project to date, and we need you and your kind support to help us bring it to life!

Into the Mouth of the Wolf debuts October 13th at the Great Star Theater, in the heart of the China town district of San Francisco.  Production is well under way, and we have 30 days to raise enough funds to bring our giant to life before our preview date of August the 20th.

What we need to pay for:

Our fundraising goal is $7,800....WHOA!  These funds are needed for the following production costs:

  • No biggie we just plan to envelop the Great Star Theater in a giant starscape, that's all. (you'll see)
  • Giant trees that create creepy shadows on stage
  • Materials and construction costs for inspiring costumes
  • Printing and promotion to get the word out
  • Rigging costs to fly people in the air

Why you should support this production:

Supporting Circus Automatic means:

  • You’re a brave human. Circus Automatic is not for the faint of heart and it is not just entertainment.  We create art that invokes conversation around important issues and support real causes in the world.

The Impact

  • You will give hope to some of the last remaining artists in San Francisco.

Risks & Challenges

  • THIS IS A BIG THING - there are a lot of moving parts to this production and resources are always thin- our people and supplies juggle multiple responsibilities to pull off our shows. Each production is a labor of love that manages to assert itself every time.  Staging a full length production in the United States is no small feat, and we want to continue pushing the boundaries of our art forms, not simply produce something that will pass.  We need your help to make this one the best ever!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re in the SF Bay Area we also need materials donations!

  • Do you have any extra computer monitors? Raspberry PIs? Lumber? Computer power sources? LED's?
  • Share the love-- if you'd like to help and funds aren't your forte, sharing our campaign with even one other person you think would be interested is a huge help!

story: Our campaign to raise money for this exciting original piece of immersive theatre is now over, but plans for the production are still going strong. If you missed our Indiegogo campaign and still want to contribute to our ongoing fundraising, we do have a Paypal account at paypal.me/oxproject

If you missed our Indiegogo campaign and still want to contribute to our ongoing fundraising, we do have a Paypal account at paypal.me/oxproject

story:
Department of what? Fools!

We are the Department of Fools!!!!  We are a new Commedia dell’Arte troupe presenting an original production titled A HISTORY OF SERVITUDE as part of the 20th Annual New York International Fringe Festival this August!

We are very excited to announce that all of our performances at the Fringe are absolutely FREE to the public!!!  While we are thrilled to offer free comedy to NYC audiences this summer, we still have costs to cover.  Not a single artist is being paid for this project, nor will audiences have to pay to see it.  This is a labor of love in the purest sense.  Please help us in providing free hilarity this summer?

A bit more about us:  The Department of Fools is internationally diverse, with performers from India, Brazil, Denmark, Israel, Morocco, Norway and the United States.  We all share a passion for satire, social justice, and the unique hilarity of mask work. 

Starting in January of this year, we spent several weeks of workshopping through improvisation, physical exercises, mask work and learning the history of Commedia dell'Arte.  Since then, we have developed a few original shows and started to share them with the public. After two very successful productions at the NYU Gallatin Arts Festival and at the prestigious Lee Strasberg Film & Theatre Institute we are bringing A HISTORY OF SERVITUDE to the NY International Fringe Festival this summer!

A History of Servitude is a comic survey of world history, from the dawn of man to the present.  The play examines and celebrates the eternal struggle of the underdog.  History remembers men (and to a much lesser extent women, which we point out as well) of greatness, who through conquest, innovation and accomplishment have left an indelible mark on the story of man.  But what about the servants of these giants?  Using the boldly physical slapstick comedy of Commedia dell’Arte, we bring attention to the contributions of the working class throughout history, which all too often goes unnoticed.  What if Einstein’s maid is actually responsible for inspiring the General Theory of Relativity?  What if Shakespeare got most of his ideas from the janitor at the Globe?  Slaves built the pyramids, but it’s the pharaohs whose names live on.  A History of Servitude posits a comic reminder that ‘the little people’ are the ones on whose back much of history rests, despite the fact that the masters get all the credit.


What We Need & What You Get

We need your help in providing free comedy to NYC audience this summer! So what will your hard earned money be used for? We are looking to raise $3500 for:

  • A Press Rep and Public Relations ($2000)

  • Costumes and Props ($750)

  • Marketing ($500)

AND if we exceed our goal, maybe we can buy a meal for our hungry actors (who are all working for free)!!! #artistlife

Literally every dollar you give (and yes, even one dollar helps) make a huge difference!


The Impact

Your donations will help us to costume our actors, get the show reviewed by major press outlets, and help spread the word about our very special show. But most importantly, you will be supporting free theatre for NYC audiences.  While our great city offers some of the finest theatrical performances in the world, few people can afford the exorbitant ticket prices.  Providing free theatre is part of our commitment to serving our community regardless of commercial concerns.  You can help us achieve that!

From the very inception of our company, all of our productions have been free to audiences.  Audiences have roared with laughter and loved our shows.  We want to continue to bring quality comedy to audiences for free, but we can't do it without your help.


Risks & Challenges

The Department of Fools is a company of a dozen gifted and highly trained actors, who have worked on TV shows like QUANTICO and have appeared on stages around the world.  However, all of the Fools work for free on our shows because they love the work and want to bring the work to audiences without having to charge an arm and a leg.  In order to do that, we rely on the generosity of like-minded individuals who love comedy, mask work and just being silly! 

If we don't meet our goal, we will survive.  We are a scrappy and resourceful bunch.  We will find a way to get the basics needed to bring a fine show to Fringe audiences this August.  However, literally every dollar you donate will help to improve the production values of the show, but even more importantly your donations will help us spread the word about our show to audiences and press alike.  We want to let people know about what we are doing, and continue to do it for free.  Please help us make that possible?

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you might not be able to contribute, and that's really ok.  Times are tough for many, and as actors in NYC we know how precious every dollar can be.  But even if you can't give, you can still help us!  Please consider doing one or more of the following:

  • Help make some noise about our campaign.  Link to it on your Facebook or Twitter accounts!
  • Help us get the word out about the show!  Again, post on your Facebook or Twitter about this fun and free production happening this summer:  http://fringenyc.org/special-events/fringeal-fresco/
  • Encourage people to check out our website: https://departmentoffools.wordpress.com/

Nuff' said. If you don't laugh, we'll give you a full refund!! Guaranteed!!!!

The play examines and celebrates the eternal struggle of the
underdog.  History remembers men (and to
a much lesser extent women, which we point out as well) of greatness, who
through conquest, innovation and accomplishment have left an indelible mark on
the story of man.  But what about the
servants of these giants?  Using the
boldly physical slapstick comedy of Commedia dell’Arte, we bring attention to
the contributions of the working class throughout history, which all too often goes
unnoticed.  What if Einstein’s maid is
actually responsible for inspiring the General Theory of Relativity?  What if Shakespeare got most of his ideas
from the janitor at the Globe?  Slaves
built the pyramids, but it’s the pharaohs whose names live on.  A
History of Servitude posits a comic reminder that ‘the little people’ are
the ones on whose back much of history rests, despite the fact that the masters
get all the credit.
   What We Need & What You Get 
We need your help in providing free comedy to NYC audience this summer! So what will your hard earned money be used for? We are looking to raise $3500 for:

A Press Rep and Public Relations ($2000) 
Costumes and Props ($750)
Marketing ($500)

AND if we exceed our goal, maybe we can buy a meal for our hungry actors (who are all working for free)!!! #artistlife
Literally every dollar you give (and yes, even one dollar helps) make a huge difference!
   The Impact Your donations will help us to costume our actors, get the show reviewed by major press outlets, and help spread the word about our very special show. But most importantly, you will be supporting free theatre for NYC audiences.  While our great city offers some of the finest theatrical performances in the world, few people can afford the exorbitant ticket prices.  Providing free theatre is part of our commitment to serving our community regardless of commercial concerns.  You can help us achieve that!
From the very inception of our company, all of our productions have been free to audiences.  Audiences have roared with laughter and loved our shows.  We want to continue to bring quality comedy to audiences for free, but we can't do it without your help.

  Risks & ChallengesThe Department of Fools is a company of a dozen gifted and highly trained actors, who have worked on TV shows like QUANTICO and have appeared on stages around the world.  However, all of the Fools work for free on our shows because they love the work and want to bring the work to audiences without having to charge an arm and a leg.  In order to do that, we rely on the generosity of like-minded individuals who love comedy, mask work and just being silly!  If we don't meet our goal, we will survive.  We are a scrappy and resourceful bunch.  We will find a way to get the basics needed to bring a fine show to Fringe audiences this August.  However, literally every dollar you donate will help to improve the production values of the show, but even more importantly your donations will help us spread the word about our show to audiences and press alike.  We want to let people know about what we are doing, and continue to do it for free.  Please help us make that possible?
  Other Ways You Can Help Some of you might not be able to contribute, and that's really ok.  Times are tough for many, and as actors in NYC we know how precious every dollar can be.  But even if you can't give, you can still help us!  Please consider doing one or more of the following:  Help make some noise about our campaign.  Link to it on your Facebook or Twitter accounts!
Help us get the word out about the show!  Again, post on your Facebook or Twitter about this fun and free production happening this summer:  http://fringenyc.org/special-events/fringeal-fresco/

Encourage people to check out our website: https://departmentoffools.wordpress.com/

  Nuff' said. If you don't laugh, we'll give you a full refund!! Guaranteed!!!!

story:
As Straw Productions is pleased to bring the World Premiere of As Straw Before the Wind to the Ruby Theatre, opening August 13 and running through September 4. 

The play offers a window into the life experience of a Filipina nurse who survives the trauma of World War II, only to discover that her war is not yet over.  The play recounts an untold and forgotten story of Filipinos and their descendants. The playwright, the director and a majority of the cast are Filipino Americans, and we are pleased to provide opportunities to them and to the entire cast, all highly talented performers. 

Producing theater of any size in Los Angeles requires significant resources, and this is particularly true for unique stories such as this one.  

Here is our budget -- $12,000 in expenses

Breakdown:

Rent $3,550

Publicity Team ($1,000 x 2) = $2,000

Photography  $500

Artwork/design  $400

Postcards, flyers, programs, banners  $500

Advertising  $100

Costumes & props  $400

Transportation  $150

Actors ($250 x 7) = $1,750

Director/Co-Producer  $800

Writer/Executive Producer  $800

Technical Director/Stage Manager  $400

Assistant Stage Manager  $250

Misc.  $400


In the U.S. it's inevitable that at some point in your life, you’ll come into contact with a Filipina nurse.  Why not let it be our show, As Straw Before the Wind?

From everyone involved in the production, thanks so much!  Maraming salamat po!

story:
Playful Substance is excited to present Frank, a play by Grant Harris, as a full stage production in October of 2016. 

Grant Harris is a writer and actor residing in Brooklyn, New York. Grant's written works have been percolating with the encouragement of LAByrinth company members as well as LAB's extended family for the better part of two years. Most recently, his play The Boy Finds Love, enjoyed a reading at LAByrinth's theater on Bank Street in Manhattans West Village. As a co-founder and artistic director of Playful Substance, Bree O'Connor has worked as a producer, writer, director and teaching artist for nearly 20 years. Both Midwesterners at heart, Harris and O'Connor struck a creative partnership during LAByrinth's 2014 Intensive retreat in Connecticut. Frank will be their first public collaboration.

Frank has enjoyed two well-received public readings in 2016. The cast for these readings featured young veterans of the downtown scene, including 

Peter Collier as Frank

Neil Vincent Smith as Blake

Fiona Robert as Tatum

Maki Borden as Troy

Genevieve Myers as Carly

Matthew K. Davis as Logan

We are indebted to them for the contributions they have made to the development of Frank!

What We Need!

Our goal is to raise $15,000 to cover expenses for a limited run of 8 performances in a unique space that will transport you from the streets of New York City to a Midwestern world of homecoming dances, cornfield keggers, angry guitars, and a sky so wide and empty that it may open up and swallow you whole.

Here's what that entails:

  • Rehearsal and Performance Space Rental plus Insurance Costs = 30% of total budget
  • Stipends for Creative and Production Staff = 20% of total budget
  • Materials for Sets, Costumes, Props, Lighting and Make-Up = 20% of total budget
  • Promotions, Printing Costs,  and Graphic Design = 15% of total budget
  • Guest Services: Concessions, Applicable Licenses, Servers = 10% of total budget
  • Miscellaneous = 5% of total budget

Your contribution will provide materials necessary to explore creative lighting design, the unique use of sound to define both time and space (possibly a new pop tune or two?!), as well as a small stipend for our every member of our staff and creative team.

More importantly, your contribution helps keep our ticket price affordable!

Our perks to you, our generous supporters, will include tickets to performances, producer credits, signed memorabilia, and even an invitation to peek behind the curtain at our final dress rehearsal and enjoy dinner with the cast!

In the event we do not reach our goal, we will need to pare down our operation to the bare minimum to make it happen. We will first apply our funds toward our rehearsal and performance space costs as well as our mandatory insurance. After that, we will need to provide for creative solutions to the technical needs of the show including sets, costumes, props, lights, etc. We may be unable to bring in designers to help realize the vision of our show and we may have to ask our actors and our production staff to donate their time to make Frank a reality.

And Frank needs to be a reality.

Playful Substance and No Name Theater Company are committed to bringing this examination of rage and American promise to the stage. Yes, Frank is entertaining, It's fun! However, one of the greatest benefits of storytelling is how the good stories stick. They get under your skin and you can walk out of the theater a little different than when you came in.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand.

Sometimes you just don't have extra cash.

But that doesn't mean you can't support! Here are some things you can do to help:

  • Share This Campaign! Help us spread our message wide via your social network
  • Come see the show in October! LIKE our Facebook page for updates!
  • Check out playfulsubstance.com
  • Follow us on Twitter @PlayfulSubstanc
  • Do you have access to materials? Lumber? Fabric? Buckets of fake blood and latex? Anyone have a spare cervical halo or other scary looking medical equipment? Let us know! We might be able to make good use of it. Contact Bree at breedanielleoconnor@gmail.com

Thank you for your consideration and support.

We look forward to seeing you in October.

story:
Christopher Marshall is the 2012 winner of the S Randolph Edmonds National Playwriting Competition for the National Association of Dramatic and Speech Arts, and he has written several plays and screenplays.  He is also a successful director and actor who has directed over 10 productions and acted in over 45 productions including community theatre, dinner theatre, Off-Broadway, film and television. 

This campaign is a “Support the arts project” that is designed to bring enjoyment and great theater to the community as well as provide a platform for actors to express their art and creativity in telling such a breath-taking and riveting show.  

The money we raise through this campaign, will be used to pay for the expensive theater costs as well as purchase props and other necessities to make this dream a reality.  Donors will be the integral force behind transforming this project from a great idea into a great reality. Please support this project.  Contribute as well as spread the word to your friends. Every dollar counts.  Remember it is better to light a candle than to curse the darkness.

story:
It's the final hours of the campaign! Help us make the small difference! 


BLUFF the Play

  • WHEN: Tues. Aug. 2, 9:00 PM, Wed. Aug. 3, 6:15 PM, Sat. Aug. 6, 6:00 PM
  • WHERE: Hudson Guild Theatre, 441 W. 26th St., NYC NY

THE PLAY:  After a fall off the bluff behind her house, 40-year-old pregnant Jude Black descends into a coma, confined to a hospital room. The identity of her child’s father and the circumstances surrounding her pregnancy remain a mystery. As the play unfolds, the families of her best friend and her nurse unexpectedly collide, forcing them to uncover the festering secrets that bind them all. Yet, even in this twilight state, she comes to grips with the failures and traumas of her life that led her to attempt suicide.

There hasn't been a play like BLUFF in a very long time and it's sure to cause a stir. 

Our creative team is passionate, diverse, connected and experienced enough to get this play to the finish line... with a little help from you, of course!

The Impact

As tender as it is intense, BLUFF is more than just a play about six people whose lives intersect and implode. It's a door to a discussion that will continue long after you leave the theatre.

  • If you've ever wondered if someone in a coma knows you're there, then this play will have special meaning for you. It's built on the premise that not only can someone in a coma understand what's happening around them, they can synthesize that experience.
  • End of life issues are especially timely and the debate over coma consciousness continues to divide the medical community. BLUFF takes a look at the unknown, stretching the possibilities and challenging us to rethink what we know.
  • With recent reports that the suicide rate in this country is at an all time high, we have to ask ourselves why and subsequently open the door to a public discourse about a topic that continues to be taboo. Those who suffer from mental illness and severe depression often find suicide their only option. They need to have a voice in this discussion.  
  • The overarching theme of this play is a look at acceptance. Through the eyes of the characters, BLUFF explores the damaging effects of judgment and petty differences that only prevent us from honoring each other and respecting each other's choices. 
  • How we live our lives individually and collectively is a daily decision we all make. Whether this is an active or passive choice is up to us. But lying on our deathbeds may not be the best time or place to first evaluate that. 

Win, Win

There is no downside to investing in this play. Or the arts. Ever. PLEASE know that your investment allows you:

  • Accessibility. You're singlehandedly bringing new theatre to an Off Broadway stage. This is nothing to sneeze at. And you're doing it for far less than if you were an investor in a professional production with a normal run. 
  • A very unique investment. When can you actually see your hard-earned dollars play the role of hard-earned dollars for someone else? That's right! You're actually paying salaries with your investment and directly supporting actors in exhibiting their craft.
  • Far-reaching support. This just doesn't impact one theatre and one play. It affects the larger theatre industry as a whole in New York City, which in turn, impacts the rest of the country. As small theaters thrive in the Big Apple, new plays get a chance to be aired, and eventually, made available to theaters everywhere. Most of the powerful and important plays that you see today in your community theaters or even high schools were developed in Off Broadway venues.
  • You're more than just a number. But numbers do indeed matter. We need to show future Broadway producers we can attract investors. And the more people who show their support by donating--even at the minimum level--the better the show looks as an investment vehicle. 
Our budget
  • Insurance: $250
  • Actors & Staff: $7,000
  • Rehearsal Space: $1,150
  • Advertising/Marketing: $3,000
  • Programs/Scripts: $250
  • Props/Set: $350
Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to our campaign, you can still help!

  • Come see the show! The dates are listed above! Go to the Thespis Theater Festival website  and order your tickets online.
  • SPREAD THE WORD! Please share this Indiegogo campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram--tell the world about the play. 
  • Like us on Facebook.
  • Word of mouth is the best marketing there is.
  • Send us prayers and good wishes because we believe those are the most significant ways to achieve success.
  • If you'd like to contribute outside of the online campaign or help in anyway, contact us.

Programs/Scripts: $250

Word of mouth is the best marketing there is.
Send us prayers and good wishes because we believe those are the most significant ways to achieve success.
If you'd like to contribute outside of the online campaign or help in anyway, contact us.

story:
From Italy to NYC:  The Journey of
Death for Five Voices continues...


Death For Five Voices is an original musical by Peter Mills (www.pcmills.com) and Cara Reichel (www.CaraReichel.com) which presents a fictionalized account of the early life of Renaissance composer -- and murderer -- Carlo Gesualdo.   The show is an ambitious hybrid project, fusing classical drama and chamber opera with contemporary musical theater techniques.  We are undertaking this campaign specifically to support our expenses related to implementing the music and sound design needs for the production.

  • The show will be produced by the critically-acclaimed Prospect Theater Company (www.ProspectTheater.org) at the new Sheen Center for Thought and Culture (www.SheenCenter.org, 18 Bleecker Street in NYC's East Village) from March 24 - April 17, 2016 for a run of 24 performances.

  • Prospect is a 16-year-old non-profit organization that supports the development and production of new musicals by emerging artists.  The company’s previous work has received a Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Ensemble Performance (2013), as well as multiple other Drama Desk nominations, and a National Theatre Grant from the American Theatre Wing (creator of the Tony Awards).

  • Music and lyrics are by one of Prospect's founding members, Peter Mills, and the book is by Mills and Cara Reichel, the company's Producing Artistic Director.  The production will be directed by Reichel, and music directed by Max Mamon.  It is co-orchestrated by Mills and Daniel Feyer.

  • The production has been selected as a recipient of a prestigious and competitive Edith Lutyens and Norman Bel Geddes Fund Design Enhancement Grant to support scenic, lighting and costume elements.  Scenic Design is by Ann Bartek, Costume Design is by Sidney Shannon, Lighting Design is by Susan M. Nicholson, and Sound Design by Janie Bullard.  

  • The show was previously workshopped by Prospect in 2013 as a "Prototype Production" and has since been further developed at the Rhinebeck Writers Retreat (2014), and through a Spring 2015 writing and research Fellowship for Mills and Reichel at the Bogliasco Foundation (near Genoa, Italy), and was most recently developed in November 2015 through an international residency in Gesualdo, Italy, at the composer's historic castle.  

The Story

Death for Five Voices  is an original musical drama that explores the complex artistic personage of Prince Carlo Gesualdo, a groundbreaking composer of the late Renaissance.  The story is based on a historic event:  On October 16, 1590
Carlo entrapped and brutally murdered his wife, Maria D’Avalos, and her lover, Fabrizio Carafa, at the Gesualdo home, the Palazzo San Severo in Naples.  At the time, the murders were widely known and documented,  but nothing was done to apprehend Carlo who, as an Italian nobleman, and having caught the lovers in flagrante delicto, was within his rights.

This new work investigates how the composer's creative internal life and subsequent compositions may have been related to his brutal external actions.  Peter Mills' sophisticated score, which incorporates musical themes from Gesualdo's compositions, blends period musical style with contemporary theater storytelling to create a compelling portrait of a troubled artist, living at a moment in history when complex political and religious forces collided and changed our perceptions of the possibility of art. 

A cast of seven actor-singers and a chamber ensemble of four musicians will bring to life this gripping drama and psychologically thrilling tale of the voices that lived within Carlo Gesualdo.
 

What We Need & What You Get

For this project, we are specifically in need of support to assure we can accomplish the musical aspects of this production, in keeping with Gesualdo's legacy as an outstanding musician and composer.  Funds we raise through this campaign will be used to assure the best possible aural experience for both Gesualdo's and Peter Mills' music.  We've already raised funds for this production, including receiving a special design grant which will support scenic, costume and lighting needs.  However, we still are seeking critical funds to meet our production budget, and help the show realize its potential. 

  • We need to raise $15,000 through this campaign, to cover expenses related to the music and sound design for this production, including renting a piano and sound equipment, and hiring personnel including musicians and technicians.
  • Perks include exclusive behind-the-scenes access opportunities, opening night invites, signed posters by the company, an mp3 recording of a song from the show, and for those who are able to provide leadership funding, Honorary Producer credit!
  • Prospect Theater Company is a 501c3 non-profit, and all gifts are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law (less the cash value of any perks).

    The Impact

    After more than three years of development through workshops and writing retreats, we are excited to finally share this new musical with NYC audiences.

    • Prospect’s goal with this production is to create an intelligent and sophisticated new drama, which represents a new direction in Mills' and Reichel's body of work, expanding the American musical theater canon. 
    • We hope that the NYC premiere production will provide an important stepping stone to publishing and licensing this show for further productions in other settings, here in NYC as well as around the country and across the Globe. 
    • This production will provide important career opportunities not only for Mills and Reichel, but for all the emerging theater professionals (numbering more than 30 persons) involved in bringing to life the production, whose work will be seen widely by general audiences as well as industry professionals.

    Risks & Challenges

    As a company of artists, Prospect has a successful history of pushing the envelope and making theater magic with limited resources.  In our 16 years of bringing to life new musicals, we've learned how to stretch every dollar to create great art and important opportunities for emerging artists.  We also know the bottom line of what it will take to make something happen, and we're not quite there yet -- which is why we have launched this campaign and are asking for your donations.

    As an organization, we have the proven expertise and are ready to meet the challenge, so we hope you can give us a boost!

    We Need Your Encouragement.

    We hope you will lend your support to Prospect’s online campaign for our upcoming production of Death For Five Voices.  However, if you are not able to contribute at this time, please help by spreading the word about the campaign and performances to your social network!  Tickets are already on sale!  Visit www.ProspectTheater.org or www.DeathForFiveVoices.com for details. 

    We hope to see you at the theater soon!

    Meet the Composer

    PETER MILLS (composer/lyricist/co-bookwriter) is one of America’s most celebrated new musical theater writers.  Recently, he received the 2014 Donna Perret Rosen Award from NYC’s Second Stage Theatre and the 2011 Cole Porter Award from the ASCAP Foundation.  He was also honored to receive the 2010 Kleban Prize for lyrics, the 2007 Fred Ebb Award for emerging songwriters, 2006 Drama Desk Award nominations, the 2003 Richard Rodgers New Horizons Award from ASCAP, and a 2002 grant from the Jonathan Larson Performing Arts Foundation.  In addition to the twelve musicals he has penned for Prospect Theater Company, of which he is a founding member, Pete is currently writing lyrics for the Broadway-aimed production of The Honeymooners musical.  Peter holds an M.F.A. in Musical Theater Writing from NYU, and a degree in English/Dramatic Literature from Princeton University.  Visit www.pcmills.com for more information!

    About Prospect Theater Company

    One of America's leading producers of new musical theater, Prospect Theater Company (founded in 1998) is dedicated to fostering and showcasing today’s new voices shaping tomorrow’s musicals. Since 2000, the company has fully produced more than 30 premiere musicals in New York City, in addition to new plays and numerous re-inventions of classic works. Reflecting its investment in the future of the field, Prospect leads a variety of developmental initiatives, including an annual Musical Theater Lab for emerging writers, and a Summer Intensive training program for teenagers. In recognition of its work as a community anchor for emerging artists that strengthens the quality, diversity, and dynamism of American theater, Prospect received a 2013 National Theatre Company Grant from the American Theatre Wing. Notable productions include: the Drama Desk Award-winning Working (2012), the Drama-Desk nominated Tamar of the River (2013), Jasper in Deadland  (2014), Unlock'd (2013), Iron Curtain (2006, 2011), Myths and Hymns (2012), With Glee (2010), The Blue Flower (2008), Golden Boy of the Blue Ridge (2009), The Hidden Sky (2010), Illyria (2002, 2008), and the Drama-Desk nominated The Pursuit of Persephone (2005).
story_txt:
From Italy to NYC:  The Journey of Death for Five Voices continues... 
Death For Five Voices is an original musical by Peter
Mills (www.pcmills.com) and Cara Reichel
(www.CaraReichel.com) which presents
a fictionalized account of the early life of Renaissance composer -- and murderer -- Carlo Gesualdo.   The show is an ambitious hybrid project, fusing classical drama and chamber opera with contemporary musical theater techniques.  We are undertaking this 
campaign specifically to support our expenses related to implementing the music and sound design needs for the production. 

The show will be produced by the critically-acclaimed Prospect Theater Company (www.ProspectTheater.org) at the new Sheen Center for Thought and Culture (www.SheenCenter.org, 18 Bleecker Street in NYC's East Village) from March 24 - April 17, 2016 for a run of 24 performances. 

Prospect is a 16-year-old non-profit organization
that supports the development and production of new musicals by emerging
artists.  The company’s previous work has received a Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Ensemble Performance (2013), as well as multiple other Drama Desk nominations, and a National Theatre Grant from the American Theatre Wing (creator of the Tony Awards). 
Music and lyrics are by one of Prospect's founding members, Peter
 Mills, and the book is by Mills and Cara Reichel, the company's 
Producing Artistic Director.  The production will be directed by 
Reichel, and music directed by Max Mamon.  It is co-orchestrated by Mills and Daniel Feyer. 
The production has been selected as a recipient of a prestigious and competitive Edith Lutyens and Norman Bel Geddes Fund Design Enhancement Grant to support scenic, lighting and costume elements.  Scenic Design is by Ann Bartek, Costume Design is by Sidney Shannon, Lighting Design is by Susan M. Nicholson, and Sound Design by Janie Bullard.  
The show was previously workshopped by Prospect in 2013 as a "Prototype Production" and has since been further developed at the Rhinebeck Writers Retreat (2014), and through a Spring 2015 writing and research Fellowship for Mills and Reichel at the Bogliasco Foundation (near Genoa, Italy), and was most recently developed in November 2015 through an international residency in Gesualdo, Italy, at the composer's historic castle.  




The Story

Death for Five Voices  is an original musical drama that explores the 
complex artistic personage of Prince Carlo Gesualdo, a groundbreaking composer 
of the late Renaissance.  The story is based on a historic event:  On October 16, 1590
Carlo entrapped and brutally murdered his wife, Maria 
D’Avalos, and her lover, Fabrizio Carafa, at the Gesualdo home, the 
Palazzo San Severo in Naples.  At the time, the murders were widely known and documented,  
but nothing was done to apprehend Carlo who, as an Italian nobleman, and
 having caught the lovers in flagrante delicto, was within his rights.This new work investigates how the composer's creative internal life
 and subsequent compositions may have been related to his brutal 
external actions.  Peter Mills' sophisticated score, which 
incorporates musical themes from Gesualdo's compositions, blends period 
musical style with contemporary theater storytelling to create a 
compelling portrait of a troubled artist, living at a moment in history 
when complex political and religious forces collided and changed our 
perceptions of the possibility of art.  
A
 cast of seven actor-singers and a chamber ensemble of four musicians will 
bring to life this gripping drama and psychologically thrilling tale of 
the voices that lived within Carlo Gesualdo.   
   What We Need & What You Get For this project, we are specifically in need of support to assure we 
can accomplish the musical aspects of this production, in keeping with Gesualdo's legacy as an outstanding musician and composer.  Funds we 
raise through this campaign will be used to assure the best possible aural experience for both 
Gesualdo's and Peter Mills' music.  We've already raised funds for this production, including receiving a special design grant which will support scenic, costume and lighting needs.  However, we still are 
seeking critical funds to meet our production budget, and help the show 
realize its potential.   


We need to raise $15,000 through this campaign, to cover expenses related to the music and sound design for this production, including renting a piano and sound equipment, and hiring personnel including musicians and technicians.

Perks include exclusive 
behind-the-scenes access opportunities, opening night invites, signed 
posters by the company, an mp3 recording of a song from the show, and 
for those who are able to provide leadership funding, Honorary Producer 
credit!
Prospect Theater Company is a 501c3 non-profit, and all gifts 
are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law (less the cash value of 
any perks).

 
    The Impact 
After more than three years of development through workshops and writing retreats, we are excited to finally share this new musical with NYC audiences. 
Prospect’s goal with this production is to create
an intelligent and sophisticated new drama, which represents a new direction in Mills' and Reichel's body of work, expanding the American
musical theater canon.  
We hope that the NYC premiere production will provide an important stepping stone to publishing and licensing this show for further productions in other settings, here in NYC as well as around the country and across the Globe.  

This production will provide important career opportunities not only for Mills and Reichel, but for all the
emerging theater professionals (numbering more than 30 persons) involved in bringing to life the production, whose work will be seen widely by general audiences as well as industry professionals.
   Risks & Challenges  
 As a company of artists, Prospect has a successful history of 
pushing the envelope and making theater magic with limited resources.  
In our 16 years of bringing to life new musicals, we've learned how to 
stretch every dollar to create great art and important opportunities for
 emerging artists.  We also know the bottom line of what it will take to
 make something happen, and we're not quite there yet -- which is why we
 have launched this campaign and are asking for your donations.
As an organization,
 we have the proven expertise and are ready to meet the challenge, so we
 hope you can give us a boost!   
We Need Your Encouragement.
We hope you will lend your support to Prospect’s online campaign for our upcoming production of Death For Five Voices.  However, if you are not
able to contribute at this time, please help by spreading the
word about the campaign and performances to your social network!  Tickets are already on sale!  Visit www.ProspectTheater.org or www.DeathForFiveVoices.com for details.  We hope to see you at the theater soon!Meet the Composer 


PETER
MILLS (composer/lyricist/co-bookwriter) is one of America’s most celebrated new
musical theater writers.  Recently, he
received the 2014 Donna Perret Rosen Award from NYC’s Second Stage Theatre and
the 2011 Cole Porter Award from the ASCAP Foundation.  He was also honored to receive the 2010
Kleban Prize for lyrics, the 2007 Fred Ebb Award for emerging songwriters, 2006
Drama Desk Award nominations, the 2003 Richard Rodgers New Horizons Award from
ASCAP, and a 2002 grant from the Jonathan Larson Performing Arts
Foundation.  In addition to the twelve
musicals he has penned for Prospect Theater Company, of which he is a founding member, Pete is
currently writing lyrics for the Broadway-aimed production of The
Honeymooners musical.  Peter holds an M.F.A. in Musical
Theater Writing from NYU, and a degree in English/Dramatic Literature from Princeton University.  Visit www.pcmills.com for more information!

About Prospect Theater CompanyOne
of
 America's leading producers of new musical theater, Prospect
Theater Company (founded in 1998) is dedicated to fostering and
showcasing today’s new voices shaping tomorrow’s musicals.  Since
2000, the company has fully produced more than 30 premiere musicals
in New York City, in addition to new plays and numerous re-inventions
of classic works. Reflecting its investment in the future of the
field, Prospect leads a variety of developmental initiatives,
including an annual Musical Theater Lab for emerging writers, and a 
Summer Intensive training program for teenagers.  In recognition of
its work as a community anchor for emerging artists that strengthens
the quality, diversity, and dynamism of American theater, Prospect
received a 2013 National Theatre Company Grant from the American
Theatre Wing.  Notable productions include: the Drama Desk
Award-winning Working (2012), the Drama-Desk nominated Tamar of the River (2013), Jasper in Deadland  (2014),
Unlock'd
(2013), Iron Curtain (2006, 2011), Myths and Hymns
(2012), With Glee (2010), The Blue Flower (2008),
Golden Boy of the Blue Ridge (2009), The Hidden Sky (2010),
Illyria (2002, 2008), and the Drama-Desk nominated The
Pursuit of Persephone (2005).

story:
Reach/Recover

"Reach/Recover" came to life in 2013 as Christopher Allen's senior capstone at Arizona State University. After its run there, Christopher let the project rest before picking it back up in 2015 and entering it in Emerging Artists Theatre's (EAT) New Works Series in New York City. 

The musical was chosen as one of EAT's shows for the 2016 New Works Series and will be performed March 15 at 7 PM at TADA! Theater. Tickets available here!

Since entering the show into the festival, Christopher has been breathing new life into the project. He's taken his last three years of life experience after college and used those experiences to rework the songs and the dialogue. Now more than ever, "Reach/Recover" tells stories of lost love and forgotten relationships that everybody can relate to. 

Whether you grew up in an abusive household, struggle with a long-distance relationship or are simply trying to figure out whether or not to let a relationship go, you'll find yourself in at least one of "Reach/Recover's" songs. 

To make this production as great as possible, we need your help. Your donation will help cover rehearsal-space rentals, stipends for the actors and other collaborators, and marketing costs. 

What We Need 

We need to earn $2000 on Indiegogo to cover rehearsal costs, marketing, and provide a stipend for the performers who are pouring their hearts and personal experiences into this project. 

Here is a breakdown of where your contributions will go:

  • $500: Two weeks worth of rehearsal space throughout Manhattan.
  • $1200: Stipends for our actors, musicians and production team. 
  • $300: Supplies and marketing (scripts, posters, flyers, social-media promotions). Plus, any unexpected emergency costs that may arise. 

The Impact

By supporting this production of "Reach/Recover," you are supporting a talented network of emerging artists. Christopher Allen is a brand new playwright to New York City's theatre scene, and the show's actors and musicians are all non-union.

In addition to supporting emerging artist, you will also be supporting the arts in general. There is no experience that matches the magic one feels when they attend a live theatrical performance. You can help make this performance as magical as possible.

You my wonder, "How do I know that 'Reach/Recover' is a piece of theatre worthy of my investment?" Let us tell you:

  • When "Reach/Recover" was performed at Arizona State University, it was extremely well-received. Audiences connected with the show's message and found themselves in the show's music.
  • As mentioned above, this is a show that everybody can relate to, especially in New York City. There are 8.5 million people in this city, and "Reach/Recover" reminds them that they are not alone in their daily relationship struggles. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you do not have money to contribute right now, don't worry -- we understand! You can still help. Here are a few ways to help: 

  • Spread the word about "Reach/Recover." Follow us and share our posts on Facebook (Reach/Recover), Twitter (@Reach_Recover), and Instagram (ReachRecover). 
  • Please share this Indiegogo campaign page so others can learn about our show and contribute if they're interested.

Our Wonderful Cast

Morgan Assante - Ensemble

Eddie Carroll - Ensemble

Samantha Collette - Ensemble

Molly Gervis - Ensemble

Galen Sho Sato - Ensemble


Thank you very much!
