story:
Hey there!

My name is Jeremiah James and I came up with and developed the concept for It Happened in Key West, The Musical.   In addition I’m one of the book writers as well as the head producer. 

I began my career in the theater as an actor/singer and have been very grateful to have had a wonderful and fulfilling career over the last 18 years. 

In 2009, I began branching out into producing, writing and directing.  I started with large concerts, solo shows and cabarets around the US and internationally.  I never would have guessed that this would lead to where I am today with It Happened in Key West and to this incredible team of artists.                                                

The story of Carl Tanzler was introduced to me late one night in the 2004 HBO series “Autopsy.”   For reasons unknown, the story stuck with me and over the years I continued to research Tanzler but never found much information.

In 2010 Carl's story resurfaced in my mind.  The difference was that this time when I looked it up I found all the information I was looking for.  In that moment, reading this incredible true story of love beyond the grave, I was convinced that this story BEGGED to be told as a Broadway musical.

I instantly knew that there was only one person with the ability and talent to write this musical with me, and that was Broadway composer and lyricist Jill Santoriello.  I cannot express to those reading this how humbled and grateful I am to be working with such a brilliant and accomplished woman.

Not too long after Jill and I began work on Key West, I met the incredible playwright and novelist Jason Huza. With Jason as part of the team we truly were off to the races. The show seemingly began to write itself.

The journey of It Happened in Key West  has grown from simply an idea in 2010 to a legitimate full-length musical. We have a complete script, score, and a full demo recording as well as set and costume renderings. 

The next big event we are aiming for is a full 29-hour industry presentation in New York City August 13th through the 19th.  

Starting this particular campaign is another significant moment for us in this process.  Every single contribution goes directly to paying our actors, directors, musicians, and stage managers as well as for theatre and rehearsal space rentals, insurance, etc.  The list goes on.

This one-week presentation will be the launching pad for a fully realized production in 2017 including sets, lights, costumes and all the bells and whistles.  However, this can only become a reality with YOUR help through contributions.

On behalf of the entire creative team of It Happened in Key West, The Musical, we thank you.  Thank you from the bottom of our hearts for taking the time to check out our page and for helping us bring this hilarious and deeply touching musical to life.

Best Wishes

Jeremiah James

story:
Our Goal

We're using Indiegogo to raise a portion of the funds we need to bring Sarah Kane's most daring play, B L A S TE D, to Portland, Maine. As a new theatre company uprooting from London, securing the trust and capital to produce a play is a daunting and challenging task... but we're on our way

  • We've obtained the rights to produce her play for a limited 4  run performance.
  • Assembled an incredible creative team and cast who have been a staple of Portland's theatre community.
  • Signed a contract for a limited run in Portland Stage Company's wonderful Studio Theatre space in the heart of downtown Portland.  

Who Are We?

We are 60 Grit Theatre Company, a young experimental cohort of theatre makers exploring the darkest corners of human experience.  We strive to push the boundaries of traditional theatre by fearlessly dissecting what it means to be human.  60 Grit's inaugural production, Adam Rapp's Blackbird (a gritty tale  of addiction), opened in London March 2016 to 4 star reviews.  Now, we need your help to bring Sarah Kane's brutal and beautiful B L A S T E D  to the Portland Stage Studio Theatre.  The story is a technically ambitious production and we can not do Kane justice without your help.

About the Show: 

 Confined Spaces.  War.  Complacent bystanders.  Tabloid Journalists.  These are just a few components of B L A S T E D.   
20 years ago, Sarah Kane’s début play set the modern theatre on its ear: her work was championed by some and condemned by others for its violence and fearless presentation of the darkest facets of human nature.  This haunting, and eerily prescient play has lost none of its ability to stir and move us.  Many said that B L A S T E D overplayed the scenario of violence and was quickly  branded  a "... disgusting feast of filth." by the Daily Mail.   60 Grit Theatre Company intends to prove that Kane's story is more than senseless brutality.   Underneath lies a powerful exploration of human experience fiercely relevant to modern politics.   Kane shines a light on complacency, proving culture is wrong to assume distant wars have nothing to do with us and we are safe. 
 B L A S T E D  tackles extreme themes of sexual and physical violence and we do not take our responsibility lightly.   60 Grit will collaborate with the community and local trauma organizations to hold vital post-show discussions regarding trauma, specifically PTS related.  We hope to use this production to actively engage the community in important healing, awareness, and discussion.  Your donation will reach far beyond this production, allowing us resources to further engage the community and partner with vital trauma centres.    
Our Team SO FAR:
Cast:  James Noel Hoban, Heather Elizabeth Irish, Nick Wakely
Director: Lindsey Higgins
Stage Manager: Andrew Hesslebart
Sound Design: Chris Fitze
Lighting Design: Michaela Denoncourt

What We Need & What You Get

B L A S T E D is a technically ambitious production and your donation will help in a number of areas.  Venue cost and rehearsal space are our main expenses and any amount under our target goal will pay directly for the performance venue, rehearsal space, and performance rights.  Even a donation of $1 can not be understated.  If we are lucky enough to  reach our target goal, through your generosity,  the amount will be divided as follows.

  • Portland Stage Company Venue Hire (1 week): $950
  • Rehearsal Space Potland Ballet Studio (July - August): $650
  • Performance Rights, 4 performances: $400
  • Insurance: $200
  • Set: $300
  • Props: $200
  • Costume: $100
  • Printing (posters/programs): $200

Have a look at our perks to the right.  We have a number of great rewards including dinners with the cast, producer credits, free tickets, and much more!  

The Impact

By donating to our campaign, you aid in: 
  • expanding the work of a brilliant, contemporary, female playwright who has NEVER been produced in Portland or even Maine.  (as far as we know)
  • Sexual assault and PTS awareness.  Your funds will help 60 Grit Theatre Company actively engage with the Portland community by collaborating with local trauma and counseling centers to hold vital post-show discussions and healing. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The power of a $1 donation can not be understated, but we understand this is not possible for everyone.  If you would like to help, but can not contribute monetarily, please consider one of the following:

  • Get the word out, tell your friends and family.  Make a bit of noise!
  • Share the campaign on Facebook, twitter, Instagram, and any other social media outlets you may use. 
  • Volunteer to help on the production!  We need backstage help in many areas and would love to hear from you!

From the bottom of our hearts, THANK YOU for taking the time to read our campaign.  Your support is invaluable to us and this project would not be possible without your help.

By donating to our campaign, you aid in: 

expanding the work of a brilliant, contemporary, female playwright who has NEVER been produced in Portland or even Maine.  (as far as we know)
Sexual assault and PTS awareness.  Your funds will help 60 Grit Theatre Company actively engage with the Portland community by collaborating with local trauma and counseling centers to hold vital post-show discussions and healing. 



    Other Ways You Can Help The power of a $1 donation can not be understated, but we understand this is not possible for everyone.  If you would like to help, but can not contribute monetarily, please consider one of the following:



Get the word out, tell your friends and family.  Make a bit of noise!


Share the campaign on Facebook, twitter, Instagram, and any other social media outlets you may use. 


Volunteer to help on the production!  We need backstage help in many areas and would love to hear from you!


From the bottom of our hearts, THANK YOU for taking the time to read our campaign.  Your support is invaluable to us and this project would not be possible without your help.

story:
Short Summary

What is KWP Productions?

KWP productions was formed to inspire the next generation of performers and theatre goers. We are dedicated to providing performance and training opportunities for actors young and old alike. We provide the community with high quality theatrical programming for all ages.

Our Story:

KWP Productions was created 5 years ago at the request of a local theatre that wanted to provide family oriented programming. After a 4 year collaboration with the theater their programming goals changed and we found ourselves, at the last minute, without a facility in which to produce our plays and musicals. Subsequently we thought we arranged for another facility only to unexpectantly lose that space as well. There are very few appropriate performance venues in the northern end of Palm Beach County. As a result, the next year we rented a local high school theatre. Finding that this was not a good fit we realized that the best way to serve the community and continue our programming was to find our own space that we could use to produce our own plays as well as host events and programming for other groups who struggle with the gypsy life as we do.

Our current small studio (1100 square feet) is inadequate to really meet our needs and allow us to grow. Being nomads for performances is difficult.

We have found a place to call our own (4500 square feet!), a place where we can create our own theatre and share that space with a myriad of other organizations struggling as we are to find a cost effective and intimate performance space. In addition the venue would be available to private individuals for events.

We are entering our 6th season!! This is an exciting time for us. Your support will allow us to expand programming, build audience, keep producing high quality productions, provide a venue for others in need of a performance space and keep a roof over our heads! We are planning to produce numerous shows on our black box stage next year (2016-2017 Season). Including

 Our Children and Families Series

       Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (opening August 5th)

       The Adventures of Tom Sawyer

        Looking Glass Land

Saturday Morning Interactive Theatre

        Alice in Wonderland

Our “Classic” Series

        It Had to Be You

        The Complete Works of Shakespeare Abridged

         The Outsiders

         The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee

          Avenue Q

In addition we will be presenting events such as Character Breakfasts, Birthday Parties, Karaoke Night, Open Mic Night, Improv shows etc. and we will continue to offer classes, camps and workshops!!

Oliver - April 2015

What We Need & What You Get

To make the dream a reality we need you!

After years of rehearsing in hallways and small rooms, this new facility will provide plenty of breathing room for rehearsal and performances, in addition to more room for camps, classes and workshops.  Every dollar will help.

The following is a list of expenses that your support will help fund:

       Facility costs

       Annual Lease for space

       Materials to build a stage

       Lighting equipment

       Sound equipment

       Seating

By providing your support you will be helping to bring programming for all ages to northern Palm Beach County. There will be something for everyone!

We have many incentives for your support. From social media shoutouts to ticket packages and space rentals, there is something for everyone.

In the new space, we'll also have the opportunity to commemorate our supporters in a permanent way. There are naming opportunities for seats, the lobby and the theatre.

The Addams Family- October 2015

The Impact

This is a turning point for our Company this year. We are ready to meet the challenges that lie ahead.  Growth is  sometimes painful but necessary and in order to continue offering our programming and to expand the time has come to invest in our own home. We are on the right road.

The company members who have made the theatre their home and family, the theatre-goers who have enjoyed our productions, and the greater community that has benefited from our contributions to the arts and humanities ALL need your support so that we can continue providing service to the theatre-lovers in us all. 

Since our inception we have entertained over 20,000 patrons, provided performance opportunities for hundreds of children, employed local actors, tech crew and an outstanding creative team. We rent and loan costumes to local theaters and schools and support the arts in our community in a variety of ways.

Mary Poppins - January 2016

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can help financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. Spreading the word about us through social media with the Indiegogo share tools is key. Our friends and family can only help so much. We need the support of the community, people who just want to help for the sake of it. But they need to know about us first! Sooooo, talk about us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, AND REAL LIFE PLACES like your workplace water cooler, your local shopping venues, at other theatres, ANYWHERE. 

Together we can make this happen.

Shrek - March 2016

story:
HELP PITSIBURGO COME TO AMERICA!

Pitsiburgo is the compelling play by acclaimed writer Soti Triantafillou about the hardships οf Greek immigration to the United States in the 1910s. After a successful three-year run in Greece, Pitsiburgo is aspiring to follow in the footsteps of its heroes and visit the US this coming Spring (2017) for a two-month tour.

A moving and true story, Pitsiburgo is both timeless and timely, as Greeks are searching once again for a better life abroad and the Mediterranean is experiencing an unprecedented migrant crisis.

The Pitsiburgo cast and creative are volunteering for the US tour and all contributions will be exclusively allocated to production expenses such as travel, theater fees, room & board, etc. Shows will take place in academic institutions in Pittsburgh and other major cities such as Boston, New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles.


ABOUT THE PLAY

Shortly after their marriage, Demosthenes and Elego are forced to part. Demosthenes migrates to Pitsiburgo, as Greeks call Pittsburgh. He works nonstop at the steel mills to buy the liner ticket for his beloved wife. Their only way of communication is mail correspondence. Through their letters, they share their thoughts and agonies. Both yearn for the moment they meet again. Elego implores Demosthenes to send the ticket that will bring her near him. However, events will bring about an unexpected and moving conclusion. In Greek, with English surtitles. Duration: 80 mins.

CAST & CREATIVE

Soti Triantafillou / Writer
A celebrated multi-faceted author, Soti holds BAs in pharmaceutical science and French literature, PhDs in urban culture and film studies, a post-doc in Russian studies and has taught film theory. She has written multiple best-selling novels, short story collections, film books and children’s books. Her stories move with ease from collective historical events to the personal microcosm of the individual and take place against an impressive variety of backgrounds. She is also a distinguished translator of English, French, German and Italian. A cosmopolitan at heart, Soti is based in New York, Athens and Paris.

Babis Klaliotis / Director
A prolific director, actor and instructor, Babis graduated from the Hatzikos Drama School in 1986 and Film School in 1991. Among his directed plays are The Trojan Women by Euripides, The Birds and Lysistrata by Aristophanes, Letter from an Unknown Woman by S. Zweig, The Dragon by E. Schwartz, La Moscheta by A. Beolco and Oscar by É.E. Schmitt. As an actor, he has worked in prominent Greek TV series and films. He has organized numerous seminars and workshops, has served on the Board of the National Theater of Greece and is in charge of the Korydallos Theatrical Group and the Thanasis Veggos Festival.

Panagos Ioakim / Demosthenes
Panagos was born in 1981 and is based in Athens, Greece. He is a graduate of the Greek Art Theatre “Karolos Koun” (Theatro Technis), one of the leading Greek schools of dramatic art. A professional actor since 2010, Panagos’ stage performances include projects based on the works of important Greek writers like Aristophanes, Georgios Vizyinos, Georges Sari and Alki Zei, as well as more contemporary writers such as Petros Sevastikoglou and Soti Triantafillou. In the film industry, Panagos has acted under major Greek directors, such as Nikos Koundouros, Tassos Boulmetis and Pantelis Voulgaris.

Theodora Douskas / Elego
As the daughter of Greek immigrants in the Netherlands, Theodora has a special emotional connection to Pitsiburgo. Born in 1982, she found her calling in life after being enchanted with Ancient Greek Drama in high school. A graduate of the prestigious Greek Art Theatre “Karolos Koun” (Theatro Technis), she is based in Athens, Greece. A professional stage actress since 2007, Theodora’s performances are characterized by great versatility and include a variety of roles from the works of William Shakespeare, Anton Chekhov, Eugene Ionesco and Pierre de Marivaux among others.

REVIEWS

Antonis Giakoumis, San Jose, CA: "Pitsiburgo was for me a touching, liberating, almost cathartic, experience. As a Greek American, I connected to my family’s history and hardships in the most profound way. Kudos to Soti Triantafillou for giving us such a gem!"

John Lignades, Playwright: "In Pitsiburgo I discovered a vast ocean of images and feelings. It is a play that touches the human soul in the most intimate and relevant manner. I will keep Pitsiburgo, Demosthenes and Elego with me for a very long time."
Eirini Stamatiou, Actοr/Director: "Panagos Ioakim and Dora Douskas, two very talented young actors, give a sublime performance. Their acting is intense, layered and precise. At the same time, it is direct, simple and true. Highly recommended without a doubt."
Kostas Haralambous, Director: "Congratulations to Babis Klaliotis. He has managed to direct Pitsiburgo with unsurpassed style and energy, but also with an esoteric economy. He has created a play in which I found myself completely immersed and transcended."

story:
Short Summary

Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical (version 2.0!) will run January 27, 28, 29 (2pm and 8pm) 2017 at Vancouver’s Rio Theatre.

‘Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical’ is a Broadway-inspired pantomime informed by the foundations of traditional musical theatre and video game culture. ‘Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical’ is produced by Geekenders Theatricals, an incorporated theatre and event company in Vancouver, Canada. 

With a book written by Fairlith Harvey based on the dialogue in ‘Portal 2’, and clever lyrics written by James Dunlop, Geekenders Theatricals’ ‘Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical’ is an electrifying stage adaptation of cult hit video game ‘Portal 2’. Combining high-octane choreography by established dancer/choreographer Patrice Bowler and stunning direction by Fairlith Harvey and Andrew Lynch, ‘Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical’ presents a first-rate adaptation of a beloved video game in an effort to discuss topics of feminism, abusive relationships, PTSD, and body positivity.

Teaser trailer for the original production:


What is Geekenders?

Geekenders is a semi-professional theatre and event troupe with the simple goal of expanding the demographic that musical theatre, vaudeville, and burlesque appeals to, and to provide fun and safe venues for all people, nerdy or not, to mingle in. We do shows based on things that geeks (that’s us!) love, and are one of the only non-union theatre groups in Canada that regularly pays its actors.

We are feminist, queer-positive, and body-positive.


Costume design concept art by Shayan Naziripour. Prints available in the perks list!

Past shows we’ve done include Jurassic Parody: The Musical!, a pantomime-style show for all ages, Vegas-style spectacular takes on the Star Wars universe, and an interactive Batman-themed dinner event in a spectacular mansion on Halloween. 

You can check out our youtube channel here: http://youtube.com/geekenders

What is Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical?

Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical was the first all-ages show Geekenders ever put on. We were just doing it for fun, because we love the video game, and hoped some of our fanbase from our burlesque shows would come and see it.

Reddit, tumblr, and the internet at large got ahold of the show and the world exploded for us! Now, we want to put on a bigger, better production of the show that changed all of our lives.


Costume design concept art by Shayan Naziripour. Prints available in the perks list!

The musical itself takes familiar songs from the musical theatre canon and parodies them to reflect the world of Aperture Science and one test subject’s journey from a stasis chamber to the surface of the earth. Combining stage magic with two parallel stories of betrayal, love, and science, Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical tells the story of the second game in the Portal franchise with humour, heart, and tremendous chutzpah from a dedicated group of fans. While the show is a parody (as we turn the genre of musical comedy on its head and parody theatre tropes and classic tunes), the piece also treats the source material as the serious, beloved property it is. The resulting show is fast-paced, wacky, nerdy, and so much fun.

What We Need & What You Get

17,000 dollars pays for the production of the show at its barest minimum. It includes paying a stage manager and lighting designer and operator, and the cast, crew, and larger band with honourariums. It includes a budget for all-new costumes, as the ones from the original show have scattered to the winds and we wish to design something a little more magical. It includes a budget for publicity and a new, more immersive set. Additionally, it will cover new props; we didn’t plan to do the show again, and the original Portal guns were signed and presented to children who attended our original show. It also covers our rehearsal space and microphone rental, as well as paying a tech person for running those mics.


Costume design concept art by Shayan Naziripour. Prints available in the perks list!

The Impact

Having already established critical and commercial success in Vancouver, Canada, Geekenders Theatricals' Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical will be going on to set the standard for independent Vancouver theatre. As one of Canada’s only ‘amateur’ companies paying its actors, Geekenders Theatricals is ready to strip away the precedents of what it means to be doing theatre on an "indie" level. Geekenders Theatricals shows have established a reputation for good humour, warmth, and inclusiveness, and now wan to add the highest production values to that reputation.

EMPOWERMENT. Geekenders is proudly people-positive, casting artists based on passion and talent rather than weight, gender identity, appearance, LGBT-identity, or any other aspect of their self.


Costume design concept art by Shayan Naziripour. Prints available in the perks list!

Further, Geekenders practices a mentorship program, wherein in any given show, a passionate individual with either no stage experience or no specific experience with the genre of theatre we’re producing at the time, will be cast and mentored by the entire team. Donation to this crowndfund will help make an individual cast member’s dream of performing come true.

Further, The story of Portal 2 is, in some aspects, a cautionary tale about the powers of emotional abuse and romantic predators. These themes are explored in a frank way that is safe for all ages, but doesn’t shy away from the horrors that many men and women go through in their lives.

‘Portal 2: The Unauthorized Musical’ is a show with many layers, safe for children, with a message that adults can relate to on a different level.


Personality core clips -- available as an indiegogo-exclusive perk!

We believe that Geekenders’ message of acceptance is timely, but the mission of Geekenders is an important one as well. Geekenders puts on shows and events with specific pop culture themes so as to encourage audience members who have never experienced theatre before, to give it a try. 

Performed this January 2017 at Vancouver’s historic Rio Theatre, ‘Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical’ will be reaching 1500+ audience members of various ages, ethnicities, and gender identities - everyone is welcome at Geekenders shows. And that only describes the live audience. On youtube, Geekenders has over 500,000 total views, with the original production of ‘Portal 2: the (Unauthorized) Musical’ reaching over 150,000 people.

Risks & Challenges

We will be mounting this production whether we reach our fundraising goals or not, but as we pay for show expenses out of pocket, always, it’s hard for us to do anything but live from show to show. This crowdfunding experience will help us to create a nest egg with which we can pay for future shows without as much risk.


Costume design concept art by Shayan Naziripour. Prints available in the perks list!


With the show's established financial viability, secured run this January in Vancouver, and established partnership with the Rio, ‘Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical has already set the stage for Vancouver’s most exciting show this winter!

Team

Fairlith Harvey - Writer/Geekenders Artistic Director/GLaDOS/Caroline

James Dunlop- Lyrics

Patrick Courtin - Musical Director

Stephen Blakley - Producer/Adventure Core

Shayan Naziripour - Costume Design

Carolyn Rapanos - Set Design

Patrice Bowler - Chell/Choreographer

Andrew Lynch - Testing sequences/boss fight sequence/Fact Core

Fuschiamae - Consultant

Waffleguppies - Consultant

Erin Mudry - Chell

Graeme Thompson - Wheatley

Tyler Richardson - Cave Johnson

Rael Linford - Space Core

Chris Nyarady - Doug Rattman/Ensemble

Alisha Leveque - King Turrent/Ensemble

Cecilly Day - Turret Soloist/Ensemble

Chloe Mullington - Ensemble

Nick Drake - Ensemble

Andrew Jossa - 2nd Keyboard

Ian James - Percussion

Andrew Cullen - Bass

Stanley Tsang - Guitar

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share! We're on Facebook, Twitter, Youtube, the WHOLE LOT! Please get in touch with us at geekenders@gmail.com! This is a TEAM effort, and we always want to welcome any form of support on our team!

If Geekenders has affected your life in a positive way, please consider donating. We are trying to create something really special, as a warm, inclusive (semi-professional) space for actors and audience alike.

If you can’t donate, please consider sharing this page with an explanation of why Geekenders is special to you, and how it has changed your life, if that is relevant.

Thank you so much for your continuing support. We are part of an amazing community, comprised of a lot of countries! We are incredibly grateful to everybody who has supported us since our inception in 2012.

Our hashtags: #thecakeistrue #geekenders #portal musical

Prints of this full poster design, art by Shayan Naziripour, available in the perks list!

The resulting show is fast-paced, wacky, nerdy, and so much fun.

17,000 dollars pays for the production of the show at its barest minimum. It includes paying a stage manager and lighting designer and operator, and the cast, crew, and larger band with honourariums. It includes a budget for all-new costumes, as the ones from the original show have scattered to the winds and we wish to design something a little more magical. It includes a budget for publicity and a new, more immersive set. Additionally, it will cover new props; we didn’t plan to do the show again, and the original Portal guns were signed and presented to children who attended our original show. It also covers our rehearsal space and microphone rental, as well as paying a tech person for running those mics.

Costume design concept art by Shayan Naziripour. Prints available in the perks list!   The Impact 
Having already established critical and commercial success in Vancouver, Canada, Geekenders Theatricals' Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical will be going on to set the standard for independent Vancouver theatre. As one of Canada’s only ‘amateur’ companies paying its actors, Geekenders Theatricals is ready to strip away the precedents of what it means to be doing theatre on an "indie" level. Geekenders Theatricals shows have established a reputation for good humour, warmth, and inclusiveness, and now wan to add the highest production values to that reputation.


EMPOWERMENT. Geekenders is proudly people-positive, casting artists based on passion and talent rather than weight, gender identity, appearance, LGBT-identity, or any other aspect of their self.
Costume design concept art by Shayan Naziripour. Prints available in the perks list!
Further, Geekenders practices a mentorship program, wherein in any given show, a passionate individual with either no stage experience or no specific experience with the genre of theatre we’re producing at the time, will be cast and mentored by the entire team. Donation to this crowndfund will help make an individual cast member’s dream of performing come true.

Further, The story of Portal 2 is, in some aspects, a cautionary tale about the powers of emotional abuse and romantic predators. These themes are explored in a frank way that is safe for all ages, but doesn’t shy away from the horrors that many men and women go through in their lives.

‘Portal 2: The Unauthorized Musical’ is a show with many layers, safe for children, with a message that adults can relate to on a different level.Personality core clips -- available as an indiegogo-exclusive perk!
We believe that Geekenders’ message of acceptance is timely, but the mission of Geekenders is an important one as well. Geekenders puts on shows and events with specific pop culture themes so as to encourage audience members who have never experienced theatre before, to give it a try. 


Performed this January 2017 at Vancouver’s historic Rio Theatre, ‘Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical’ will be reaching 1500+ audience members of various ages, ethnicities, and gender identities - everyone is welcome at Geekenders shows. And that only describes the live audience. On youtube, Geekenders has over 500,000 total views, with the original production of ‘Portal 2: the (Unauthorized) Musical’ reaching over 150,000 people.   Risks & Challenges  
We will be mounting this production whether we reach our fundraising goals or not, but as we pay for show expenses out of pocket, always, it’s hard for us to do anything but live from show to show. This crowdfunding experience will help us to create a nest egg with which we can pay for future shows without as much risk. 

Costume design concept art by Shayan Naziripour. Prints available in the perks list!

With the show's established financial viability, secured run this January in Vancouver, and established partnership with the Rio, ‘Portal 2: The (Unauthorized) Musical has already set the stage for Vancouver’s most exciting show this winter!   
Team
Fairlith Harvey - Writer/Geekenders Artistic Director/GLaDOS/Caroline


James Dunlop- LyricsPatrick Courtin - Musical Director


Stephen Blakley - Producer/Adventure Core

Shayan Naziripour - Costume Design

Carolyn Rapanos - Set Design
Patrice Bowler - Chell/Choreographer

Andrew Lynch - Testing sequences/boss fight sequence/Fact Core


Fuschiamae - Consultant

Waffleguppies - Consultant


Erin Mudry - Chell

Graeme Thompson - Wheatley

Tyler Richardson - Cave Johnson

Rael Linford - Space Core

Chris Nyarady - Doug Rattman/Ensemble

Alisha Leveque - King Turrent/Ensemble

Cecilly Day - Turret Soloist/Ensemble

Chloe Mullington - Ensemble

Nick Drake - EnsembleAndrew Jossa - 2nd KeyboardIan James - PercussionAndrew Cullen - BassStanley Tsang - Guitar
Other Ways You Can Help 
Please share! We're on Facebook, Twitter, Youtube, the WHOLE LOT! Please get in touch with us at geekenders@gmail.com! This is a TEAM effort, and we always want to welcome any form of support on our team!

If Geekenders has affected your life in a positive way, please consider donating. We are trying to create something really special, as a warm, inclusive (semi-professional) space for actors and audience alike.

If you can’t donate, please consider sharing this page with an explanation of why Geekenders is special to you, and how it has changed your life, if that is relevant. 

Thank you so much for your continuing support. We are part of an amazing community, comprised of a lot of countries! We are incredibly grateful to everybody who has supported us since our inception in 2012.

Our hashtags: #thecakeistrue #geekenders #portal musicalPrints of this full poster design, art by Shayan Naziripour, available in the perks list!

story:
"Everything I Need to Know I Learned From... Ethel Merman" is a 60-minute musical extravaganza coming to the Blue Venue of Orlando Fringe 2017. Taking a hint from the popular children’s book, “Everything I need to know I learned in kindergarten,” this show explores the ABCs of survival in the adult world by following the wisest Diva of them all: Ethel Merman! Come along on a showtune-filled, laughter inducing, “one-man show” about growing up gay in a Pentecostal household in the bible belt where his only saviors were community theater, an old record player, and the vinyl recordings of Broadway’s greatest diva!

We feel this show will resound with anyone who understands the power of music, finding a personal anthem, and just singing your heart out to get you through life's trials.

While we our throwing our lives and possible sanity out the window to put on the best possible show for you, we still need your help! Any contributions you make will go towards the numerous expenses required to make our show a success: purchasing and producing props and costumes, renting rehearsal space, marketing and advertising, and so much more.

We thank you so much for your help, and even if you can't contribute here, we can't wait for you to see "Everything I Need to Know I Learned From... Ethel Merman". It's been a goal for years for us to have a show in the Orlando Fringe, and a true honor to have you hear this story. Because you're gonna hear it, even if you're all the way over in the Beer Tent.

Written and Performed by Mickey Layman

story:
OKaua Theatre Festival is our Companys 

biggest  accomplishment

 

     Behind this success hide 12 years of hard work and the tremendous efforts of each of the members who have hoped that one day, they could create a `playground` that theatre lovers and art lovers in general could benefit from.

        The first edition, in 2012, was the solid basis we needed in order to build up a strong, high class, national and even international competition in the following years.

          Our goals are the main goals that define our troupe:
"Education through theatre"

In the Western countries this form of education is implemented in the scholar curriculum while in Romania it only occurs thanks to the ambition of some truly art devoted people.

    Starting from the second edition, a new section was introduced, alongside the "High School" section:  "College", where shows produced by UNATC ( National Theatre University "I. L. Caragiale", Bucharest) and the Hyperion University delighted the audience and UNARTE ( National Arts University, Bucharest) showcased their Scenographic Models/Miniature Mock-ups and Theatre Masks. 

    Today we want to make one more step and change the status of the festival to "international", but this is still only a dream, and that is why we need your help.

     We know that everyone can make a difference and we want to give you a chance to do that. 

       Who are we?

      The name of our troupe, "OKaua" stands for our creed to take the measure of everything using a unique scale, the scale of TRUE VALUE and COMPETITION. "Ocaua" is in romanian language a unit of measure from the 19th century.
      This creed, inspired by William Shakespeare’s works, gave birth to the motto of the festival:

                                                                     `Measure for Measure`

      We were the only high school troupe in Romania invited to play in professional festivals, including The International `Shakespeare` Festival, for three editions in a row so we know how important it is for a festival to invite both professionals and professionalized amateurs.

 

     The present stage of our festival

 

Period: Between 10th - 12th of May 2017

Location: National Children's Palace - " Ion Cojar" Auditorium

Structure: Two Competitional Sections:
-High School (besides the play in the contest, there will be another `Short Play`, with a given sequence of a script)
-College (besides the play in the contest, there will be an impromptu)
-Dance and Theatre acts outside the competition
-Workshops
-Theatre Crafts Competition ( Best Theatre Mask "Ion Sava" and  Best Scenographic Model/Miniature Mock-up "George Baron Lowendal")

Jury:  UNATC Drama Coaches, TV hosts from the National Broadcasting Service of Romania, radio hosts, singers and composers, actors and actresses.

The Grand Prix of this Festival can be awarded to both a High School or a College Show.

Why and how can you help us?

    

        Our festival wants to become international and add even more forms of art at future editions like : theater - dance, theater animation, sports theater, pantomime, musical shows, and puppet theater.

        We self-finance ourselves through the contributions of each and every member and this is how we mostly have funded our festival, a lot of people/little sponsors have joined our cause but they are not enough for what we want to build.

        We sold handmade objects for 4 years to be able to pay for a part of the last editions of this event. We also had shows especially for raising money for the project, did volunteer work to promote our festival and won some prizes in money over time with our troupe.

         We need this fundraising in order to pay for :

- the transport, food and accommodations for every international or national troupe that would like to join us and every person who wants to see the performances but does not have the means to do it

- ads that can promote our festival and bring us more publicity

- paying for our prestigious jury

- offering food at the event

- all promotional materials like roll-ups, stickers and posters.

 

    We know how to deal with struggles because we started from nothing. We learned how to work with people, how to promote our ideas, how to build things with our hands, how to make promotional stuff and how to build something from scratch. We believe we can learn anything, and we can help you learn it to.

    We want our festival to grow along with its team and so we decided to ask everyone for help.

We would be pleased with any help that you can give, maybe a share, a facebook like, or a kind word, is all you have to give right now, and we really appreciate it.

 

Thank you,

OKaua Theatre Company. 

 

Website: http://festivalulokaua.ro/ 

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/FestivaluldeTeatruOKaua

_____________________________________________________

 

Festivalul de Teatru OKaua este cea mai mare realizare a Companiei noastre

 

 În spatele acestui succes, se ascund 12 ani de muncă grea și eforturile enorme ale fiecăruia dintre membrii care au sperat că într-o zi ar putea crea un "loc de joacă" de care iubitorii de teatru ,și iubitorii de artă în general, ar putea beneficia. 

Prima ediție, în 2012, a fost baza solidă de care aveam nevoie pentru a construi o competiție puternică, natională și chiar internatională în următorii ani.  

Scopul nostru este chiar deviza care definește trupa noastră:

 "Educația prin teatru"

În țările occidentale, această formă de educație este implementată în curriculumul școlar, în timp ce în România se produce numai datorită ambiției unor oameni cu adevărat devotați artei.

Începând cu cea de-a doua ediție, a fost introdusă o nouă secțiune, alături de secțiunea "Liceeni": "Studenți", unde spectacolele realizate de UNATC (  Universitatea Națională de Teatru și Cinematografie "I.L. Caragiale" ,București) și Universitatea Hyperion au încântat publicul și UNARTE ( Universitatea Națională de Arte, București) și-a prezentat machetele de decor și măștile de teatru. 

Astăzi vrem să facem încă un pas și să schimbăm statutul festivalului în "internațional", dar acesta este doar un vis, și de aceea avem nevoie de ajutorul tău.

Știm că orice ajutor mic poate face diferența dintre vis si realitate și dorim să vă oferim șansa de a face acest lucru. 

Cine suntem?

 

Numele trupei noastre, "OKaua", arată crezul nostru de a măsura totul folosind o scară unică, scara VALORII REALE ȘI A COMPETIȚIEI. "Ocaua" este în limba română o unitate de măsură din secolul al XIX-lea. 
       Acest crez, inspirat de lucrările lui William Shakespeare, a dat naștere motto-ului festivalului:

"Măsură pentru măsură"

Suntem singura trupă de liceu din România invitată să participe la festivaluri profesioniste, inclusiv la Festivalul Internațional "Shakespeare", pentru trei ediții la rând, deci știm cât de important este pentru un festival să invite atât profesioniști cât și amatori profesionalizați.

Stadiul actual al festivalului 

 

Perioada: 10 - 12 mai 2017

Locația: Palatul Național al Copiilor - Sala Ion Cojar

Structura: Două secțiuni competiționale:
- Liceeni (pe lângă spectacolul din concurs, va exista și un "Scenariu impus")
- Studenți (pe lângă spectacolul din concurs, va exista o probă de improvizație)
- Momente de dans și teatru prezentate in afara concursului
- Workshop-uri
- Creații plastice (Costume și Măști de Teatru și Machete de Decor – Secțiune rezervată studenților la scenografie și la arte plastice).

Juriul :  actori, profesori U.N.A.T.C. și din domeniul pedagogiei teatrale, oameni de radio și televiziune, cântăreți.

Trofeul festivalului poate fi câștigat atât de o trupă de liceeni cât și de o trupă de studenți. 

 

De ce și cum poți să ne ajuți? 

   Festivalul nostru dorește să devină internațional și să adauge și mai multe forme de artă la viitoarele ediții, cum ar fi: teatru-dans, teatru de animație, teatru-sport, pantomima sau musicalul.

Ne autofinanțam prin contribuția fiecărui membru și astfel am finanțat cea mai mare parte a festivalului nostru, foarte mulți oameni/sponsori mici s-au alăturat cauzei noastre, dar nu sunt suficienți pentru ceea ce vrem să construim.

Vindem obiecte handmade încă de acum 4 ani pentru a putea plăti pentru o parte din ultimele ediții ale acestui eveniment. Am avut, de asemenea, spectacole, jucate special pentru strângerea de fonduri pentru acest festival, am făcut voluntariate ca să promovăm festivalul nostru și am câștigat câteva premii în bani de-a lungul timpului cu spectacolele trupei noastre.   

Avem nevoie de această strângere de fonduri pentru a plăti pentru:

- transportul, mâncarea și cazarea pentru fiecare trupă internațională sau națională care ar dori să se alăture nouă și tuturor celor care doresc să vadă spectacolele, dar care nu au mijloace să o facă

- anunțuri si reclame care pot promova festivalul nostru și ne pot aduce mai multă publicitate

- plata pentru juriul nostru prestigios

- mâncarea pe care o oferim la eveniment

- toate materialele promoționale, cum ar fi roll-up-uri, autocolante și postere.

Știm cum să facem față obstacolelor pentru că am pornit de la nimic. Am învățat cum să lucrăm cu oamenii, cum să ne promovăm ideile, cum să construim lucruri cu mâinile noastre, cum să facem materiale promoționale și cel mai important : cum să construim ceva de la zero. Credem că putem învăța orice și ca vă putem ajuta si pe voi să învățați.

     Vrem ca festivalul nostru să crească odată cu echipa sa și astfel ne-am decis să cerem ajutor tuturor. 

Ne bucurăm de orice ajutor pe care îl puteți oferi, poate că un share, un like pe facebook sau un cuvânt bun este tot ce aveți să oferiți acum și îl apreciăm cu adevărat. 

 

Mulțumim,

Compania de Teatru OKaua. 

 

Website: http://festivalulokaua.ro/ 

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/FestivaluldeTeatruOKaua

Credem că putem învăța orice și ca vă putem ajuta si pe voi să învățați.     Vrem ca festivalul nostru să crească odată cu echipa sa și astfel ne-am decis să cerem ajutor tuturor. Ne bucurăm de orice ajutor pe care îl puteți oferi, poate că un share, un like pe facebook sau un cuvânt bun este tot ce aveți să oferiți acum și îl apreciăm cu adevărat.  Mulțumim,Compania de Teatru OKaua.  Website: http://festivalulokaua.ro/ Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/FestivaluldeTeatruOKaua

story:
Who we are

T: @F_COWtheatre I: @filthycowtheatre F: Search 'Filthy COW'

FilthyCOW is made up of Danielle Brook Weir and Roisin Brehony, supported by the current cast and company of our next show ECLIPSED.

FilthyCOW are driven to create and produce theatre that explores the roles of women; historically, culturally, socially and politically.

Our work strives to strip away the male gaze and show womanhood at its truest, bravest, strongest, messiest, flawed and most beautiful.We champion intersectional feminism and embrace the diversity of women's experiences around the world by exploring and devising new work, nurturing new writing and re-imagining existing texts; under the umbrella of our artistic policy. Women's stories. Told by Women.

Danielle and Roisin trained as actors at Rose Bruford College of Theatre and Performance. FilthyCOW's journey began in 2015. Then known as 'Winged&Gilded' they were part of Theatre Deli's inaugural Departure Point Programme, in which they were mentored both administratively and artistically by top industry professionals such as Roland Smith (Theatre Deli), Sarah Sansom (Time won't wait), Martha Mosse and A Younger Theatre. To conclude the 10 week programme, FilthyCOW produced an intimate adaptation of Charlotte Perkins Gilman's 'The Yellow Wallpaper' that combined music, aerial circus and the original text from Gilman's century short story. The performance was attended by Theatre professionals and venues. FilthyCOW hope to spread their wings without the safety net of these mentors and launch themselves professionally into the industry with 'Eclipsed' this summer.

What we're doing

ECLIPSED by Patricia Burke Brogan at The Space, Isle of Dogs, London 29th August - 2nd September 2017

FilthyCOWs' ECLIPSED  will combine live and recorded music, Patricia Burke Brogan's text and an intimate, sensory and claustrophobic setting to immersively bring audiences into Magdalene laundry in Ireland 1963. The time is important: Attitudes are changing in and around the second Vatican Council and outside, society is becoming more influenced by rock n’ roll each day. These two wholly opposing sides of society meet within this laundry: Claire Sharpe's skilled direction juxtaposes the music of Elvis Presley and traditional catholic hymns, dream sequences and very real mental and physical abuse of these women, to create a warped and blurred sense of reality that the audience will share. Opposites are a recurring theme of this production: Tragedy and hilarity in equal parts will force audiences to confront this area of history, and question the repercussions in todays society.

Why now?

This play feels painfully relevant in 2017 as reproductive rights of women in the Republic and Northern Ireland are still under siege. It is still illegal to have an abortion there and much of the healthcare in both nations comes under the umbrella of religious funding.

The last Nun-run Magdalene laundry was shut in Ireland in 1996. That's 21 years ago. Women's ownership of their own reproductive rights are still at the forefront of political discussion; being disputed and decided by the rich, white, male and powerful. If it's not Donald Trump's 'women should be punished [for having an abortion]'  it's Theresa May joining forces with the DUP. This is not an issue only residing in Ireland.

There is no denying the UK's immigrant connection and affinity to Ireland. The Irish diaspora spreads far and freckles the Isles with rich culture and history. We feel a firm duty to engage with a London audience (and eventually further afield) who, though rich in culture may not know about these goings-on so close to home.

The money raised in this campaign will be paying for:

- Actors' expenses
- The performing rights to Eclipsed
- Costume and set
- Specialist accent coaching
- Press and publicity
- Post show workshops and panel Q&A sessions that discuss how to get involved with reproductive rights organisations around the UK and women's rights in general.

The Impact

Your contribution would mean so much to FilthyCOW, a little or a lot can help us achieve our goals in some way or another. The most important thing is ensuring that this story is told and reaches a UK audience.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We know that purse strings are tight in the current economic climate, and if you can't contribute, but like the sound of what we do, please share this page far and wide and receive our eternal gratitude!

story:
BroVogue is a dance theater duo, a workshop, and a personal research project that explores layers of masculinity via non-male bodies. While masculinity is not owned by males it is forced upon them and appropriated by them in patriarchy. Dasha and Morgan view masculinity as a floating entity that anyone can try on and take off, indulge in, get trapped in, love and mock. While there are many types of masculinity that are not identical across racial lines they, being white, focus on white masculinity. It is important to scrutinize white masculinity because it dominates our societies and suffocates the diversity that may be more nurturing for the world. The characters, Yaroslav and Ricky, are two bro’s struggling with internalized homophobia as they practice conformity and perform the cliches of heteronormativity.  

In BroVogue the artists pose a question on how one can expand their identity to gain empowerment as well as a greater understanding of the world we live in?

What We Need

We have been working on BroVogue since September 2016 and we have been invited to a one week residency in rural Maine this summer! We are excited about teaching a workshop there to the local community as well as performing the evening length version of our piece for the first time. We plan to tour in New York during our travel. It will be our first time taking Ricky and Yaroslav out of the Bay Area! After workshoping BroVogue in Maine we are planning to focus on performing BroVogue locally for the rest of the summer. But we really need your support to achieve this goal.

We are asking for your generosity to support this awesome project. We are two full time artists holding part time jobs; coaching gymnastics, teaching dance, running a screen printing studio for social justice, and working farmers markets. We won’t be making any money from these jobs while we travel or work on the project.

Our budget:

Flights to Maine: $1,075

Food while traveling: $500

Other Transportation fees: $100

Oakland rent while traveling: $400

Money we lose while taking time off our jobs to work on BroVogue: $1,570

Total: $3,645

 

Why We Need It:

This project is important to us for a lot of reasons. As two queer people in female bodies our relationship to masculinity is fairly complicated.

Dasha Che - “I come from Russia, a very sexist society, where women are called a “weak gender.” I remember how at a certain age I was told not to be boyish and act according to my prescribed gender. For years I despised femininity because it was viewed as a second class category. My character Yaroslav has been helping me to uncover my internalized misogyny and work through it. While Yaroslav is embracing his femininity, I, a genderqueer person, get to respect my own.

Morgan True - “Masculinity for me was always something I wanted to express and be acknowledged for but was simultaneously glad I wasn’t expected to perform. I learned masculinity from my mother but in school I learned that being too masculine or not feminine enough would make me an outcast. Ricky is an opportunity for me to explore the freedom to express the masculinity I was denied. At the same time, Ricky allows me to use my femininity and my queerness to dismantle an ideal that most people can’t live up to anyway.”

We have a desire to recognize the masculinity that our bodies may feel at home in though we have not always felt safe or comfortable to try on. At the same time we strive to discern from the aspects which may be toxic and find a way to navigate away from them. We are seeking alternative forms of masculinity that deviate from the mainstream consciousness. We hope to encourage our audiences to explore their own relationship to masculinity by offering our own lense for viewing it through.

Anonymous feedback from the audience after BroVogue premier

"The dismantling of the homoerotic undertones of toxic masculinity."

"It was liberating in a way of offering more options for being over-the-top masculine vs. sensitive/ emotional."

"The challenge of navigating authentic connection in relationships when the performance of/ internalization of perceived gender expectations gets in the way."

"All the reflection on masculinity and socialization was fabulous. The homo eroticism was hilarious and brilliantly choreographed."

story:
BEAVER by Claudia Dey: a CO-PRO BETWEEN WeWillMeet Productions and The Storefront Theater #indieunite

I'm Chala Hunter, Artistic Director of WeWillMeet Productions. I am an actor, writer, and producer living in Toronto, ON, and I'm originally from Saskatoon, SK. I studied as an actor at The Univserity of Toronto, and The National Theatre School of Canada, and have been working as a professional actor, as well as producing and making my own work for ten years. I have a profound to see my ethic, politics and aesthetics upheld and fostered in the cultural ecology of this country.  This includes a devotion to female driven content, where the protagonists are women, and the stories foster a perspective other than the male gaze. I'm equally motivated to invest belief, time, and money into a Canadian aesthetic that reflects the landscape and people of this country, and their interactions and experiences, which includes people of all cultural backgrounds, including the first keepers of this land. I want to support, produce, and foster Canadian talent so that people are compelled to stay in this country.

WHAT IS THIS CAMPAIGN ABOUT?

My campaign is towards the full production of Beaver, a classical Canadiana story, with a renegade female hero.  In order to mount this show, and to do justice to the rich script and complex vision in a way that is inventive, highly stylized and bold I needed to hire designers and actors of the highest skill level. I have an enormous vision for this play, which is ultimately Claudia's vision, which she articulates with humour, love, poetry and intense specificity and skill in her text, capturing family relationships and the struggle to find one's way in the world in a way that everyone can relate to.

The same way a bank, or a new condo, or any new product needs investment to get it off the ground, this team and this story needs people who are passionate about making female driven stories a priority in our culture to help get this play off it's feet. Any contribution you make will go towards compensating these artists who are coming together from diverse communities and backgrounds to make this coming of age story for girls come to life.  Because of the turn around time between programming and production is under six months, the opportunities to apply for government funding are  very limited. This show will sell out, and the box office sales will cover our basic production costs, including rehearsal space and rentals. The Storefront endeavours to make theatre tickets accessible and affordable, and that means an incredible diversity of audiences members are able to, and DO walk through it's doors. But it also means this large team of primarily women needs outside support in order to make this project sustainable for these incredibly devoted and talented artists. 

WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO?

Your contributions will allow the team to cover some production costs and contribute to the compensation of the performers, who will be working fast and hard over three weeks. 

We will be transforming The Storefront Theatre with a design that will make the space nearly unrecognizable.  We are interested in pushing forward a growing desire for an inventive and modern aesthetic in the theatre culture of Toronto, that moves outside of traditional forms of narrative realism, alongside our European and American counterparts, who are WELL ahead of us in this regard. We need so much paint to do this. So much.

Our lightning designer, Kaileigh Krysztofiak is coming from The Stratford Festival to work on Beaver, and because The Storefront has a limited lighting set up, we will need to rent external light fixtures in order to uphold her incredible vision for the lights, which play such an important part of Claudia's highly aesthetic play, in which light and sound are described in articulate and precise detail. 

Rehearsal space, rights to the brilliant play (writers need to get paid also), and a membership to TAPA (Toronto Alliance for the Performing Arts) so that we can be included in the official Dora Jury Nomination selection are addition production costs that will allow this story of a young woman struggling, and ultimately succeeding, to overcome family trauma, inhabit her own life, and personal power, to be produced with the level professionalism it deserves.

After all our production costs are met, all remaining funds will be divided equally according to The Equity Artist's Collective Policy, among all artistic members of the team, which includes the director, stage manager (invaluable!), designers, and the actors.

 

BENEFITS/PERKS

 

WHY DOES THIS PLAY MATTER IN THE GRAND SCHEME?

Joseph Campbell, mythologist and writer of “The Hero With a Thousand Faces”, says we need stories to exist so that we can feel their relevance to what is happening in our own lives. So what happens if you grow up, mature, and continue to exist still being show primarily male hero myths?  Certainly much of the theatre STILL being produced in this country (and the world) depict female experiences of being alive as constructed by men. If we tell these stories again and again, no matter how we frame and re frame them, they still largely feature women who are demonized for their desires, or punished for ambition, anger, strength--characteristics celebrated in the men inside these same stories. This is part of what makes Beaver, a story that delves into the lives of five women struggling to “fly their own flag”, so special and essential at this time in our cultural ecology, as Canadians. The opportunity to make a difference in the way we allow women to think about their lives is at our fingertips, and as an artist who contributes to culture I feel this responsibly acutely.

Language is a site of cultural and political struggle. So then what are the cultural and political ramifications of continually putting up plays, or creating content that reinforces gender roles and replays (literally re-plays) traumatic or oppressive situations and circumstances? What does is mean that the word HERO is still associated with maleness? It’s easy to just throw around phrases like “girl power” and “strong woman” (as if the word ‘woman’ doesn’t already include strong in its meaning) but what we really need to work on is getting active about understanding that a female hero myth is just a hero myth, with a female hero. 

WeWillMeet Productions has a history of producing feminist theatre experiences, (Five Fingers, Amy: La Reine des Morts, and Fresh Water) and I have cultivated an acting and producing career were every project I take on integrates my social and political values, I am constantly investigating how I can question the gendered implications within every role I play, because I know that what I put out there, will affect younger women watching me.
 
When I first read Beaver, and discovered Claudia's writing, which is both poetic, playful, funny, and bitterly honest, I felt as though someone had finally given my spirit water to drink. The sense of feeling represented and recognized, of being reflected back to myself was life changing, literally.  All the women who have read this play, including the ones who are going to work on it, are captured and captivated by the play, it has a kind of resonance for women of all ages and backgrounds. If the purpose of art isn't to awaken people's heart's in this way, so they can feel seen, less alone, and more alive, then I don't know what it is.
 

 

POSSIBLE RISKS

The risks in this production are that many of the artists won't be reasonably financially compensated. Artists work for free, or not enough pay, often out of devotion to a cause, the craft, and for the joy of the work they are making. This doesn't make it ok. I think we need as a community to really consider how art and culture enriches our life, and continually ask ourselves what the value of that enrichment is, in an era where music, film, and other forms of media are so readily downloadable/steable for "free".  I have very little doubt about the levels of excitement and attendance for this play, since Claudia is a revered and celebrated writer, and the cast is filled to the brim with recognized and acclaimed Toronto actors, designers, and the director, Brendan McMurtry-Howlett has an outstanding reputation. Also: the time is ripe. There has been a recent surge in the arts, especially the performing arts,  towards devoting funding towards making female driven content, and ensuring that women are in positions of power (writer, director, producer).  This surge has come out of the undeniable recognition that things are truly out of balance, and that the demand and desire for stories coming from the female gaze, rather than the predominant male gaze, is very large.  This content, contrary to previous assumptions, will sell.

OTHER HELP

Use all your fancy social media skills. Here are some tips. Share this campaign. Share it with people you know love the arts, that are activist and social justice advocats, that are feminists, that appreciate that every effort makes a difference. Talk about it. Come to the show. Bring women and men you know. Bring young women.

#Beaver #Claudiadey #thestorefronttheatre #indieunite #bechdeltest #bechdelbill #heroine

Follow us at:

Instagram @hunterche @the_storefrontto

Twitter @ChalaHunter @StorefrontTO

Check out: http://thestorefronttheatre.com/events/beaver/

So then what are the cultural and political ramifications of continually putting up plays, or creating content that reinforces gender roles and replays (literally re-plays) traumatic or oppressive situations and circumstances? What does is mean that the word HERO is still associated with maleness? It’s easy to just throw around phrases like “girl power” and “strong woman” (as if the word ‘woman’ doesn’t already include strong in its meaning) but what we really need to work on is getting active about understanding that a female hero myth is just a hero myth, with a female hero. 
WeWillMeet Productions has a history of producing feminist theatre experiences, (Five Fingers, Amy: La Reine des Morts, and Fresh Water) and I have cultivated an acting and producing career were every project I take on integrates my social and political values, I am constantly investigating how I can question the gendered implications within every role I play, because I know that what I put out there, will affect younger women watching me. When I first read Beaver, and discovered Claudia's writing, which is both poetic, playful, funny, and bitterly honest, I felt as though someone had finally given my spirit water to drink. The sense of feeling represented and recognized, of being reflected back to myself was life changing, literally.  All the women who have read this play, including the ones who are going to work on it, are captured and captivated by the play, it has a kind of resonance for women of all ages and backgrounds. If the purpose of art isn't to awaken people's heart's in this way, so they can feel seen, less alone, and more alive, then I don't know what it is. 
 
POSSIBLE RISKS
The risks in this production are that many of the artists won't be reasonably financially compensated. Artists work for free, or not enough pay, often out of devotion to a cause, the craft, and for the joy of the work they are making. This doesn't make it ok. I think we need as a community to really consider how art and culture enriches our life, and continually ask ourselves what the value of that enrichment is, in an era where music, film, and other forms of media are so readily downloadable/steable for "free".  I have very little doubt about the levels of excitement and attendance for this play, since Claudia is a revered and celebrated writer, and the cast is filled to the brim with recognized and acclaimed Toronto actors, designers, and the director, Brendan McMurtry-Howlett has an outstanding reputation. Also: the time is ripe. There has been a recent surge in the arts, especially the performing arts,  towards devoting funding towards making female driven content, and ensuring that women are in positions of power (writer, director, producer).  This surge has come out of the undeniable recognition that things are truly out of balance, and that the demand and desire for stories coming from the female gaze, rather than the predominant male gaze, is very large.  This content, contrary to previous assumptions, will sell.

OTHER HELP
Use all your fancy social media skills. Here are some tips. Share this campaign. Share it with people you know love the arts, that are activist and social justice advocats, that are feminists, that appreciate that every effort makes a difference. Talk about it. Come to the show. Bring women and men you know. Bring young women.
#Beaver #Claudiadey #thestorefronttheatre #indieunite #bechdeltest #bechdelbill #heroine
Follow us at:
Instagram @hunterche @the_storefrontto
Twitter @ChalaHunter @StorefrontTO
Check out: http://thestorefronttheatre.com/events/beaver/

story:
WHO WE ARE:

Third Eye Theatre Ensemble presents quality productions that inspire conversation. We want to get people talking about the issues we face in today's world and hope the power of music and theater can inspire those conversations at a community level. We strive to champion rarely performed operatic works while advocating social change and providing Chicago's emerging artists with performance opportunities. We perform in intimate spaces so you can be up close to the action, and we have a come as you are policy - no need to dress up for the opera!

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:

Many people don't realize that arts organizations cannot survive on ticket sales alone. In a typical arts organization, individual giving makes up 40% of funding. For newer companies, the number is much higher. This is because it is difficult to obtain grant money from foundations and government organizations without a proven track record and body of work. Therefore, we have to rely heavily on individual giving for a large part of our funding. We hope you will believe in what we want to achieve and will contribute as generously as you can. Every bit helps, so even if you can only give $5, that still helps us get closer to our goal.

WHAT YOU WILL GET:

Our perks are listed on the right hand side of the page. We think they are pretty cool! Everyone who donates to our campaign will be listed on our website as a supporter of Third Eye Theatre Ensemble. Those who donate prior to 10/2 will also be listed in our program. Additionally, you'll get our undying gratitude, which we hope counts for a lot, and a feeling that you are making a difference. Your contribution, however big or small, helps us tremendously! You're also helping to keep the performing arts alive. Who wouldn't feel good about that?

WHERE THE MONEY GOES:

  • Artist Salaries (Singers, Actors, Directors, Designers)
  • Sets, Lighting, Props
  • Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Performance Space Rental
  • Truck Rental (for transporting set pieces and lighting equipment)
  • The Rights and Rental Fees to Perform Dark Sisters
  • Insurance
  • Marketing
  • Unforeseen Expenses (we all know these happen!)

HOW DOES MY CONTRIBUTION HELP:

Here are some examples of what your specific contribution can do for us:

  • $10 buys 1 hour of rehearsal space rental
  • $25 buys 1/4 hour of truck rental
  • $50 buys 1 hour of performance space rental
  • $100 buys all of the props for our show
  • $250 buys half of the costumes for our show
  • $500 buys all of our set pieces and lighting equipment
  • $1000 buys the rights to perform Dark Sisters

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

  • Come and see the show, October 21 through November 6 (Fridays, Saturdays, Sundays)
  • Share this link with others 
  • Like us on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/thirdeyete
  • Follow us on Twitter - https://twitter.com/ThirdEyeTE
  • Visit our website at www.thirdeyete.com and sign up for our emails
  • Sign up at iGive.com and shop online at over 1400 retailers who will donate a percentage of your purchase to us - http://www.igive.com/396NT6J
  • Help us spread the word!
