story:
It is with great pleasure that we are announcing the new production of "Les Bonnes" ("The Maids") by Jean Genet at La MaMa in the original French language, coproduced by L'Atelier Theatre Productions & La MaMa.

 

How this project came about?

The idea for this project emerged two years ago from the desire to explore Genet's ferocious play in the original French language. Last year, we gathered a wonderful team of director and actors and workshopped the play through a resolutely physical approach. As we entered the complex world of the play's characters, we were amazed by the layers and the colors intertwined in the play, both in terms of character relationships and in terms of political resonance. 

This past September, we have been invited by La MaMa Theater to present the play in a coproduction. We are so grateful to La MaMa for their invitation and we are very much looking forward to presenting this timely play in their theater.

 

Why you are so important

As we are entering the rehearsal phase, we are now reaching out to YOU.

We are looking for your support to make our production as exciting as it can be.

We are looking to raise $10,000 in order to finance part of our production costs, including set, costumes, props, promotion material, designers and PR.

By helping us now, you will not only help us reach the full potential of this production,  but you will also participate in making our artistic choices most meaningful.

The first $5,000 will cover our basic production budget. The following $5,000 will allow us to make daring choices and to remunerate our creative team as they should be. So let's work together towards the first $5,000!

All contributions are tax deductible. L'Atelier Theatre NY, Inc is a non-profit 501c3 organization and therefore, you will receive a donation receipt to file with your taxes. 

 

There are many ways to help

We gladly accept your donations, small and large. But, if you cannot donate, there are many ways to help. By spreading the word about our campaign and show, you are already making a big difference. Please feel free to share our campaign on Facebook and to spread the word with your friends, colleagues and families!

We are also reaching out to private & corporate donors. If you would like to help by putting us in touch with donors you know or if you think that your company may be interested in supporting our project, please put us in touch by sending us an email at lesbonnesbygenet@gmail.com.

Finally, if you would like to help the production, creative or crew team, please shoot us an email with your skills and interests at lesbonnesbygenet@gmail.com. We gladly accept in-kind contributions. 

We hope that you will join in our effort to make this promising production reach its full potential. We thank you for your help and look forward to seeing you in the theater.

 

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR HELP & SUPPORT

 

About the Maids

An aborted revolution, Les Bonnes (the Maids) stages the pathetic failure to break from social domination when the engine that drives the revolt is an unescapable identification to the very power that is the source of oppression. In this case, the only refuge becomes fantasy where boundaries are blurred and taboos lifted. Here, savage love erupts and finds no other exit than self destruction. 

An unequivocal literary work, Genet’s play captures the grim substance of the incestuous relationship of the Papin sisters while sending us to a flower-coated fantasy dream. Role games and class war add a singularly timely dimension to this classic, in a time of stark political and economic divide.

About the Artists

Oliver Henzler (Director) is a New York based theater maker and performer. His passion for directing and devising theater productions derives from his in-depth experience as a performer over the past fifteen years. On stage, Oliver has worked in numerous productions including Shakespeare’s Pericles (ART), Berlioz’ Benvenuto Cellini (Metropolitan Opera, NY), Peter Shaffer’s Amadeus, Adam Rapp’s Nocturne, Strindberg’s The Pelican, Fabio Rubiano’s Mosca, Büchner’s Woyzeck, and Rashomon based on Akutagawa’s short stories. Oliver also frequently works on TV and Film. Recent appearances include roles on Blacklist (NBC) and Person of Interest (CBS), and feature films The Happy House and the soon-to-be released Too Cold To Swim and A Different Sun. Oliver is a graduate of Wesleyan University (BA with honors) and Columbia University (MFA), he is an authorized Synapsing® teacher and a guild certified Feldenkrais® practitioner.

Laura Lassy Townsend (Actor & Producer) is a New York based actor originally from Paris, France. Her credits include the National Opera of Paris, the Venice Film Festival, Classic Stage Company, The Rattlestick Theatre, Mabou Mines and Target Margin Theater. Laura has taught as a Teaching Artist at Classic Stage Company, the French Institute Alliance Française and is the co-founder of L'Atelier Théâtre NY, where she teaches drama in French.She is a member of Actors' Equity. She holds an MSc in Business from HEC, Paris and an MFA in Acting from Columbia University.

Cloe Xhauflaire (Actor) is an actress hailing from Belgium. She has worked extensively in film, television, and the theatre in Belgium, France and the US. In Europe, she has worked with numerous established directors and founded her own successful theatre company, with which she won the "Best Young Creative Artist Project” national award for The Belgrade Trilogy. She studied theatre at The Royal Drama Conservatory in Brussels & LAMDA. For a full list of credits, www.cloexhauflaire.com

Hélène Godec (Actor) is an accomplished French actress whose various work has been seen on stage, film and TV. Theater credits include Advice to a Young Bride, Dialogues en soliloque, Les nuits de la colère, Au dessus des chiffons, Don Juan de Manara, Six personnages en quête d’un auteur among many others. Helene Godec has played in several film roles and leading and recurring roles in many popular French television series including Sections de Recherches and Paris Enquêtes Criminelles (French Law and Order). Helene is the artistic director of the theater company “L’Arpenteuse Géomètre”, whose mission is to seek support for young playwrights. Helene also teaches theater at Fordham University where she recently directed L’amour médecin by Molière. Helene holds an MFA from France’s top national theater school, L’ENSATT (L’Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Arts et Techniques du Théâtre) and earned a Bachelor’s degree in Theater from the Sorbonne University. For more info, www.arpenteusegeometre.com

 

Leah Lawrence (Musical Composition) is an actor and singer-songwriter with credits off-Broadway, national television and two released albums of her own music, available on Itunes, Amazon & Spotify (Folk by Foulke, Volume 1 & Everywhere To Go: Folk by Foulke V.2 ). Leah has composed original music for theater productions including John Gould Rubin's Hamlet, the Caucasian Chalk Circle, CoCoLab’s Dylan’s Lullaby and Blink, and written an original musical entitled Jungle Suburbia. Graduate of Colorado College (BFA) and Columbia University (MFA); she is an authorized Synapsing teacher and certified Yoga instructor. 


Roxane Revon (Producer) is a French theater director and producer based in NYC. A graduate from La Sorbonne University in Paris and HB Studio, she has worked with the Actors Studio, the Wired Arts Festival, the Avignon Festival, the New York Theatre Globe, the Play Company, Transatlantique Co., Dell’Arte Opera, LRP Productions, and Roots and Wings Co. She directed numerous plays including Two shall meet by Caralie Christo, Menteurs by Colette Lapointe, Huis Clos (No Exit) by Sartre, Music Hall by J-L Lagarce, Le Poisson Rouge by S. Grassian, The Bald Soprano by Ionesco, The Just Assassins by Camus, La Nuit de Valognes by E.E Schmitt, and Les Précieuses Ridicules by Molière. She was a member of the PD Unit of the Actors Studio in 2014 and directed Madwomen of Chaillot by J. Giraudoux with members of the Actors Studio.  She is the founding director of L’Atelier Théâtre NY and teaches acting, directing and French drama at CUNY University as well as L’Atelier Théâtre NY.

 

About L'Atelier Theatre Productions

L'Atelier Theatre Productions is the professional production branch of L'Atelier Theatre NY. We support emerging artists presenting bold theater projects in the French language in New York. 

L'Atelier Theatre NY has become renowned for providing drama classes in French to the French and francophile community in New York. Founded by Roxane Revon and Laura Lassy Townsend, L'Atelier's classes have drawn a joyous community of theater lovers and players to its classes. Every year, hundreds of French theater lovers have come to see our student shows at the 4th Street Theater, including most recently Feydeau's "Le Dindon" & "La dame de chez Maxim'", and Molière's "Le Malade Imaginaire" & "Les Précieuses Ridicules".

With "Les Bonnes" by Jean Genet, we are launching the professional production branch of L'Atelier Theatre NY . By developing such a project, we hope that we’ll not only present a bold and inspiring play to our audiences but that we will forge a movement for our collective that will allow us to build future projects that continue the dialogue between European and American Theater. We intend to build a New York-based community of artists, hailing from European horizons, who are ready to blend the two theater heritages here in New York.

We hope that you will join us by supporting the first project of our production company. 

https://ateliertheatreny.com/

 

About La MaMa Experimental Theater

La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club is dedicated to the artist and all aspects of the theatre. Founded in 1961 by Ellen Stewart, La MaMa is recognized as the seedbed of new work by artists of all nations and cultures. To date, La MaMa has presented more than 150,000 artists from over 70 nations. Each season, we offer more than 80 productions and receive 34,000 visits from people of all ages and all backgrounds who attend performances, exhibitions, educational activities and the Archives.

La MaMa has a worldwide reputation for supporting fearless and provocative theater while helping artists gain a foothold in New York. La MaMa is a global organization with creative partners and dedicated audiences around the world.

La MaMa provides a supportive home for artists and takes risks on new work. Artists such as Sam Shepard, Lanford Wilson, Philip Glass, Robert Wilson, Harvey Fierstein, Blue Man Group, David and Amy Sedaris, – and others whose names you haven’t heard of yet – began their careers at La MaMa. International artists introduced to America by La MaMa include Tadeusz Kantor, Andrei Serban, Kazuo Ohno and, more recently, the acclaimed Belarus Free Theatre. In its 50 year history, La MaMa has been honored with more than 30 OBIE Awards, dozens of Drama Desk and Bessie Awards, and Villager Awards.

As a landmark institution for artists and audiences alike, La MaMa presents cross-disciplinary work in theatre, dance, performance art, and music that defies form and transcends boundaries of language, race, and culture.

http://lamama.org/

story:
Who we are!

Cirquedelic is a bay area circus crew that produces events, as well as provides incredible atmosphere and performance. Alongside SpekrFreks, Wood St Productions, and Inked Sherbert we have created a spectacle of a show. Not only are we looking forward to performing it in Oakland this March, but we also plan to take it on the road. The album has been funded and created but we still have costumes, sets, props, hours of projection mapping, and so much more to create. Which is why where you come in!

The Breakdown

So why do we need $13,000? Well to start we need to design and create 12 beautiful costumes that are both pleasing to look at, and functional to the circus performer. On top of that our Dr. has turned our performers into mechanical marvels, which are all props that need to be built and again usable to the performers wearing them. Factor in makeup, and additional performance props and that alone gets expensive quick. Then we need to build multiple sets that are also transportable for tour. From there we will be spending hours upon hours mapping the sets, as well as the performers for a spectacular visual fusion of performer and projections. We honestly have not budgeted what the crew deserves hourly both performance and production sides, but we are trying to compensate a little of that. Not to mention our incredible artist who as I mentioned has designed the entire look and feel of the show, and will be creating a comic book based on our show. Everything you give will go into making this a mindblowing show, and directly to all the artists involved. For your donations we've got lots of rewards from tickets, to the comic book, lessons from the performers, or even us throwing you a big ole circus party!! Any and all help is greatly appreciated.

Why this show is important to us.

For the last 5 years Cirquedelic has created visceral experiences all over the Bay are. Including the wildly popular, Freaky Deeky circus party monthly. We labor daily to not only perfect our art, but imagine new and beautiful experiences for our audiences. This is something, to my knowledge, that has not been done. Taking the best in electronic music, combining it with musical theater, then adding circus performance, and state of the art projection mapping. We are pulling so many elements from the festival, and big event scenes and bringing it to a whole new group in, in a very unique way. Our hope is to immerse you into this unique reality somewhere between history, comic book, and party... all while giving you all manner of spectacle to sit back and enjoy.

The Tough Stuff

So obviously breaking new ground is scary and completely without assurance. Mixing a musical and glitch-hop alone is something many people have questioned. Throw in also creating a new aesthetic we're calling steameasy (a merging of steampunk and speakeasy fashion), and then attempting to tell a theatrical story with circus performers... we have a lot of curiosity, but also some doubt. This is a huge undertaking, and I at times have questioned my own sanity... but the second we got the first track and my dream had a soundtrack... I knew. So did an investor who heard it and immediately offered to cover our music production costs. I know the incredible level of talent I've brought together is going to produce an experience unlike any other, which is a staggering feat in the bay.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know many of you are struggling artists and friends who may not be able to help much, or at all financially. Please share this page, tell your friends, help us make this big ridiculous dream come true!

story:
What is The Cadaver Synod: A Pope Musical?

There are some moments in history that make you think... huh?  This is one of those moments.  And it's a musical now.

In the year 897 AD, Pope Stephen VII dug up the corpse of his predecessor, Pope Formosus, and put the rotting body on trial in front of the entire Roman clergy, senate, and aristocracy.  Literally dressed it up in its old Pope clothes, propped it up on a chair, and screamed accusations at the thing for hours while a whole host of onlookers nodded along.  The only person assigned to defend the dead body was a teenage deacon, a sputtering, naive academic facing a righteous onslaught from the most holy and famous man on Earth.

Ultimately, Stephen had the corpse declared guilty of... crimes, and the body was dismembered, disrobed, and thrown in the Tiber River.  If you think this is a spoiler, we assure you: there is so much more to it.

Why did Stephen do this?  What could drive a man to execute a cadaver posthumously?  And why, by all accounts, was he SO.  VERY.  ANGRY?  These are the questions this musical seeks to answer.  And our conclusions may not be what you expect.

After coming across this story in 2014, amateur bull rider and noted physicist Robbie Florian had visions of rock'n'roll popes, undulating bishops, and tap-dancing corpses dancing through his head (much akin to sugarplums 'round Christmastime).  He has spent three years writing the book, music, and lyrics for the show, and now it is receiving its WORLD PREMIERE with the New York Musical Festival, headed by our brilliant director RYAN EMMONS (Groundhog Day, Matilda, Ghost) and our outstanding music director DAN GARMON (The Bad Years, The Other Side of Paradise, dangarmon.com).  Together, they are creating a show unlike any other, combining a plethora of theatrical and musical genres into one ambitious, explosive happening.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to a goal of $45,000 to help us make this production as spectacular and mind-blowing as possible.  Your money will go toward:

A cast of 13 INCREDIBLE ACTORS (soon to be announced)

COSTUMES to prevent them from being naked

MICROPHONES so we can hear them speak, sing, and ululate

PROPS that they can manipulate with their limbs

A GNARLY POPE CORPSE to make various hairs stand on end

A 5-PIECE BAND including drums, guitar, bass, piano, and brass to shake the theatre with the power of papal punk, pop, doo-wop, and ska (among others)

A SET to transport you to the beat-down Rome of the 9th century

REHEARSAL SPACE, PUBLICITY, INSURANCE, RUNNING CREW, PHOTOGRAPHY...

AND MUCH MORE!

Your money will go a long way.  For example, a donation of $50 dollars pays for ALL OF OUR SCRIPTS.  A donation of $200 CLOTHES AN ENTIRE ACTOR head to toe.  $500 pays for the very crux of our show: THE POPE CORPSE.  $2,000 covers THE WHOLE SET.  $3,000 - THE WHOLE BAND.  $5,000 would mean our entire REHEARSAL PROCESS would be completely and totally paid for!!!

In addition, your contribution gives you access to a wide variety of perks that allow you to be an even greater part of the show.  Take a look to the right side of the page to see our many amazing perks, everything from a mention in the program, to a personalized thank you song from our entire cast, to free invites to our opening night party!  We want to make sure that you understand just how happy we are to have you be a part of our passion.

We have the versatility of experience (from Broadway regulars to festival veterans) and the utter willpower to make this show a unique theatrical experience for all.  Your investment will be utilized to the full extent of its value and beyond.  It is our goal to show you what your contribution can accomplish in the hands of determined and impassioned creators.

Why This Show?

Though the specifics of this strange historical event might seem shocking, we find a surprising amount of parallels between 897 and 2017.  Spectacle over substance, in political, social, and personal spheres, is nothing new, and has taken many shocking forms over the centuries.  The show does not seek to proselytize, teach, or scold.  We simply wish to explore innate tendencies toward control and categorization that end up conflicting with our unique ability to show altruism and empathy, and how a few individuals navigated these trappings while living in a famously corrupt and immoral time.

Also, there's a part where the dead pope's severed fingers come to life as a Ronettes/Supremes-type group and sing about flowers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share share share!  If you know anyone who might like to invest in new musical theatre, or contribute to young, ambitious artists, send this page along... help us get the word out there!  Friends, co-workers, parents, grandparents, children, obscure cousins - anyone!  This show is years in the making and we want to do everything we can to not only make sure our production is of the highest quality, but to also involve as many people as humanly possible in our vision.  We want everyone to know and care about the Cadaver Synod as much as we do, because this moment in history has a right to see life in the 21st century!

LET'S DO THIS.

story:
Serious theatergoers like you have made our small non-profit company a respected part of the New York theater community.

Our breakout production of “Waiting for Godot” (“Vartn Af Godot”) brought Yiddish theater to people who never dreamt of seeing a play in mame-loshn, as did our Drama Desk nominated “Death of a Salesman” (“Toyt Fun A Seylsman”). Most recently, audiences were mesmerized by our sold out productions of “God of Vengeance” (“Got Fun Nekome”).

This season we are producing four mainstage productions: Ionesco’s absurdist comedy, “Rhinoceros” (“Nozhorn”), Clifford Odets’ Depression-Era drama, “Awake and Sing!” (“Vakh Oyf un Zing!”), Perertz Hirschbein’s “Di Puste Kretchme” (“The Empty Inn”), and Israeli playwright Hanoch Levin’s wonderful one acts,“The Labor Of Life” and “The Whore From Ohio". Not since the heyday of Yiddish theater has a Yiddish  company offered four mainstage productions in one season.

Our vision for Yiddish theater is ambitious. But without flour we can’t bake bread. So this year I have pledged $100,000 in matching funds from individual donors. If you give $50, I give $50. If you give $500, I give $500. With a $200,000 budget, your gift and my match Please join me in supporting New Yiddish Rep with your tax-deductible contribution and make our 2017/2018 season unprecedented in recent Yiddish theater history.

No matter the amount, your gift will be instrumental in helping this one-of-a-kind company continue transforming Off-Broadway Yiddish theater in the 21st century.

Mit khavershaft
Ben Feldman
Board Chairman

A clip from the 2013 production of "Waiting For Godot," which went on to play at Beckett festivals  in Enniskillen, Northern Ireland in 2014, and Paris in 2016. Samuel Beckett's nephew Edward Beckett saw it at both festivals, and couldn't get over how natural the play sounded in Yiddish.

story:
I am so excited to launch KidzLA!

I have been a Teaching Artist and Arts Ed. Coordinator for over a decade, working with non-profits and schools, bringing performing arts to youth in California and New York City. I loved every minute of teaching for organizations like: Disney Theatrical Group, Theatre Development Fund, Marquis Studios, Creative Arts Team, S.T.A.R.R., Inc, Center Theatre Group, MALDEF’s CREATE –Civil Rights Education & Art Toward Empowerment, The Third Act! Foster Youth Services, and Barbizon. I have witnessed first-hand the power and impact of live arts in children’s self-confidence, team-building, and artistic expression.

And now, I am so grateful to finally launch the company I have been dreaming about for so long: KidzLA. I humbly ask for your support in bringing to life the pilot program, Musical Winter Camp –a 4-day afternoon camp where kids will rehearse and perform musical numbers from Broadway shows!

What We Need

The funding we receive from our IndieGoGo angels will go to:

  • Tuition Scholarships for low-income families
  • Rental of award-winning space Art Share LA in the Arts District of Downtown Los Angeles
  • Compensation for our Artist Instructors: Choreographer, Musical Director, Stage Manager & Vocal Coach
  • Healthy Snacks for 4 days of camp
  • Supplies for Art Direction, Fun props & Costumes for kids
  • Video documentation of program

Please share with your network and help us get one step closer to SHOWTIME!

story:
We are raising funds to stage four one-acts in midtown NYC in July 2017. We have already gotten performance rights and booked the theatre. This show is ON!

But we can always use help. We are raising funds for rehearsal space, event insurance, sound and light design, building and transportation of set pieces,  and various printing and admin costs that always, but always, arise. 

Every cent counts, and we will make it go really far.

We have a proven track record for productions that feature diverse actors and draw diverse audiences:

"Always Love Lucy (what a vivid name for a theatre company!) .... I found the current off-Broadway production of Salesman an intimate and effective rendition of Miller's profoundly important and tragic work." - Paul Hansen, Charged, June 27, 2014

"[I]deas like an Asian-American production of an American classic are absolutely workable.”...A new “Death of a Salesman” is running in a 99-seat theater through June 29 starring South Asian actors as the Loman family, including the show’s producer, Saima Huq, as the matriarch Linda. - Patrick Healy, New York Times, June 22, 2014

"[Regarding Out Cry, directed by Christopher Romero Wilson] The production marks an artistic milestone by featuring South Asian actors, in the lead roles of Felice and Claire Devoto, for the first time in New York City." - Stagebuddy

This will be our 4th production in three years. Hello to Rose follows:

Death of a Salesman (2014): Arthur Miller's 1949 Pulitzer Prize-winning play seen through the eyes of an Indian immigrant without changing any of the text or setting.  

Pygmalion (2016): George Bernard Shaw's 1913 classic tale of transformation took Eliza Dolittle from a Covent garden flower girl  to a high-class gentleman named Elijah at the ambassador's ball. 

Out Cry (The Two Character Play) (2016): Tennessee Williams' 1973 seldom-seen final work was featured at the Tamasha festival in Sept/Oct 2016. [video above]

story:
Archiving, Preserving & Restoring

Some years ago while living in my loft in Pilsen, I went to the upper loft to retrieve a tape of an Orchid Show, and what I found were ants: They had invaded and were feasting on all of my tapes. Stunned and not sure what to do, I put the tapes into the freezer to kill the ants, but then I just had cold tapes filled with dead ants. Heart broken, I finally threw them all away. Luckily, Peter Neville who documented most of the Milly shows from it’s beginning at Lounge Ax, made copies of most of the masters before he gave them to me. Some shows are lost forever, but many are still on tape. However, that tape is deteriorating quickly, some of them are well over 25 years old dating back to early 1988. It is, again, my great luck that Peter has become a web-God, and determined to save what we have left (and reduce his clutter), he proposed doing this Indiegogo campaign to archive what remains. I resisted the idea of asking for help, but he was patient, very patient. And then I realized that what has always made the Milly shows great is you, the audience. Performers say it to me over and over again, “You have the best audiences.” So it is fitting that we should do this together as we have always done, because without you, there is no show. Together we will ‘take what God gave us (and the ants haven’t eaten) put a couple a sequins on it’ and get ourselves an archive!  

Thank you for it all,

Brigid (aka Milly May Smithy) xoxo

What it would entail is:

  • Digitizing and archiving of the estimated 30-40 shows (or more). 
  • Restoring some of the poor quality of the older shows. 
  • Building a website to upload and link videos, photos and stories for your viewing pleasure.

 

How Will It Work?

Digitizing, logging and archiving all of these tapes will be very time consuming. Not to mention, restoring some. The entire project will take over two months, but it will be an ongoing project including additions and uploads of newer shows.  

We will have the entire available library of shows digitized and ready for viewing on the website. This would require purchasing domain, hosting, designing and layout of website including uploads and links. In addition, we also need to purchase multiple data storage devices including protective back-ups.

 

The Impact

Your generous donations will help this project become a reality. 

  • You will be able to view the shows at the website!
  • See performances you may have missed!
  • Enjoy hours of entertainment!
  • View slideshows of photos over the years!
You will get to see:

The first time Blue Man performed in Chicago — when it was just three blue guys igniting our imagination and covering the front rows in bananas and paint—who knew?! ;o)

You will also get to see  fabulous performers like:

  • John "Sinatra" Connors
  • David Sedaris
  • Eric Bogosian
  • Frank and Malachy McCourt
  • Lisa Kron
  • Syd Straw
  • Davis Cale
  • Jim Lauderdale
  • Poi Dog Pondering
  • Robert Kline & Karen Valentine
  • Nora Dunn
  • Matthew Owens
  • Paula Killen
  • Cheyl Trykv
  • Dennis DeBondt
  • Monk the Wandering Wizard 
  • PLUS! A variety of variety acts!

 and, of course, Consuelo Allen as Milly’s little spoon-danglin' bard-reciting sister, Willy May. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount that you contribute will help, but if you’d like to participate in another way,  you could send this campaign to your friend's and family, and help spread the word to other Milly fans. We would also love to see any video or photos you might have to add to the archives. There are still many shows that are missing, and you may have a piece of  Milly-history somewhere.

Don't forget to check back soon as the fun unfolds on the website launching! 

Now, give us a twirl, honey!  xoxo  -Milly

www.millysorchidshow.com

Some shows are lost forever, but many are still on tape. However, that tape is deteriorating quickly, some of them are well over 25 years old dating back to early 1988. It is, again, my great luck that Peter has become a web-God, and determined to save what we have left (and reduce his clutter), he proposed doing this Indiegogo campaign to archive what remains. I resisted the idea of asking for help, but he was patient, very patient. And then I realized that what has always made the Milly shows great is you, the audience. Performers say it to me over and over again, “You have the best audiences.” So it is fitting that we should do this together as we have always done, because without you, there is no show. Together we will ‘take what God gave us (and the ants haven’t eaten) put a couple a sequins on it’ and get ourselves an archive!  
Thank you for it all,
Brigid (aka Milly May Smithy) xoxo
What it would entail is:

Digitizing and archiving of the estimated 30-40 shows (or more). 
Restoring some of the poor quality of the older shows. 
Building a website to upload and link videos, photos and stories for your viewing pleasure.

 
How Will It Work?
Digitizing, logging and archiving all of these tapes will be very time consuming. Not to mention, restoring some. The entire project will take over two months, but it will be an ongoing project including additions and uploads of newer shows.  
We will have the entire available library of shows digitized and ready for viewing on the website. This would require purchasing domain, hosting, designing and layout of website including uploads and links. In addition, we also need to purchase multiple data storage devices including protective back-ups.
 
The Impact
Your generous donations will help this project become a reality. 

You will be able to view the shows at the website!
See performances you may have missed!
Enjoy hours of entertainment!
View slideshows of photos over the years!
You will get to see:The first time Blue Man performed in Chicago — when it was just three blue guys igniting our imagination and covering the front rows in bananas and paint—who knew?! ;o)
You will also get to see  fabulous performers like:

John "Sinatra" Connors
David Sedaris
Eric Bogosian
Frank and Malachy McCourt
Lisa Kron
Syd Straw
Davis Cale
Jim Lauderdale
Poi Dog Pondering
Robert Kline & Karen Valentine
Nora Dunn
Matthew Owens
Paula Killen
Cheyl Trykv
Dennis DeBondt
Monk the Wandering Wizard 
PLUS! A variety of variety acts!

 and, of course, Consuelo Allen as Milly’s little spoon-danglin' bard-reciting sister, Willy May. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Any amount that you contribute will help, but if you’d like to participate in another way,  you could send this campaign to your friend's and family, and help spread the word to other Milly fans. We would also love to see any video or photos you might have to add to the archives. There are still many shows that are missing, and you may have a piece of  Milly-history somewhere.
Don't forget to check back soon as the fun unfolds on the website launching! 
Now, give us a twirl, honey!  xoxo  -Milly
www.millysorchidshow.com

story:
About Seemia Theatre

Seemia Theatre is an ensemble of performers from different parts of the world; including Iran, Argentina and the UK. The company’s work combines both emotional and physical memory with expression of vocal improvisations, whilst working with ceremonial songs from different cultures. Seemia as a multicultural theatre company has the benefit of a dialogue between their own cultures and history, which is skilfully interpreted into the refugee stories that are being told.  This enriches the performance and can then connect with a wider range of people from all backgrounds. 

Why Seemia Theatre chose to tell stories of refugees

In society today over 60 million people worldwide stand forcefully displaced from their homes. In this current climate of mass migration, Seemia Theatre explores how the recent refugee crisis is told, outside of the mainstream media.

How is Seemia Theatre telling these stories

Seemia started their research conducting interviews and cultural exchanges with refugees. From the interviews they got a sense of people’s history, their journey, the problems they now face and what they have left behind.  This was to help them to understand the risk the refugees took and also their hopes and ambitions.

These interviews combined with individual history and memories of Seemia performers formed an understanding of the topic.  This then influenced ideas which the performers used to write texts and create dramatic relationships which led to making scenes.

Seemia's practice is very physical, and as such they are using physicality as a visual language to accompany the texts.  This is a method to create a story that may not necessarily be linear in narrative, but rather an emotional dramaturgical event that can connect to an audience despite language barriers.  They chose this way of working as they had a background in training together in this way with Song of the Goat theatre, and wanted to develop this technique further.

As part of their research Seemia have also collected folk and ceremonial songs. Song is a universal language which can enhance the performer’s ability to tell stories, along with physical language, to connect with an audience beyond text.

What We Need & What You Get

So far we have made several scenes which form 30 minutes of the performance.  We have done this solely from our own pockets and driven by our passion for the topic. In order to finish the work we need more rehearsal time and space which means we need funding. 

If you share our heart and compassion for the cause, care for theatre and/or liked the sample of our work that you see here, please help us make it happen.

Your contribution, however small or large, will play a big role in the destiny of our work in the coming year.

The fund that we are hoping to raise will go towards our rehearsal space, a venue for performance and will enable our performers to continue their work.

We need you to help us survive and thrive in theatre, to tell the stories that matter.

The Impact

We believe that although in theatre we are geographically limited, what we convey and communicate will travel far and wide.  We have made it our mission to portray and share stories of our time, like Evros; The Crossing River. 

Seemia’s ethos is we all share what it is to be human and can always connect on this level of empathy and understanding.

story:
About Us

The Second Breakfast Company (2BCo) is a not-for-profit youth theatre company, founded by youths, for youths. 

Earlier this year, we ran an open call for scripts. We had hoped to profile young writers and empower young voices with the platform to hold important conversations. When we came across the two plays, Lemmings and The Wedding Pig, we were struck by how real the stories were and how accurately reflective they were of the societal issues we face today that we wanted nothing more than to present these works to the world. 

However, with double the script, it is double the cost of presenting the works on stage. This, along with the limited arts funding available *and the sensitive nature of our play* has made the realities of staging the two plays a struggle for a youth theatre company such as ours.

These developments have placed us in a difficult situation where spending needs to be further-streamlined and selling tickets to schools and youths have to be put on hold in case the rating we eventually get disallows these young people from watching.

The team has taken these events in our stride. We've had to hence re-evaluate our strategies and find ways of raising the funds needed to cover basic costs. We know - there have been a few other crowdfunding campaigns going around. We understand. But we still believe that there will be kind people who are willing/able to help out. We strongly believe in the two plays, and we can only TRY to convince everyone else. As such, the campaign will carry on till slightly after the run of the show (2-5 November) so that if you need that push, you can purchase a ticket and watch the show and then donate. 

We are still learning and we can only give you the promise that (1) the show will be worth your time and ticket price, and (2) we will only do better next time.

At the same time, with your support we'll be able to keep doing what we do to empower youths in their creative pursuits and that we continue to provide a safe and comfortable space for youths to gather and exercise their talents and capabilities.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to support but broke like us (LOL), you could help by spreading the word ! Tell all your friends and family about this campaign or have them come watch our show. Tickets are available at www.sistic.com.sg/events/clemm1117  :) 

Truly, we really appreciate any form of love and support.

story:
We are Nozama Dance Collective, a modern dance company based in Cambridge, MA with the mission to portray the bold stories of female empowerment through dance. We call for women to come together, to support one another, as we claim our voices. We have heard enough, we have seen enough, we’ve had enough. Now is the time to embrace that we are enough. This is what drives “Enough”, the third full-length performance produced by Nozama Dance Collective.

Our pieces, along with the works of numerous guest artists, will depict the full spectrum of this concept, from the relentlessness of what women endure, to the celebration of what can be accomplished when we empower one another. We are honored to produce this performance, bringing the community together to celebrate female empowerment. Nozama Dance Collective has been dedicated to this mission for five years now, and we believe that now more than ever it is critical for empowered female voices to be heard through dance.

But we need your help. We are aiming to raise $2500 to cover production costs for “Enough”, including:

  • Theatre rental
  • Lighting by our incredible designer, Jeff Salzberg
  • Stage manager
  • Additional assistance backstage
  • Printing costs for our posters to get the word out about “Enough”
  • Rehearsal rental costs

We have set our donation goal to $2500, as this amount will fund the production and allow us to donate a portion of our ticket sales to the Big Sisters Association. In 2017, we partnered with the Big Sisters Association to teach dance workshops about girl power and positive body image to young girls ages 9-13. We are so lucky to share a partnership with the Big Sisters Association, as there are so many similarities in our mission statements. We are looking forward to being able to further give back to the organization. 

Even if you cannot contribute, we so appreciate your help in other ways! 

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about “Enough”!
  • Share our dance videos on YouTube and get the word out about Nozama fighting for female empowerment
  • Visit our Facebook page and ”Like” us!

Thank you so much for your generosity. With your help, we will further promote female empowerment in the Boston dance community, and give back to the Big Sisters Association, an organization with whom we are honored to partner with.

story:
Hello!

With your support, ESCAPE, a new play directed by Lynnsey Oooten and written by Deya Danielle Drake will make its world premiere October 2018 at the New York International Fringe Festival; the largest multi-arts festival in North America, celebrating indie theater, music and dance, with a twenty-one year history of introducing NYC audiences to bold new work and fresh voices.  

ESCAPE is a full length, five character (3W, 2M) play, with video.  It paints a timely picture of the temptation to pursue power, by any means necessary, and the human need to solidify our own relevance in a world that is changing quicker than we are. 

We believe that theater is an essential form of artistic expression.  One with the ability to capture and showcase, through live story, the often intangible zeitgeist of different eras.  It gives life to feelings and emotions, many universal, but difficult to articulate.  Experienced through the lens of performance, these feelings can be unifying and ignite discussion.

Some amazing people have already come on board to help bring this project to life.

Cast Rhonda Ayers (I Origins, Law and Order SVU, Boardwalk Empire) 

Casting Director Kimberly Graham (2012 Emmy and Artios Awards for Outstanding Casting for a Drama Series “Homeland”)

Assistant Director Malloree Hill (The Taming of the Shrew - Utah Shakespeare Festival, Iphigenia Among the Taurians - Everyday Inferno Theatre)

Sound Designer Jessica Hart

Stage Manager Dara Swisher

And many more TBA!!!

In addition to allowing us to pay these wonderful theater makers, your support will help cover essential costs of production: rehearsal space, video production, insurance, fees and contingency, marketing/PR materials, props, sets and costumes.  

Are you impressed with basic Excel skills?  Here's a colorful piechart to give you an idea of how it all breaks out.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may not be able to contribute $$. Your help would mean a lot in other ways: 

  • Come see the play at FringeNYC! Tickets on sale September 1st, 2018 at www.FringeNYC.org (but donate today and get one for free!), Performances  October 2018 in the West Village dates/timesTBA.
  • Tell your friends about ESCAPE and share our campaign.
  • "like" us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/EscapeatFringeNYC/

Thank you SO MUCH for your support (and for reading this far)!!!

--The ESCAPE Team

story:
We are the Butterfly Effect Circus Company. While our name may invoke the sense of ethereal, delicate creatures, it is specifically an allusion to a phenomenon in physics: one small action can multiply and create a tremendous effect further down the line. Although we come from small beginnings and humble materials, our goal is to create something singularly magnificent, both on and off the stage. 
 

To Create New Acts

A large basis for our show content are new, unique acts never seen before in the industry. The role of an artist is to create- yet when a physical artist steps outside the bounds, those endeavors are not rewarded. However, we want to take those unseen gems and showcase them as a part of our make. The above video is an example of the level of ingenuity we seek to place on the stage. 

 

To Rework the Presentation of the Stage

A traditional circus is one ring in the middle of a tent and a half moon audience surrounding it. We may very well be anything! One stage. Three Stages. Audience in the middle. Audience on top. Inside. Outside. Anything goes, as long as it shows! Our design concepts push boundaries and blow old ideas out of the water.

 

To Set a New Standard in the Circus Entertainment Industry

Life in the circus can be incredibly difficult, and there’s a long history of sexism, racism, and general elitism associated with it. It’s also well known that artists do not make a lot of money, as a general rule.  Our goal with our new company is to change that- to not only revamp employment standards from a circus standpoint, but to be revolutionary in the scope of any American corporation.

(Yes, we understand how incredibly idealistic that is- which is specifically why we strive for it!)

We have a tight timeline that we plan to follow; However, as developments occur we may need to expand and change our expectations. 

 

January/February 2021 - Funded and Concepts Complete

March/April 2021- Begin Developing Show - Logistics

April/May 2021- Begin Developing Show - Artistic

June/July 2021- Seed Show Premiere! Las Vegas

2021/2022- Two Options: Begin Planning National Tour / Host at Casino

Our first show concept is an ode to our name and spirit: Vivarium; an enchanted, ethereal garden that breathes life into the souls of those that enter it. It is a vision saturated with beautiful green and blue leaves, bright pops of colorful flowers, and the flow and presence of majestic and mysterious animals of the tropic sphere- all encased in prismatic glass and scattered light.

 

We are currently developing a new musical score for the show that echoes the spirit of the concept, and working with several costume designers to create spectacular pieces for our artists. Our lighting design is also crucial to create the enveloping nature of glass and leaves.

In response to the Pandemic, we are strong advocates of safety, hygiene and good health. It is important to follow strict federal regulations and guidelines. We therefore plan to model our show and logistics with these notions in mind. Our plan includes:

An open-air performance space

Masked costumes

Filtered ventilation when possible/necessary

Although it will be difficult, we believe this is the best time to establish a brand new company. Like saplings out of the ashes, this is a perfect time for small companies to gather their bearings and to unsaturate the entertainment market.

Without overhead damage to deal with and armed with foresight, we can navigate the market with advantages that larger established companies simply do not have.

As a new company, we will be able to contribute to the re-establishment of the economy. We will be giving back to small companies and struggling artists, and creating boundless employment opportunities.

1. We are a brand new company. There is a chance we could fail, especially with the current economic and social climate. However, we are establishing a well rounded, experienced and intuitive team to try and circumvent any challenges associated with establishment.

2. Circus is dangerous! People regularly get hurt, and quite often fatally. There is always a high level of danger associated with what we are doing. However, our artists are experienced in their specialty, and we will always be insured.

3. We may not be able to outmaneuver Covid-19, despite our best efforts. However, with our timeline we do expect to surpass the time of danger and begin our real growth after we prevail against the virus.

story:
Temple of Dance is not your typical dance studio-- it is exclusively, and inclusively(!) for adults, ages 18+.  We will be offering a wide variety of dance fitness and dance instruction classes for all ability levels, beginner to pro.
 

I'm Carrie. I'm a dancer, dance instructor, and choreographer in the Tulsa area.  I'm also mom to my 7-year-old son. And I know all about the struggles of being an adult who wants to dance.

The thing is when you become an adult, your options to learn dance greatly diminish.  Most traditional studios are for children ages 3-18.  There is currently no studio in the Tulsa area that offers adults, of all ability levels, the opportunity to learn hip-hop, jazz, modern, ballet, and other styles all under one roof.  And there is no dedicated studio for dance fitness classes and training programs.

At Temple of Dance, the focus is on the adult dancer.  We'll be offering many classes for beginners just starting out. And for more experienced dancers, there will be a wide variety of classes to further hone their skills.  We will also be offering homegrown dance fitness classes 5 days a week-- No Zumba! I'm talking about programs people created right here in Tulsa, Oklahoma!

Such as Shake It Off created by Tulsa's own Joshua Forbes!

There are two things I know and love: dance and small, local business.  I have been a student of dance most all my life, and an assistant, teacher, and coach for 17 years. I have managed many a small business, yoga and dance studio.  And I have an awesome, wide, established network of instructors and choreographers, many of whom are already on board to teach at Temple of Dance.

I have an undying passion for dance and offering this space to my community.  But I need your help to make it happen! I am asking *you*, friends, family, colleagues, and believers to help me secure the initial funding to open this studio in Tulsa.  With your help, I can put down the security deposit and first month's rent to get Temple of Dance up and running!  The studio I have picked out is ready to go, minus sound systems and some furniture.  So your donations will go directly towards getting into the studio to be able to start offering classes as soon as possible.

I'm asking for your community support and donations of all shapes and sizes to bring this to life. 


AND there's rewards!  You can pay it forward towards classes at the dance studio, you can get some Temple of Dance swag, or you can even get a personal thank you dance video from yours truly. 

Thank you all from the bottom to the top of my heart for your support!!!

And please share, share, share!

(See FAQ for more details)
story_txt:
Temple of Dance is not your typical dance studio-- it is exclusively, and inclusively(!) for adults, ages 18+.  We will be offering a wide variety of dance fitness and dance instruction classes for all ability levels, beginner to pro. 
I'm Carrie. I'm a dancer, dance instructor, and choreographer in the Tulsa area.  I'm also mom to my 7-year-old son. And I know all about the struggles of being an adult who wants to dance.
The thing is when you become an adult, your options to learn dance greatly diminish.  Most traditional studios are for children ages 3-18.  There is currently no studio in the Tulsa area that offers adults, of all ability levels, the opportunity to learn hip-hop, jazz, modern, ballet, and other styles all under one roof.  And there is no dedicated studio for dance fitness classes and training programs.
At Temple of Dance, the focus is on the adult dancer.  We'll be offering many classes for beginners just starting out. And for more experienced dancers, there will be a wide variety of classes to further hone their skills.  We will also be offering homegrown dance fitness classes 5 days a week-- No Zumba! I'm talking about programs people created right here in Tulsa, Oklahoma!

Such as Shake It Off created by Tulsa's own Joshua Forbes!
There are two things I know and love: dance and small, local business.  I have been a student of dance most all my life, and an assistant, teacher, and coach for 17 years. I have managed many a small business, yoga and dance studio.  And I have an awesome, wide, established network of instructors and choreographers, many of whom are already on board to teach at Temple of Dance.
I have an undying passion for dance and offering this space to my community.  But I need your help to make it happen! I am asking *you*, friends, family, colleagues, and believers to help me secure the initial funding to open this studio in Tulsa.  With your help, I can put down the security deposit and first month's rent to get Temple of Dance up and running!  The studio I have picked out is ready to go, minus sound systems and some furniture.  So your donations will go directly towards getting into the studio to be able to start offering classes as soon as possible.
I'm asking for your community support and donations of all shapes and sizes to bring this to life. 

AND there's rewards!  You can pay it forward towards classes at the dance studio, you can get some Temple of Dance swag, or you can even get a personal thank you dance video from yours truly. 
Thank you all from the bottom to the top of my heart for your support!!!
And please share, share, share!(See FAQ for more details)

story:
Who we are?

CBC "Christine Bonansea Company" is a contemporary dance company formed by Christine Bonansea, who is an US-European dancer and choreographer with 20 years of international experience in conceiving, directing/choreographing and performing movement-based works.  

 

"Vogel" : The Streaming Performance Project

Project Overview

Vögel is a new choreographic women solo series choreographed by Christine Bonansea. 

The space is set up as a container, an emotional space that questions our sensitive and social relationship to the world. Our perception of the self is dramatically reflected when the condition of isolation provokes a radical attempt for escape. The work is inspired by the philosophical essay: “LE CORPS UTOPIQUE” from Michel Foucault.

"We are trapped in our body restrained by the large space with a dimensionality that emphasizes our limitations, a “pitiless place”. However the body might be also a unique space where the perception and creativity has the potential to develop: ‘the body incomprehensible, penetrable, opaque, open and closed, the utopian body’. The body is visible, for example, through others and through looking in a mirror, but also strangely invisible, thoroughly traversed with excitement and desires and, for Foucault, the origin and model of our utopian imagination.”

The body is actually ‘always elsewhere’, a placeless site that is forever travelling through, and to, different spaces, with the tremendous power to imagine and realise utopias."

The series demonstrates the various qualities of each interpreter despite the systematic dramatic outcome. The space revealed by the cut of lights and the sound density installation will emphasize the scale and extreme tension where the body is trapped. The scenic elements combined are chosen to increase the dimension of the tragedy, showing the incap acity to escape our human condition.

The Story: Where we want to achieve?

 

We are trapped in our body restrained by the large space with a dimensionality that emphasizes our limitations, a “pitiless place”. However the body might be also a unique space where the perception and creativity has the potential to develop: ‘the body incomprehensible, penetrable, opaque, open and closed, the utopian body’. The body is visible, for example, through others and through looking in a mirror, but also strangely invisible, thoroughly traversed with excitement and desires and, for Foucault, the origin and model of our utopian imagination.”The contrast in between the body and its environnement evokes an emotional tension, questioning our sensitive and social relationship to the world. Our perception of the self is dramatically reflected when the condition of isolation provokes a radical attempt for escape. The work is inspired by the philosophical essay: “LE CORPS UTOPIQUE” from Michel Foucault. 

 

The body is actually ‘always elsewhere’, a placeless site that is forever travelling through, and to, different spaces, with the tremendous power to imagine and realise utopias.

The series demonstrates the unique qualities of the dancer interpreter within the systematic dramatic outcome for each piece. The scenic elements are chosen to increase the dimension of the tragedy using light frequencies and sound installation that increase the pressure and the weight of the space over the body.

The Collaboration:

Vögel is in collaboration with a multimedia collaborative team featuring visual projection and electronic composition that emphasize the time space dimensionality:

 

  • Dancers : Yeri Anarika, Laura Cornejo, Yuri Shimaoka, Christine Bonansea​

 

  • Film Director:  Carlos Vasques
  • Visual Design: Lucas Kuzma https://verdant.systems/copy%20error/points/
  • Sound Compositions: 

       ​Jorge Bachmann https://soundcloud.com/ruidobello/hydra101010

       Byungseo Yoo https://www.zku-berlin.org/people/byungseo-yoo-3/

  • Light and Projection Mapping : Shaly Lopez
  • Photo: Gaia Squarci 
  • Streaming Video : Walter Bickmann 
  • Production: CBC  : Christine Bonansea Company : Tomoya Kawamura

Supported

by: NPN-STEPPING OUT JOINT ADVENTURES // NATIONALES PERFORMANCE NETZ

story:
My name is Sheane T. Kirksey I am the founder and Director of Star Struck Divaz Dance Company, LLC,  I currently own 51 percent of the company,  I like to think of myself as self made motivated entrepreneur small minority business owner, who was raised in Midwest St. Louis MO.  As a young adult I became obsessed with being physically fit and active. Over the years I turned that obsession of being physically fit into a healthy hobby and then I turned that healthy hobby into a mental passion which in turn I built into a small business, my dance company/studio to share my health journey with others . 

This campaign will help me to seek greatly needed funds, to relocate this company to a larger studio location that I'm sure will need some repairs to bring the new building up to state code and customer satisfaction. My campaign is so important to me because it will allow the company the  growth opportunities it needs to move forward with business clientele and its annual revenue. Overall I am applying for this $5000.00 loan to help provide working capital expense of running the  dance company sufficiently once we have made the move. 

The funds provided by the contributors would help tremendously, by allowing the company the cash flow on hand needed to launch and reopen the larger and better location.  This company move would allow a much wider target market, allowing more client based business along with increased revenue weekly, monthly and annual.  The funds secured by the contributors would certainly be a great impact on Star Struck Divaz day to day over all business success.

What the company needs is the maximum loan amount of $5000.00 is requested on behalf of Star Struck Divaz Dance Company,LLC to help obtain our goal in moving forward with our dance art vision by securing this loan to help relocate our dance team to a into a bigger and better location, we are a local competitive dance team that practices in a shared and rented space six days a week. The loan would provide secure funding for the deposit on a new location and some minor move in repairs, purchases of licenses and permit. The move would generate a more profitable income  for the company.  Drive the annual revenue up by large percentages, projecting to up to and around 30K-50K, this change this would definitely be a great benefit to Star Struck Divaz Dance Company, Llc. 

Star Struck Divaz Dance Co. is unique in a lot of ways, one we are a family oriented studio, here we offer one on one mentoring to our youths. We offer competitive cost sufficient services, selective uniforms styles are included with monthly tuition (youths dance team), offer family discounts and client pick up and drop off services with in the studios traveling miles radius.  

If we are not able to reach or meet our entire goal, whatever funds are collected would still be of great assistance to the company.  We would still need to purchase uniform inventory and  some much needed exercise equipment, new marketing strategies will be implemented. Also the funds would help secure the team competitions and travel fees throughout the competitive dance seasons.

This campaign is just what the company needs to move forward in its next business phase,  to everyone who will contribute to our cause know that you too will be helping Star Struck Divaz Dance Company make a major difference by offering our  low cost diverse health and fitness services to single parents, low income families, minorities, youths and adults in our communities.  In turn this will help create and promote a healthier and happy lifestyle for our clients. 

The companies project is valuable to my clients, contributors and the world because the services we provide to help maintain and focuses on everyday  physical fitness, health & mental awareness among youths and adults in diverse communities. 

The biggest challenge in this business is client retention, the turn over rate is actually kind of high, although I (we) love what I (we) do, it's really hard work spending many training hours with new youths & adult clients. The future goal for the business is to one day actually have multiple studios locations in different states that provides services to minorities in urban communities. I am mostly proud that my business has succumb the start up phase and is ready to move forward in building more capital and revenue along with the fact that Star Struck Divaz Dance Co. allows each individual to gain more confidence, self esteem along with a healthy and positive environment, each time they walk through those studio doors.

I have created Star Struck Divaz from the ground up. Star Stuck Divaz Dance Co, even has a great social media following causing a social impact on three audience crowds, minority youths who is fond of the art of dance and would love to further their craft in it and adults/parents/ supporters all also follow our social media platform, mostly the objective is to keep the audience engaged and entertained, many social media platforms has gained me a high percentage of clients, fans and supporters in the Dance Art World. This social tactic continuously allows the company to gain business the near future to come.

Now, who will help me help the youths and adults of the communities fit and health, will it be you?  Remember there are a many different ways to help out and support. So please be sure to share our story to others to help make this campaign dream to become true and most of all successful. 

The companies project is valuable to my clients, contributors and the world because the services we provide to help maintain and focuses on everydays  physical fitness, health & mental awareness amongst youths and adults in diverse communities. 

The biggest challenge in this business is retention, the turn over rate is actually kind of high, although I (we) love what I (we) do, it's really hard work spending many training hours with new youths & adult clients. The future goal for the business is to one day actually have multiple studios locations in different states that provides services to minorities in urban communities. I am mostly proud that my business has succumb the start up phase and is ready to move forward in building more capital and revenue along with the fact that Star Struck Divaz Dance Co. allows each individual to gain more confidence, self esteem along with a healthy and positive environment, each time they walk through those studio doors.

story:
Who We Are

Founded in 1993, Mammalian Diving Reflex creates site and social-specific theatre and performance, forming deep participatory collaborations with many different communities. We have developed a unique and inventive way of making social practice art, which has helped redefine theatre and performance, expanding the definition to include rigorous community engagement. 

We have created work in 27 counties and 80 cities around the world.

Our youth wing, the Young Mammals, is a world-leading model of engagement which has expanded to Germany, London and Milan. Starting with a diverse group of youth from Parkdale, Toronto, The Young Mammals have been collaborating artistically with us since 2006 when they were 10 years old, with the mandate to diversify the arts industry. For over a decade, they have gained access to professional development and creative opportunities embedded directly within the company at home and on tour. Now 24-years-old, they continue to work with the company in leadership positions.

Articulating the methods of long-term engagement and taught at universities around the world, Artistic Director, Darren O’Donnell has written two books about the company’s methodologies: Social Acupuncture (2006) and Haircuts by Children and Other Evidence for a New Social Contract (2018). 

 

What is F2F-IRL?

Created in response to the social isolation brought on by COVID-19, Face-to-Face In-Real-Life (“F2F-IRL”) is an Artist-in-Residence program that continues Mammalian’s intention to diversify the arts through tailor-made mentorship in social-practice performance focusing on long-term and high impact engagement in Toronto.

Our goal is:
To build professional development resources for emerging artists and create a diverse locally connected community using socially-engaged performance and its rapidly growing practices through in-person public facing events & mentorship.

F2F-IRL will run for ten months annually, engaging Toronto-based artists/companies developing projects that work in collaboration with marginalized communities, (ie. age, class, ethnicity, in/abilities, etc). Mammalian will prioritizes a diverse team of artists for the residency via an open call.  

Tapping into what we have learned through our extensive international touring and the Young Mammals’ long-term engagement strategy, we will share knowledge, methodologies, networks, and opportunities with these artists - yielding high-impact results and relationships, unique to the Toronto landscape. 

We will also connect with local presenters to co-curate and facilitate artist talks with local and visiting artists. In tandem with these talks, we also plan to host three international artist masterclasses with each artist’s masterclass focusing on different aspects and methodologies of social practice and immersive performance. 

We recently completed an F2F-IRL prototype featuring five Toronto artists that were developing projects with our artistic support. Their projects engaged communities of: the visually impaired, people with dementia, asian diaspora, immobile elderly, and gamers. 
 

What We Want to Achieve

F2F-IRL offers professional development opportunities for artists engaging with diverse communities with a public community-building event in Toronto. 

The intended outcomes are:

  • To increase connectivity, knowledge sharing, and resource distribution within the socially-engaged performance art and theatre sector.
  • To use socially-engaged practice to highlight engagement with diverse and marginalized communities in Toronto.
  • To strengthen Toronto’s cultural identity by developing a wider community, deepening a sense of belonging as well as amplifying the voices of new and emerging artists of varied backgrounds both nationally and internationally. 
  • To diversify the arts industry.
     

The Breakdown

Your Donation Supports

The total cost of F2F-IRL will come to a little over $70,000. This isn’t a small chunk of change. Grants have given us a leg up to meet this goal, although they do not come close to covering the entire cost of the initiative. Even though our campaign goal is set at $5,000, any amount of support we receive in excess of this goal will go a very long way in helping us cover the full-cost of this initiative.

The fully funded model of F2F-IRL will have the following elements:

  • Social Practice Intensive: The launch of F2F-IRL will feature a week long public intensive covering the social practice topics of ethics, methodologies, research, and form. 
  • 10 study group sessions: Once a month, with Mammalian, the artists give peer-to-peer feedback and constructively critique each others’ projects from seed idea to performable work.  
  • 10 one-on-one feedback meetings: Mammalian provides dramaturgical feedback to each project individually as they develop.
  • Production support: The F2F-IRL Producer provides logistical production mentorship (grant writing support, budgeting, scheduling, creating artistic contracts, etc.) for each project. 
  • Public presentation showcase to industry peers: Closing the residency, Mammalian will invite high-level industry professionals, offering the artists a platform to pitch to future collaborators. 
  • 4 Local Artist Talks: Connecting with local presenters, we will ask them to co-curate artist talks by visiting or local artists, focusing on their inspirations and research methodologies. 
  • 3 International Artist Masterclasses: Mammalian will host three international artists throughout F2F-IRL, with each artist’s masterclass focusing on different aspects and methodologies of social practice and immersive performance. These masterclasses will be open to the general public for a small fee. 

The above consists of costs such as artist fees, venue rental, equipment rental, marketing, hospitality, travel costs and the producer’s wage, which when totalled, is a substantial investment in the future of the Toronto performing arts industry. 

Should we not be able to obtain the funding necessary to afford all of these elements, we will unfortunately face the need to postpone the International Artist Masterclasses and trim down the artist fees for the F2F-IRL artists. 

 

Psst...quid pro quo?

We’ve partnered with a collection of visual artists to create unique, limited edition gifts of appreciation for your generous donations. Who doesn’t love a quid pro quo? 

Our Artistic Director, Darren O’Donnell, reached out to Montreal-based artist, Matt Evans, with an idea. He wanted to advocate Facebook to include stickers of Mark Zuckerberg testifying in the U.S Congress. And thus, Mark Stickerberg was born. We have created one-of-a-kind (no fact-checking required) Stickerberg mugs and tote bags to stick it to the social media mogul. Get yours today!

We are working with Young Mammal and embroider-extraordinaire, Kathy Vuu, to create gorgeous, hand-embroidered Mammalian socks. 

COVID-19 sucks, but at least the fashion mask business is through the roof! Kathy will be working with Teodula, the mother of another Young Mammal, Isabel Ahat, to hand-make and hand-embroider Mammalian masks, suitable for all socially-distanced occasions!  

Finally, we are very excited to offer the opportunity for exclusive access to the F2F-IRL sessions and also VIP invitations to the premiere of our new development work, The Last Minutes Before Mars, wherever it the world it is taking place.

 

The Risks

The most obvious risk we are currently facing for this project is the unpredictable nature of COVID-19 and it’s drastic impact on the performing arts industry throughout the world. As we are a company that specializes in international touring, our finger has been on the industry’s pulse for the majority of 2020 and we feel confident in our ability to adapt in this ever-changing environment. Should social distancing’s restrictions return in full-force, we have created a digital contingency plan to postpone and reassess the program’s structure so that it is able to be implemented regardless of COVID’s impact. 

 

Help us help Emerging Artists

Getting the word out about this campaign is half the battle. 

If you hope to strengthen Toronto’s cultural and community capital, please share this campaign with your networks so that we can succeed in bringing people Face-to-Face In-Real-Life. 

Thank you in advance for your time and support.
