For over a decade, they have gained access to professional development and creative opportunities embedded directly within the company at home and on tour. Now 24-years-old, they continue to work with the company in leadership positions.
Articulating the methods of long-term engagement and taught at universities around the world, Artistic Director, Darren O’Donnell has written two books about the company’s methodologies: Social Acupuncture (2006) and Haircuts by Children and Other Evidence for a New Social Contract (2018). 
 

What is F2F-IRL?
Created in response to the social isolation brought on by COVID-19, Face-to-Face In-Real-Life (“F2F-IRL”) is an Artist-in-Residence program that continues Mammalian’s intention to diversify the arts through tailor-made mentorship in social-practice performance focusing on long-term and high impact engagement in Toronto.
Our goal is:To build professional development resources for emerging artists and create a diverse locally connected community using socially-engaged performance and its rapidly growing practices through in-person public facing events & mentorship.
F2F-IRL will run for ten months annually, engaging Toronto-based artists/companies developing projects that work in collaboration with marginalized communities, (ie. age, class, ethnicity, in/abilities, etc). Mammalian will prioritizes a diverse team of artists for the residency via an open call.  
Tapping into what we have learned through our extensive international touring and the Young Mammals’ long-term engagement strategy, we will share knowledge, methodologies, networks, and opportunities with these artists - yielding high-impact results and relationships, unique to the Toronto landscape. 
We will also connect with local presenters to co-curate and facilitate artist talks with local and visiting artists. In tandem with these talks, we also plan to host three international artist masterclasses with each artist’s masterclass focusing on different aspects and methodologies of social practice and immersive performance. 
We recently completed an F2F-IRL prototype featuring five Toronto artists that were developing projects with our artistic support. Their projects engaged communities of: the visually impaired, people with dementia, asian diaspora, immobile elderly, and gamers.  

What We Want to Achieve
F2F-IRL offers professional development opportunities for artists engaging with diverse communities with a public community-building event in Toronto. 
The intended outcomes are:


To increase connectivity, knowledge sharing, and resource distribution within the socially-engaged performance art and theatre sector.

To use socially-engaged practice to highlight engagement with diverse and marginalized communities in Toronto.

To strengthen Toronto’s cultural identity by developing a wider community, deepening a sense of belonging as well as amplifying the voices of new and emerging artists of varied backgrounds both nationally and internationally. 

To diversify the arts industry. 


The Breakdown
Your Donation Supports
The total cost of F2F-IRL will come to a little over $70,000. This isn’t a small chunk of change. Grants have given us a leg up to meet this goal, although they do not come close to covering the entire cost of the initiative. Even though our campaign goal is set at $5,000, any amount of support we receive in excess of this goal will go a very long way in helping us cover the full-cost of this initiative.
The fully funded model of F2F-IRL will have the following elements:

Social Practice Intensive: The launch of F2F-IRL will feature a week long public intensive covering the social practice topics of ethics, methodologies, research, and form. 
10 study group sessions: Once a month, with Mammalian, the artists give peer-to-peer feedback and constructively critique each others’ projects from seed idea to performable work.  
10 one-on-one feedback meetings: Mammalian provides dramaturgical feedback to each project individually as they develop.
Production support: The F2F-IRL Producer provides logistical production mentorship (grant writing support, budgeting, scheduling, creating artistic contracts, etc.) for each project. 
Public presentation showcase to industry peers: Closing the residency, Mammalian will invite high-level industry professionals, offering the artists a platform to pitch to future collaborators. 
4 Local Artist Talks: Connecting with local presenters, we will ask them to co-curate artist talks by visiting or local artists, focusing on their inspirations and research methodologies. 
3 International Artist Masterclasses: Mammalian will host three international artists throughout F2F-IRL, with each artist’s masterclass focusing on different aspects and methodologies of social practice and immersive performance. These masterclasses will be open to the general public for a small fee. 

The above consists of costs such as artist fees, venue rental, equipment rental, marketing, hospitality, travel costs and the producer’s wage, which when totalled, is a substantial investment in the future of the Toronto performing arts industry. 
Should we not be able to obtain the funding necessary to afford all of these elements, we will unfortunately face the need to postpone the International Artist Masterclasses and trim down the artist fees for the F2F-IRL artists. 
 

Psst...quid pro quo?
We’ve partnered with a collection of visual artists to create unique, limited edition gifts of appreciation for your generous donations. Who doesn’t love a quid pro quo? 
Our Artistic Director, Darren O’Donnell, reached out to Montreal-based artist, Matt Evans, with an idea. He wanted to advocate Facebook to include stickers of Mark Zuckerberg testifying in the U.S Congress. And thus, Mark Stickerberg was born. We have created one-of-a-kind (no fact-checking required) Stickerberg mugs and tote bags to stick it to the social media mogul. Get yours today!
We are working with Young Mammal and embroider-extraordinaire, Kathy Vuu, to create gorgeous, hand-embroidered Mammalian socks. 
COVID-19 sucks, but at least the fashion mask business is through the roof! Kathy will be working with Teodula, the mother of another Young Mammal, Isabel Ahat, to hand-make and hand-embroider Mammalian masks, suitable for all socially-distanced occasions!  
Finally, we are very excited to offer the opportunity for exclusive access to the F2F-IRL sessions and also VIP invitations to the premiere of our new development work, The Last Minutes Before Mars, wherever it the world it is taking place.
 
The Risks
The most obvious risk we are currently facing for this project is the unpredictable nature of COVID-19 and it’s drastic impact on the performing arts industry throughout the world. As we are a company that specializes in international touring, our finger has been on the industry’s pulse for the majority of 2020 and we feel confident in our ability to adapt in this ever-changing environment. Should social distancing’s restrictions return in full-force, we have created a digital contingency plan to postpone and reassess the program’s structure so that it is able to be implemented regardless of COVID’s impact. 
 
Help us help Emerging Artists
Getting the word out about this campaign is half the battle. 
If you hope to strengthen Toronto’s cultural and community capital, please share this campaign with your networks so that we can succeed in bringing people Face-to-Face In-Real-Life. 
Thank you in advance for your time and support.

story:
We are a diverse group of theatre-makers in New York City. Our teams’ resumes comprise of TV/film, professional dancers, Off-Broadway, choreographers, producers, international theatre tours, published writers, & numerous awards within the arts sector. To learn more about our ensemble members, please visit our WEBSITE.​

The Company

Bret Bailey | Cara Cifferelli | Khari Constantine | Genevieve Coovrey

Alida Rose Delaney | Matthew Gasda | Sarah Means | Melissa Rae Nelson

Callan Shattuck | Gayle Staffanson | Natasha Walfall | Jonathan Wilde

Phrenes was founded in early 2018, becoming the first official democratic theatre cooperative in New York City. We are comprised of interdisciplinary artists who use art as a tool for self-knowledge.

We are a unique company of creatives exploring the depths of individuals through a democratic system, where all ideas are encouraged & honed by The Company. We conceive of new works & the reimagining of classic texts for audiences as well as educational purposes.

Our previous rapport as phrends & co-artists have led us to a place of establishing this cooperative in the unconventional.

Phre~nes - a word of Greek origin which roughly translates to “the organ of breath” & designates the physical localization of thumos (heart/spirit).

*DISCLAIMER: All proceeds are going towards production costs for the 2019 season. PHRENES & it's members are not profiting from this campaign. 

Compared to most performing arts institutions in New York, our 2019 season is considered "ultra-low budget." We are launching our IndieGoGo campaign to procure financing from those that we believe will support our vision. 

A major challenge associated with producing indie-theatre is obtaining affordable rehearsal & performance space. New York rentals range anywhere from $2,000 for a week-long run. All of us at Phrenes are tapping into our personal networks to secure the best for our buck– without sacrificing the performance value. 

All (big or small) contributions towards raising $10,000 will enable "Messages," "Lotus," & "Measure for Measure" to reach their full creative potential. 

Phrenes is committed to sharing diverse stories, in collaborative mediums, & in unconventional settings. We are confident that with your help, we can make it happen.

  1. VOLUNTEER to help work front of house, run our ticket booth, or lend us a hand on site during our performances.
  2. HOST a small salon to help fundraise for our season.
  3. SPONSOR an event or our performance bar.
  4. SPREAD the word about the campaign to those who love grass-root art organizations!
  5. FOLLOW us on our Facebook and Instagram.

  • EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH - within NYC public schools, as well as weekend workshops led by members of Phrenes in writing, producing, & performance.
  • FOSTER NEW WORK - extend our olive branch by encouraging space for different voices to be heard by up-and-coming creators.
  • EXPAND OUR PHAMILY - continue to build our company & community to include more interdisciplinary artists, & those within arts administration.
  • FESTIVALS - get our mission & cooperative out there, by partaking in local Fringe & International theatre festivals.

story:
Hi, I'm Nina Chhibber Williams!

I'm a South Asian/American writer and comedian taking my soloshow to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival this year! The Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world and takes place every August for three weeks in Edinburgh, Scotland’s capital city.

"Om Shaadi Om" is my deeply personal story, yet the themes of clashing cultures, family tensions, and awkward first dates are universally true for many.  Additionally, I am thrilled for the opportunity to elevate South Asian representation at the Fringe.  Your partnership will allow me to pursue this incredible "Bucket List" opportunity, and I am so grateful for your support.

"Om Shaadi Om" originated from the Solocom Festival at the People's Improv Theater in NYC, and has been performed to the delight of many in NYC since!

How You Can Help

Your contribution means that you've joined me as a producer of my show.  Hey, look at you!  You're a producer!  Sounds pretty cool, right?  Here's what I need help with:

  • Venue and Tech Costs: I'm performing at Greenside Venues, one of the top-rated venues at the Fringe!  Help me cover festival registration fees, insurance, and technical support so we can ensure the theatre thrives for many Fringe Festivals to come!
  • Marketing Materials: I've worked hard on this show and I want to spread the word across the sea!
  • Accommodation and Living Costs: Scotland is a rainy place, and I am grateful for a roof over my head for the month!

Learn More About the Show!

Follow my adventures and spread the word on Instagram, Facebook, and Twitter!

See "Om Shaadi Om" in NYC!  Click here for info!

Visit me and see "Om Shaadi Om" in Edinburgh at Greenside Venues Aug 2-10!

story:
Our 50th Season is Approaching and We Need Your Help

We Will Think You Are Amazing if You Show Your Support!!!

The Summer Place, is a not-for-profit 501(c)(3) organization, has been Naperville's Community Theater since 1966 and has launched over 100 awesome productions. Our mission was and is to provide a vehicle for the community to participate and enjoy quality theater. In continuous operation all these years, Summer Place Theatre has performed in canvas tents, tinroof structures, and outdoor pavilions.  

Since 1993, an agreement has allowed us to perform at an area high school, in a 700+ seat Auditorium, where we stage our major productions.

Ticket prices are kept low by our board of directors as part of our philosophy of keeping the enjoyment of theater within reach of all our community. For the rest of our expenses, we rely on the generosity of our patrons and sponsors.

Our financial reserves were depleted a few years ago when we had to pay exorbitant rent during renovation of our home base.   We hope that we can augment our revenue sources by receiving funds to offset our operational expenses.  Our seasonal fundraising goal is $20,000 - we are sponsoring many fundraising efforts through 2015 - and we are looking to your amazing generosity with this endeavor!!

How You Can Help

As rising costs continue to affect our organization, our needs are greater!  The 2015 season is bound for greatness:  "Spamalot," "Camelot," and "William Shakespeare's Land of the Dead."

Your money will go towards: 

  • Costumes 
  • Props (a case of coconuts.. some crowns.. some zombies..)
  • Musicians for our live orchestra
  • Designers, Directors, and all those magically talented people
  • Technical Team (yay crew members)
  • Set Design and Construction (let's not forget about the killer rabbit)
  • Press material (posters, logo designs and postcards)
So what will you get in return for your support?

  • Our endless gratitude, friendship and air kisses
  • Some amazing perks listed over THERE ---->
  • All of your donations are tax deductible to the extent of the law. 

Thank you. Thank you. THANK YOU! 

Please know how much our company means to us and to the community.  Our 50 years have had ups and downs - and we have poured our blood, sweat, and love into The Summer Place Theatre. 

We appreciate the smallest to the biggest donation and we truly appreciate your wonderful support.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone has extra funds... but we would really appreciate your sharing this with people and help us get out the word!   Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Help send Kultar's Mime to the 2015 PARLIAMENT OF THE WORLD'S RELIGIONS

Over the past year, thousands from all over the world have watched KULTAR'S MIME, a documentary play about the quest for justice in the aftermath of two deadly massacres: The Kishinev Pogrom in 1903 and the 1984 Delhi Pogrom. Though we have traveled far and wide sharing this story, our work is not yet finished!

Our Story

Learn about our story, and how **YOU** can help us reach the next step in deepening the conversation surrounding these tragic events through poetry, music and the power of live theatre. 

Our journey began in 1991, with the poem "Kultar's Mime" by Sarbpreet Singh, which serves as the main text of the play. In early 2013, his daughter, Mehr, adapted this text into a play of the same name which premiered to a small audience in a high school auditorium. Two years, and many revisions later, this play has had thirty-six acclaimed performances in four countries across three continents including: 

*  Delhi on the exact 30 year anniversary of the massacre, 
*  British Parliament for MPs and members of the House of Lords
*  Before an audience of 1500 in Wolverhampton in the British Midlands.
*  Universities such as Harvard, Stanford, UC Berkeley, Columbia, BU, Penn State, Carleton and many others. 
An outpouring of emotion from survivors of 1984 who were invariably present in the audience everywhere the show went.The play has garnered strong reviews in the US, Canada and India and was covered by every major newspaper in India as well as the BBC and several British TV channels. 

Next Steps:

KULTAR'S MIME has been invited to perform at the 2015 Parliament of the World's Religion Conference in Salt Lake City, Utah this October. The first Parliament took place in 1893 in Chicago; since then it has become the premier interfaith event in the world attracting more than 10,000 attendees form all over the world.

We will need $ for:

* Flying to and from the Parliament
* Accommodations during the Parliament weekend
* Rehearsal space leading up to the event
***PAYING OUR ARTISTS***  We are committed to compensating our artists so that we can continue to make theatre as a tool for social change
*Publicity materials


Please contribute generously to the campaign and send the production to Salt Lake City! 


Kultar's Mime is being presented worldwide by The Sikh Research Institute.

story:
• Short Summary

The aim of the appeal is to set up a School of Arts in Nablus to provide an outlet for Palestinian children and young adults to showcase their talents and engage with the local community.

We believe in providing light for the children of Palestine through dance, music and engagement with their traditional culture. For the realisation of this we need your help in raising the costs of the school for the children of Palestine. Children from Nablus will be trained in traditional dance, music and crafts (such as embroidery) after school and during holidays. 

The Arts School will encourage comradery among young Palestinians and promote community spirit and teamwork. The youth of Nablus are highly motivated about showing off their country, dance and songs to the world. The school will provide a chance for the children to tell their own narrative, as the humanistic side of Palestinian culture is often overshadowed. 

  • Where the money raised will go

The money raised will be used for renting premises for the school, running costs such as electricity and water. Funds raised will also go towards the expenses of the trainers and teachers salaries. Finally, funds are also required for the purchase of traditional dance clothing, materials and items such as a sound system. 

An Overview of the start-up cost would look like this:

-Costumes and materials: 3000 USD  

-Administrative costs: 3000 USD

-Rent and running costs: 3500 USD

-PA System: 4000 USD

-Coordinators salary: 6500 USD

-Summary: 20000 USD 

After one full year we will have our running costs covered by tuition fees.

  • What We Need

We believe in providing light for the children of Palestine through dance, music and engagement with their traditional culture.

We think it’s time for a Dance School to be developed in North Palestine to provide an outlet for Palestinian children and young adults to showcase their talents and engage with the local community. Masha El’Falesteen (The Lights of Palestine) hopes to establish this school and our dream is to raise $20000 for the engagement of marginalised children in their heritage and culture.

Once established the Dance School will become a cornerstone of the Nablus community, showcasing its work at national and international events  and serving to promote the human side of the Palestinian nation.

The proposed school will also work with children from local refugee camps including Askar and Balata refugee camp. Displaced for decades, Palestinian refugees remain in a ‘temporary’ state with limited access to resources, poor living conditions, restricted mobility, and numerous barriers to livelihood. While Palestinians have continued to find innovative ways to maintain their communities and spirit, we believe that a Dance School will foster a greater sense of community and pride in Palestinian culture. 

We aim to establish a grassroots non-profit Palestinian organization that will focus on the needs of local children by utilizing the skills of Palestinian volunteers who are knowledgeable in local dance, music, traditions and culture. The school will aim to rebuild the identity of Palestinian children through creative processes and will send a strong message of community resilience, transcend occupation and conflict and offer the world a message that even in the most adversarial conditions there is grounds for talent in the arts to flourish.

We appeal to those who wish to support creative solutions to promoting Palestinian culture and heritage in an increasingly complex political situation in Palestine and to those of you who simply love the arts, dance and promotion of traditions. Your support will help us to bring children of varying ages, capabilities and backgrounds together to learn and train under the highest professional standards.

Around 250 children will attend to the school.

  • Other ways you can help

If you cant help financially sharing on social media such as Facebook and Twitter goes a long way and we are happy for anything that will make this project succeed!

French Translation: 

. Résumé

L'objectif de l'appel est de mettre en place une école d'expression artistique à Naplouse destinée à des enfants palestiniens et des jeunes adultes afin qu'ils puissent exprimer leurs talents et s'engager au sein la communauté locale.

A travers la danse, la musique et l'engagement avec leur culture traditionnelle, nous apporterons de la lumière pour les enfants de la Palestine. Pour la réalisation de ce projet nous avons besoin de votre aide principalement pour assurer les coûts de lancement de l'école pour les enfants et les jeunes de Naplouse. Ils seront formés à la danse traditionnelle, la musique et également à l'artisanat (comme la broderie) après l'école et pendant les vacances.

L'École des arts encouragera la camaraderie parmi les jeunes Palestiniens, l'esprit communautaire et le travail d'équipe. La jeunesse de Naplouse est très motivée à l'idée montrer hors de leur pays, de la danse, de la musique et des chants au monde. L'école sera l'occasion pour les enfants de raconter leur propre histoire, dans laquelle le côté humaniste de la culture palestinienne est souvent éclipsée.

. L'argent collecté

L'argent récolté sera utilisé pour la location de locaux pour l'école, les coûts tels que l'électricité et l'eau courante. Les fonds recueillis serviront aussi aux dépenses des formateurs et aux salaires des enseignants. Enfin, les fonds sont également nécessaires pour l'achat de costumes de danse traditionnelle, des matériaux et du matériel tel qu'un système de son.

Un aperçu du coût de démarrage:

Costumes et matériaux: 3000 USD

Coûts Administratifs: 3000 USD

Location et coûts de fonctionnement: 3500 USD

Système de sonorisation: 4000 USD

Salaires: 6500 USD

Total: 20 000 USD

Après une année complète, nous aurons nos coûts de fonctionnement couverts par les frais de scolarité.

. Ce dont nous avons besoin

Nous croyons pouvoir fournir de la lumière aux enfants de la Palestine à travers la danse, la musique et l'engagement avec leur culture traditionnelle.

Nous pensons qu'il est temps de développer une école de danse dans le nord de la Palestine afin de fournir une alternative pour les enfants palestiniens et les jeunes adultes afin qu'ils puissent exprimer leurs talents et s'engager avec la communauté locale. Masha El'Falesteen (Les Lumières de la Palestine) espère mettre en place cette école et notre rêve est de réunir 20,000$ pour l'engagement des enfants marginalisés dans leur patrimoine et la culture.

Une fois établie l'école de danse deviendra une pierre angulaire de la communauté de Naplouse, présentant ses travaux lors d'événements nationaux et internationaux et servant à promouvoir le côté humain de la nation palestinienne.

L'école se propose pour également travailler avec les enfants des camps de réfugiés d'Askar, de Balata et autres . Déplacés depuis des décennies, les réfugiés palestiniens restent dans une situation provisoire avec un accès limité aux ressources, de mauvaises conditions de vie, une mobilité restreinte et de nombreux obstacles à la subsistance. Alors que les Palestiniens ont toujours su trouver des moyens novateurs pour maintenir leur esprit communautaire, nous croyons qu'une école de danse contribuera à un plus grand sens de la communauté et à la fierté de la culture palestinienne.

Nous créerons une association palestinienne non lucrative qui mettra l'accent sur les besoins des enfants de la région en utilisant les compétences des bénévoles palestiniens qui connaissent les danses locales, la musique, les traditions et la culture. L'école vise à reconstituer l'identité des enfants palestiniens par des processus créatifs et enverra un message fort de la résilience des communautés. Transcender l'occupation et le conflit, offrir au monde un message : même dans les situations les plus contradictoires, des talents artistiques peuvent s'épanouir.

Nous lançons un appel à ceux qui souhaitent soutenir des solutions créatives pour promouvoir la culture et le patrimoine palestinien dans une situation politique de plus en plus complexe et à ceux d'entre vous qui aiment tout simplement les arts, la danse et la promotion des traditions. Votre soutien nous permettra d'accueillir les enfants d'âges, de capacités et d'horizons différents pour apprendre et se former dans des conditions extrêmement professionnelles.

L'école permettra d'accueillir jusqu'à 250 enfants.

.Autres façons d'aider

Si vous ne pouvez pas aider financièrement le partage sur les réseaux sociaux tels que Facebook et Twitter est également utile et nous serons heureux pour toute initiative qui permettra le succès de ce projet.
story_txt:
Short Summary
 
The aim of the appeal is to set up a School of Arts in Nablus to provide an outlet for Palestinian children and young adults to showcase their talents and engage with the local community.
We believe in providing light for the children of Palestine through dance, music and engagement with their traditional culture. For the realisation of this we need your help in raising the costs of the school for the children of Palestine. Children from Nablus will be trained in traditional dance, music and crafts (such as embroidery) after school and during holidays. 
The Arts School will encourage comradery among young Palestinians and promote community spirit and teamwork. The youth of Nablus are highly motivated about showing off their country, dance and songs to the world. The school will provide a chance for the children to tell their own narrative, as the humanistic side of Palestinian culture is often overshadowed. 


Where the money raised will go
The money raised will be used for renting premises for the school, running costs such as electricity and water. Funds raised will also go towards the expenses of the trainers and teachers salaries. Finally, funds are also required for the purchase of traditional dance clothing, materials and items such as a sound system. 
An Overview of the start-up cost would look like this:
-Costumes and materials: 3000 USD  
-Administrative costs: 3000 USD
-Rent and running costs: 3500 USD
-PA System: 4000 USD-Coordinators salary: 6500 USD-Summary: 20000 USD After one full year we will have our running costs covered by tuition fees.





What We Need
    

We believe in providing light for the children of Palestine through dance, music and engagement with their traditional culture.
We think it’s time for a Dance School to be developed in North Palestine to provide an outlet for Palestinian children and young adults to showcase their talents and engage with the local community. Masha El’Falesteen (The Lights of Palestine) hopes to establish this school and our dream is to raise $20000 for the engagement of marginalised children in their heritage and culture.
Once established the Dance School will become a cornerstone of the Nablus community, showcasing its work at national and international events  and serving to promote the human side of the Palestinian nation.
The proposed school will also work with children from local refugee camps including Askar and Balata refugee camp. Displaced for decades, Palestinian refugees remain in a ‘temporary’ state with limited access to resources, poor living conditions, restricted mobility, and numerous barriers to livelihood. While Palestinians have continued to find innovative ways to maintain their communities and spirit, we believe that a Dance School will foster a greater sense of community and pride in Palestinian culture. 
We aim to establish a grassroots non-profit Palestinian organization that will focus on the needs of local children by utilizing the skills of Palestinian volunteers who are knowledgeable in local dance, music, traditions and culture. The school will aim to rebuild the identity of Palestinian children through creative processes and will send a strong message of community resilience, transcend occupation and conflict and offer the world a message that even in the most adversarial conditions there is grounds for talent in the arts to flourish.
We appeal to those who wish to support creative solutions to promoting Palestinian culture and heritage in an increasingly complex political situation in Palestine and to those of you who simply love the arts, dance and promotion of traditions. Your support will help us to bring children of varying ages, capabilities and backgrounds together to learn and train under the highest professional standards.
Around 250 children will attend to the school.

Other ways you can help

If you cant help financially sharing on social media such as Facebook and Twitter goes a long way and we are happy for anything that will make this project succeed!
French Translation: 


. Résumé

L'objectif de l'appel est de mettre en place une école d'expression artistique à Naplouse destinée à des enfants palestiniens et des jeunes adultes afin qu'ils puissent exprimer leurs talents et s'engager au sein la communauté locale.

A travers la danse, la musique et l'engagement avec leur culture traditionnelle, nous apporterons de la lumière pour les enfants de la Palestine. Pour la réalisation de ce projet nous avons besoin de votre aide principalement pour assurer les coûts de lancement de l'école pour les enfants et les jeunes de Naplouse. Ils seront formés à la danse traditionnelle, la musique et également à l'artisanat (comme la broderie) après l'école et pendant les vacances.

L'École des arts encouragera la camaraderie parmi les jeunes Palestiniens, l'esprit communautaire et le travail d'équipe. La jeunesse de Naplouse est très motivée à l'idée montrer hors de leur pays, de la danse, de la musique et des chants au monde. L'école sera l'occasion pour les enfants de raconter leur propre histoire, dans laquelle le côté humaniste de la culture palestinienne est souvent éclipsée.

. L'argent collecté

L'argent récolté sera utilisé pour la location de locaux pour l'école, les coûts tels que l'électricité et l'eau courante. Les fonds recueillis serviront aussi aux dépenses des formateurs et aux salaires des enseignants. Enfin, les fonds sont également nécessaires pour l'achat de costumes de danse traditionnelle, des matériaux et du matériel tel qu'un système de son.

Un aperçu du coût de démarrage:

Costumes et matériaux: 3000 USD

Coûts Administratifs: 3000 USD

Location et coûts de fonctionnement: 3500 USD

Système de sonorisation: 4000 USD

Salaires: 6500 USD

Total: 20 000 USD

Après une année complète, nous aurons nos coûts de fonctionnement couverts par les frais de scolarité.








. Ce dont nous avons besoin

Nous croyons pouvoir fournir de la lumière aux enfants de la Palestine à travers la danse, la musique et l'engagement avec leur culture traditionnelle.

Nous pensons qu'il est temps de développer une école de danse dans le nord de la Palestine afin de fournir une alternative pour les enfants palestiniens et les jeunes adultes afin qu'ils puissent exprimer leurs talents et s'engager avec la communauté locale. Masha El'Falesteen (Les Lumières de la Palestine) espère mettre en place cette école et notre rêve est de réunir 20,000$ pour l'engagement des enfants marginalisés dans leur patrimoine et la culture.

Une fois établie l'école de danse deviendra une pierre angulaire de la communauté de Naplouse, présentant ses travaux lors d'événements nationaux et internationaux et servant à promouvoir le côté humain de la nation palestinienne.

L'école se propose pour également travailler avec les enfants des camps de réfugiés d'Askar, de Balata et autres . Déplacés depuis des décennies, les réfugiés palestiniens restent dans une situation provisoire avec un accès limité aux ressources, de mauvaises conditions de vie, une mobilité restreinte et de nombreux obstacles à la subsistance. Alors que les Palestiniens ont toujours su trouver des moyens novateurs pour maintenir leur esprit communautaire, nous croyons qu'une école de danse contribuera à un plus grand sens de la communauté et à la fierté de la culture palestinienne.

Nous créerons une association palestinienne non lucrative qui mettra l'accent sur les besoins des enfants de la région en utilisant les compétences des bénévoles palestiniens qui connaissent les danses locales, la musique, les traditions et la culture. L'école vise à reconstituer l'identité des enfants palestiniens par des processus créatifs et enverra un message fort de la résilience des communautés. Transcender l'occupation et le conflit, offrir au monde un message : même dans les situations les plus contradictoires, des talents artistiques peuvent s'épanouir.

Nous lançons un appel à ceux qui souhaitent soutenir des solutions créatives pour promouvoir la culture et le patrimoine palestinien dans une situation politique de plus en plus complexe et à ceux d'entre vous qui aiment tout simplement les arts, la danse et la promotion des traditions. Votre soutien nous permettra d'accueillir les enfants d'âges, de capacités et d'horizons différents pour apprendre et se former dans des conditions extrêmement professionnelles.

L'école permettra d'accueillir jusqu'à 250 enfants.

.Autres façons d'aider

Si vous ne pouvez pas aider financièrement le partage sur les réseaux sociaux tels que Facebook et Twitter est également utile et nous serons heureux pour toute initiative qui permettra le succès de ce projet.

story:
Help us bring this important piece to the stage and uncover the forgotten secrets and atrocities of a denied genocide.


“Who, after all, today remembers the annihilation of the Armenians?” 
– Adolf Hitler, 1939

About The Project

We intend to produce the world premiere of “I Wish To Die Singing – Voices From The Armenian Genocide.

Performances will run from 21st April to 16th May 2015 at the Finborough Theatre.

Commemorating the exact centenary of the deportations that began the Armenian Genocide, this piece is a controversial documentary drama uncovering the forgotten secrets and atrocities of a denied genocide – featuring eyewitness reportage, images, music, poetry from Armenia's greatest poets, and verbatim survivors testimonies from one of the greatest historical injustices of all time.

The Armenian Genocide was perpetrated by the Ottoman Turkish Government in 1915. 1.5 million people died. Today, the Turkish government refuses acknowledge that any genocide took place.

With the centenary taking place, this topic has become highly relevant. This piece aims to contribute to raising awareness of these events as well as pay tribute to those who lost their lives. We want the audience to leave the theatre profoundly affected by what they've seen. 

The Armenian Genocide has been largely ignored by the UK theatrical community. This production is intended to address this omission.


Creative Team

Neil McPherson, Writer

Neil is the acclaimed Artistic Director of the Finborough Theatre. He won The Writers’ Guild Award for the Encouragement of New Writing in 2010, and has twice won the OffWestEnd Award for Best Artistic Director.  An earlier version of I Wish to Die Singing was presented for a sold out short run at the Finborough Theatre in 2005 to mark the 90th anniversary of the Armenian Genocide, and received a staged reading at the Centre for Armenian Information and Advice, London, in 2006.


Tommo Fowler, Director

Tommo returns to the Finborough Theatre where he directed Obama-ology and was Resident Assistant Director at the Finborough Theatre working on Sommer 14: A Dance of Death and Harajuku Girls. Trained with Living Pictures and on the Short Course at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. Direction includes Monster Party (Arcola Theatre), Vesting Day (Southwark Playhouse), a staged reading of Wake (English Touring Theatre Studios), The Repast, Porcelain, Just Say No (Theatre503), The (Accidental) Execution of Alan Bishop (Pleasance London) and Extremely Brief and Violent (Royal Academy of Dramatic Art). Assistant Direction includes Handel Furioso (Arcola Theatre and National Tour), Rainbow (Edinburgh Festival and winner of Fringe First Award) and Mojo Mickybo (Old Red Lion Theatre).


About the Finborough Theatre

The multi-award-winning Finborough Theatre presents plays and music theatre, concentrated exclusively on thought provoking text-based new writing, as well as rediscovering genuinely neglected works from the 19th and 20th centuries, many produced or co-produced in-house. We offer a stimulating and inclusive programme at the centre of London's cultural life, appealing to theatregoers of all generations and from a broad spectrum of the population.

The Finborough Theatre has been awarded the prestigious Pearson Playwriting Award bursary for writers:  Chris Lee in 2000, Laura Wade in 2005 (who also went on to win the Critics' Circle Theatre Award for Most Promising Playwright, the George Devine Award and an Olivier Award nomination), James Graham in 2006 (also subsequently nominated for an Olivier Award), Al Smith in 2007, Anders Lustgarten in 2009, Simon Vinnicombe in 2010, Shamser Sinha in 2012 and Chris Thompson in 2014. Three bursary holders (Laura Wade, James Graham and Anders Lustgarten) have also won the Catherine Johnson Award for Best Play written by a bursary holder. 


How Much Do We Need?

To fund the entire show from conception to completion will cost us £19,580, but we are asking IndieGoGo backers for £5,000 to cover our physical production costs so that we can devote all our fundraising efforts to paying our cast as much as we possibly can.

Budget:

  • Set: £1,500
  • Properties: £500
  • Costumes: £700
  • Lighting: £300
  • Sound: £300
  • Running Costs – Properties: £150
  • Running Costs – Wardrobe: £150
  • Travel and Transport: £200
  • Multimedia: £1,200
Total Physical Production Costs = £5,000

The Finborough Theatre have decided to use IndieGoGo because we love the direct contact with backers. We want every one of you to be as passionate about this production as we are, and to invite you into the creative process. IndieGoGo makes this possible by allowing us to message backers directly and thank them for pledges. It's not just about receiving money and spending it: it's a creative exchange. 

Of course, we do desperately need the funds we hope will be raised by this campaign. Theatre is an expensive business and the income from ticket sales alone often can't guarantee any sustainability. 


What Else Can I Do?

We understand that not everyone can afford to give money, but there are still plenty of other ways you can help!

  1. Like the Facebook Page and share our posts.
  2. Follow us on Twitter and retweet our posts.
  3. Buy tickets to the show.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Révelino Marciano (28), dancer and choreographer from the Netherlands. After i survived cancer in my younger years i have hearing problems left. This doesn't stop me from becoming a dancer. Since my hearing problems i didn't had much choice of getting a "normal" job. My dream became to be an inspirational dance teacher for kids and teenagers and i can say with proud that i am.
  • The reason i start this campaign is because i moved from the Netherlands to the small country Luxembourg and started without anything a dance studio here. This is working pretty well but it is pretty hard also. Lot's of people know that Luxembourg doesn't have the highest level in dance, but i can tell that within a year i have pushed students to a new level. Now we have a dance team that called 'Press Play Dance Crew', we started on a basic level and worked our way up to a great level. Our team consists of 10 talented young girls and boys.
  • With your help we can travel to other countries and represent Luxembourg worldwide. So we get a chance to show that anything is possible if you work hard. I always believed that hard work pays off. You just have to believe in yourself and in the people who support you. For my team it is a big dream coming true that they have grown so far and have the change to show their talent on different stages. For me it means a little more than that.. It proves for me that people were wrong about the fact they were telling me i could never be a dancer, teacher or choreographer.
"I'm very happy to be a dance teacher. See here a video from my class."

What We Need & What You Get

  • We try to raise at least €3000,- so we can travel with our team to the Netherlands for our next big competition, with a tour-bus for support from people of Luxembourg. From that same money we also want to buy clothes for the team and pay overnight staying in Holland. If we raise more money we could use the remaining money for renovation of our dance studio.
    Calculation: €1400,- Tourbus retour
    €750,- Event tickets for supporters (50 x €15,-)
    €300,- Hotel
    €720,- Clothes (€80,- per person)
    Total: €3.170,-
  • Any bit would help us and we will be very thankful. For companies we can put your logo on our website as sponsors. And individual people that sponsor us living in Luxembourg or coming to visit Luxembourg we can offer a free class at our dance studio.
  • If we don't reach our goal we still could use the money to work on our dance studio (publicity material, small renovation, show for end of the year).

The Impact of Your Help

  • I believe that dancing, singing and playing music is a very important thing in human life. I always say that dancing is important for the development of young people: they get self-confidence (I can tell), a better condition, they get to know other people and it is fun!
  • Before we had also some sponsors and they helped us to our way up to where we are now. So we traveled for example to Switzerland to attend the BigBang Bern 2014 (travel costs paid by the organization) and clothes we could borrow from Urban Diamond store in Luxembourg.
  • I can't really explain how much it means to us, but i can tell you it means a lot. By winning our first competition in Rotterdam the Netherlands (after just our 2nd performance together) i saw how my team was touched by hearing the speaker saying: "1st place goes to PRESS PLAY!!!". My team was in tears from happiness and jumping all around. This feeling will forever stay with me and that's why i know that it means a lot to all of us.
"See below our performance after dancing just one year together!"

Risks & Challenges

  • I understand that it is maybe not possible to reach my goal but at least i give it a try. Even if we don't get to our goal, we won't give up and keep doing what makes us most happy.
  • My plan is to tell as much people about our campaign by using the internet, telling people face to face and telling public after a performance.

Other Ways To Help Us

  • We completely understand that not everybody can contribute, but this doesn't mean you can't help! To those people we ask to spread the word.. let people know about our campaign!!
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign. Thank you!

    Please have a look at our website: www.pressplaydancecrew.com

story:
Makhampom Foundation (Thailand) kindly invites you to join support for social circus movements for ethnic youth groups in Northern Thailand. 

A Background of Makhampom Foundation

Makhampom Foundation is a social organisation that works with the medium of theatre. Born in 1980, we defined our mission as: to apply theatre as a community media form to create connections between different sectors, regions, and countries towards transforming Thai society and beyond. We believe in the power of theatre. Adapting various styles of performing arts has been our signature for decades, not to be the master, but to communicate, to encourage creativity, to express, to prompt dialogue, to entertain, to provoke debate, to strengthen cultural practice, to open the creative mind and body, and to facilitate direct social activism.

The theme of Social Circus was introduced to us not so long ago by our marvellous friends from all corners of the world. After 6 years of ups and downs in our experience, it has paved its way to be one of our main programmes. Based in Chiang Dao, a small district in the north of Thailand, we founded the Pang Daeng Youth Circus Troupe of Dara’ang ethnic group children. There are networks of young circus artists and trainees from our programs spread around Thailand to bring out the powerful message of social change.

The Project and its Important Impact

This year in 2015, we challenge ourselves to take a step further with a project called “Circus on the Edge”. It is a collaborative project in which circus trainers from Europe and Asia are joining the journey of circus/theatre training to strengthen 3 ethnic communities in northern Thailand through applied circus practices. These communities constantly face issues of socio-cultural stigmatisation, freedom of movements, sustainability, and external development pressures. The unique learning opportunities of this project will offer new perspectives, knowledge, and a toolkit for participants to fight against the deprivation they are facing; especially as two of the participant groups are from stateless, displaced backgrounds.

Circus as an old European tradition occurs in Thailand as a new approach. The emerging popularity of circus arts, particularly amongst young rural people, indicates an attraction to the physicality, aesthetics, and excitement of the form and a natural affiliation with local dance, ritual, and martial arts traditions. However, each community joins us, not to be circus/theatre stars, but to strengthen themselves for bigger goals - to protect local environments and traditions, to raise their status and profile with outsiders, and to address youth gangs, suicide, drugs, and cultural identity issues. This will then extend through their districts and collectively create the potential for social circus theatre movements amongst ethnic minority groups in northern Thailand, with powerful impacts on young people and social discriminations.

Current Contributors

We’re so thankful to the Asia-Europe Foundation (ASEF) and Arts Network Asia (ANA) who listen and answer to our call for financial help for training activities. They kindly support 50% of the whole budget as a part of “Creative Encounters” initiative. A number of dignified organisations join the support; even the villagers from the 3 communities are glad to put their hands in. However, our dream is big, but so is the obstacle of sustainability that we are striving to overcome.

What We Need

Most of the expenses of this project are, gratefully, covered by now, but we need only one last piece to complete the puzzle. The training will finish at some point and the kids will go home; but we can’t stop just yet when the keyword of our community work is “sustainability”. Groups will be formed who are always ready to work at their best for their communities. It is essential that, within the first months after the project finishes, each group continues working in their community using what they have learnt from the project. And here we are now, at the point where we kindly ask you to support our dreams.

We calculated the factors that each group would need for their starting point, and we found that there are 2 main necessary parts:

1.  Group Founding and Management - We’re not talking about construction of buildings, but there are still items needed for work. We set the figure of USD 1,000 for each group to be used for:

a.  Stationeries– notebooks, boards, pens, A4 and flipchart paper, etc.

b.  Meals and Travel for Meeting and Activity Days – they travel from different areas of the village for meetings and activities, and some villages are as big as a mountain, with no mass transportation service.

c.  Cover of Income – to work with the youth group means to drop other jobs; including picking chilli, cutting grass, or harvesting rice, which they earn their living from.

2.  Circus Equipment– A circus group cannot do much without circus equipment. We set the figure of USD 1,000 for each group to be used for:

a.  Making Equipment – some circus apparatus can be handmade, such as hula-hoop, juggling balls and clubs, poi, and walking stilts. With this money, villagers will receive some money as a thank you gift for helping to make equipment for the group.

b.  Buying Equipment – some equipment cannot be made by hand because it will not be safe enough, such as silk, trapeze, and safety mats. With help from Makhampom’s international friends, we can get them for a discounted price.

From details above, each group will have USD 2,000 to get their group started. Therefore the total amount for 3 groups would be USD 6,000.

How We Will Show Our Gratitude

For those who contribute, we’re glad to present very special and unique gifts to you as a ‘thank you’ for your generous and valuable contribution:

-  A handmade thank you card from the kids

-  A Recycled Juggling Ball DIY Kit, supported by Gooseberry Arts Inc., a Makhampom family member with the same mission of social change

-  A handmade local craft from the communities

-  An exclusive DVD documentary of the whole project, with English subtitles

-  Accommodation at Makhampom Chiang Dao Art Space (Chiang Dao, Chiang Mai, Thailand) with community trips around Chiang Dao and a creative art workshop course by Gooseberry Arts Inc.

And even if we cannot reach this goal, the money will be divided equally between the 3 groups. We will be extremely grateful to all contributors who spend time supporting, promoting and helping our project in many other ways.

All updates about the project will be presented to the public on our project blog, Facebook pages, and here on Indiegogo.

Ongoing Makhampom Successes

We always sustain long-term contact with every community we work with. We exchange e-mails, talk on the phone, pay visits, and set up meetings to keep each other updated. So there needn’t be any concern that we would disappear after; the communities are valued and important members of the Makhampom family.

Our successful track record of projects with social circus/theatre approach:

-  Transformative Theatre for Teens (TTT): emerged from Makhampom’s will to reinforce society’s health education. Supported by Thai Health Organization, since 2009 TTT has created transformative networks of over 60 youth theatre groups, 6 associations, and a network of 700 teachers.

-  Theatre for Ethnic Youth: a TTT branch project focused on blending local identities of 6 ethnic communities in Northern Thailand with theatre and circus arts.

-  Pang Daeng Youth Circus Troupe: Directed by a circus trainer who has 10 years volunteering experience with Makhampom. The troupe, running since 2009, is now considered the most active ethnic youth group in Thailand working with the approach of social circus.

Final Words

So, please consider our message. You can also help by sharing it to your friends by using the Indiegogo sharing tools, on Facebook, on Twitter, other social media platforms and word-of-mouth. Your support, in any way possible, would help us to put the last jigsaw piece in place and complete this puzzle of sustainable community development.

Other Ways to Reach Us

-  Circus on the Edge Website : Our online space for information and updates about the project

-  Makhampom International Network : Our Facebook page for international friends

-  Makhampom Art Space : Another Facebook page for our base in Chiang Dao (Thai language)

-  Makhampom Website : Our visions, missions, policies, and history

Makhampom
Foundation (Thailand) kindly invites you to join support for social circus
movements for ethnic youth groups in Northern Thailand. A Background of Makhampom FoundationMakhampom Foundation is a social organisation that works
with the medium of theatre. Born in 1980, we defined our mission as: to apply theatre as a community media form to create connections
between different sectors, regions, and countries towards transforming Thai
society and beyond. We believe in the power of theatre. Adapting various styles of performing arts has been
our signature for decades, not to be the
master, but to communicate, to encourage creativity, to express, to prompt
dialogue, to entertain, to provoke debate, to strengthen cultural practice, to
open the creative mind and body, and to facilitate direct social activism.

The
theme of Social Circus was introduced
to us not so long ago by our marvellous friends from all corners of the world.
After 6 years of ups and downs in our experience, it has paved its way to be
one of our main programmes. Based in Chiang Dao, a small district in the north
of Thailand, we founded the Pang Daeng Youth Circus Troupe of Dara’ang ethnic
group children. There are networks of young circus artists and trainees from
our programs spread around Thailand to bring out the powerful message of social
change.The Project and its Important
Impact
This year in 2015, we challenge ourselves to take a
step further with a project called “Circus on the Edge”. It is a collaborative
project in which circus trainers from Europe and Asia are joining the journey
of circus/theatre training to strengthen 3 ethnic communities in northern
Thailand through applied circus practices. These communities constantly face

story:
Who the Hell Are We?

Hi, my name is Justin Giachetti, and I am the writer and director of Inferno. "Inferno" follows the stories of seven people who mysteriously find themselves trapped in a neverending hallway. As details about their past begin to shed light as to the reasoning for their captivity, they slowly begin to turn on each other until the last one stands. For the devil desires a partner, and he isn't picky. The play deals with the idea that evil isn't born, it is created, and that sin is part of human nature. It’s a character study and a look at how circumstance can push people to the worst extremes.  It also tackles such controversial topics as: eating disorders, armed robbery, human trafficking, school shootings, and much more.  

I’ve always been obsessed with the this idea of sin, and how something so intangible can be so feared and scorned. These larger than life archetypes needed to be brought back down to earth and I was just the 20 year old theater student to do it. I’ve been writing plays for almost five years and none have changed my whole perspective of writing such as this one. I am personally sure that once you watch the show, these characters and these stories will touch you just as much as it has touched everyone who’s read it so far.

With your help, this show will see its world premiere this August. We, the cast and crew of Inferno, feel that this is a show that speaks to the world right now. The sooner it gets produced, the sooner it can reach people, no matter what scale its on. We hope to be accepted to the New York City Fringe Festival, but if not accepted, there is a local theater willing to house the production.

What We Need & What You Get

This show can be something beautiful, but we need your help. Right now we are looking for $7,500 dollars, but any amount would help to get this show off the ground. If we do obtain our final goal, we would be able to afford:

  • Rental and Performance Fees for the theatre/Festival Fees
  • Budget for costumes, sets, and props
  • Print ads and other advertising strategies
  • Printing of scripts, programs, and other materials
  • Payment for our cast and crew
  • Transportation compensation
  • Production of Merchandise

Again, any amount we raise would help us immensely, and we would appreciate any and all donations. Plus, we will be giving out unique perks that you can only get with this show. Only with Inferno can you get perks like:

  • The Seven Deadly Sin Trading Cards (Featuring the cast of Inferno)
  • Homemade Phoebe Cloaks 
  • A Fun Day Out with the Cast (Followed by Much Needed Therapy)
  • Masks Signed by the Cast
  • And More!

The Impact

This play is not one to be taken lightly, and really sheds light on different afflictions people in our everyday lives may be dealing with. Therefore, we know, as a cast and crew, how important it is that foundations that help these disorders and social problems receive the funding they need to make a change just as much as we do. Not only will we be reaching out to some foundations and putting helpline numbers on our website and programs, but a portion of our ticket sales will also be going towards charities that help fight cancer, eating disorders, mental disorders, and many other issues our play tackles. Inferno isn’t just a way for you to kick back for two hours and watch something mind numbing. We not only want to entertain, but educate, help, and give back to our community. 

Also, if you are ever wondering where your money is going at a certain moment, Inferno will have a YouTube channel and a website to keep you up to date. The YouTube channel will feature sneak peaks at the show, as well as a vlog series chronicling the production of the show called “The Road to Damnation”. The website will feature more info on the cast and crew, performance information, and news about the production. 

Risks & Challenges

Theatre always may produce ricks and obstacles, however, we made sure when devising this goal number that we have enough wiggle room just in case. Personally, we have enough dedicated people working on this project that if a problem does arise, it will be handled swiftly and accurately. You will not be disappointed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

It is more than ok if you can't contribute anything. What really matters to us is that you even looked at this campaign to begin with. Now, all we ask of you is to help get the word out. And once we produce Inferno, we hope each and every one of you will come see the show.

story:
Short Summary:  Too Much Exposition!

Thanks for clicking on our Indiegogo link!  
Third Mask Theatre Company is beginning its 4th season this summer and we really want to start it off with a bang, but we won't be able to get off the ground without your help.  We need to run this campaign because we need to raise $2000 to purchase licensing rights to "Urinetown, The Musical." 

 Let me start with our mission statement and our dedication to education!

"Third Mask Theatre Company is a 501(c)(3) organization designed with the following goals:
(a) to provide an outlet for artists and anyone interested in the arts, allowing them to experience and be involved in the creative, technical and educational process of bringing a theatrical production to life,
(b) to educate and engage new audiences with thought-provoking, yet approachable material, thus providing area residents the opportunity to experience what live theatre has to offer,
(c) to promote the arts in the community through public acts and events, aiding local theatre, and lending the time and talent of our committed organization members"

With your donation, you can provide many students, both in high school and college the opportunity to continue their theatre participation and education during the summer months when they aren't attending school.  Your donation will also benefit you and the community by allowing us to mount a full scale musical production for Lehigh Valley residents.

Expected Performances:

July 30th-August 1st at 7:30pm

August 2nd at 2:00pm


From Third Mask's production of Seussical: August 2014

What We Need & What You Get: Run, Freedom, Run!

With your donation, you will receive varying levels of recognition in our program and in social media posts.  If you decide to donate higher amounts of money you will even receive tickets to the show you helped produce!

Funds gathered from this campaign will go directly into Third Mask Theatre Company and will allow us to purchase licensing rights for the production.

But that won't be all! Here are some of the things that we will need to pay for while we are preparing for performance:

Lighting and sound: $2000

Sets: $500-$1000

Production Staff: $1000

Musicians: $1500

Venue Rental: $4000

Costumes: $200

....and the list goes on and on!

Risks & Challenges: Don't be the Bunny!

Most people who are deeply involved in the process of making a show come to life understand that money is always a difficult issue to overcome but with your help, we can make this a reality once again! I say once again because we have been successful in the past.  We represent, along with other fine groups, a growing need for  professionalism and excellence in theatre in our community and with every passing show we raise the bar to what community theatre can achieve.  Our production crew, actors, musicians, stage hands, parents, volunteers and many others work tirelessly to put on the most professional and polished shows we can produce!!

Other Ways You Can Help: Follow your Heart!

We know that not everyone can contribute but if you are so inclined, please spread the word about our campaign by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Pinterest, Tumblr etc. and by using the Indiegogo tools to spread the word about "Urinetown."

Cast photo from Third Mask's Charlie Brown: August 2013

story:
Belgrade English Language Theatre's APRILFOOLATHON

We are a group of 13 young people who are part of Belgrade English Language Theatre. This is a theatre group for young people aged 7 and up, giving us the chance to learn about, make and perform theatre of our choosing.
We were lucky enough to get in touch with a similar group to ours in Prague (Prague Youth Theatre) and we all thought it would be a great idea if our group (aged 17 to 19) could find a way of getting to Prague to meet our colleagues and do something creative with them for the weekend; perform plays, do workshops etc.
Even better than this we thought, what if we could make this happen ourselves? Raise all the money ourselves without relying on any parents, organisations, companies? And do it in a way that would highlight our skills and makybe bring a little amusement to others in the process: The Aprifoolathon was born!


What We Need & What You Get

To be able to get us to Prague, spend four days there and come back via bus, we need to raise a total of 2000 euros. We already raised over 500 euros through our first marathon Improv fundraiser and this inspired us to do another, with a little more publicity and ambition. 

Our fundraising efforts here will help to publicize our next live fundraising performance event:the Aprifoolathon: a live four hour drama improv on: yes April the 1st! If the combination of these two campaigns are successful we will have managed to do what many people told us was not possible and in a way which reflects our own tastes, sense of fun and desire for self-sustainable youth-based art. 

If in the very sad event of not reaching our entire goal we will be forced to travel only as far as the money allows: getting the bus to Zagreb perhaps or just to the end of our street: seriously though, if we don't reach our goal we will continue with other events until we do! and get to Prague by hook or by crook!

The Impact

We have to be honest and say that Serbia is not the richest country in the world, and that opportunities to travel, be creative, develop our creative ideas are not overflowing: which is why we are making things happen ourselves. We have already made many shows, been on tours and entertained hundreds of people with our own brand of particular theatre, and we hope that our efforts will not only inspire others to do the same but will also inspire us to go as far as we can with out own creative potentials.

    Risks & Challenges

    The only risk in this project is not doing it, and that is not an option. Some people think it is scary to stand up in front of people, in your second language and improvise, to perform without a safety net: and in some ways this is true, but it is not as scary as being too scared to.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Just because you can't contribute financially, doesn't mean you can't help us by spreading the word about our campaign, so please share any material from here that you like the look of.

This is a theatre group for young people aged 7 and up, giving us the chance to learn about, make and perform theatre of our choosing.We were lucky enough to get in touch with a similar group to ours in Prague (Prague Youth Theatre) and we all thought it would be a great idea if our group (aged 17 to 19) could find a way of getting to Prague to meet our colleagues and do something creative with them for the weekend; perform plays, do workshops etc.Even better than this we thought, what if we could make this happen ourselves? Raise all the money ourselves without relying on any parents, organisations, companies? And do it in a way that would highlight our skills and makybe bring a little amusement to others in the process: The Aprifoolathon was born!  

What We Need & What You Get   To be able to get us to Prague, spend four days there and come back via bus, we need to raise a total of 2000 euros. We already raised over 500 euros through our first marathon Improv fundraiser and this inspired us to do another, with a little more publicity and ambition. 
Our fundraising efforts here will help to publicize our next live fundraising performance event:the Aprifoolathon: a live four hour drama improv on: yes April the 1st! If the combination of these two campaigns are successful we will have managed to do what many people told us was not possible and in a way which reflects our own tastes, sense of fun and desire for self-sustainable youth-based art.  
If in the very sad event of not reaching our entire goal we will be forced to travel only as far as the money allows: getting the bus to Zagreb perhaps or just to the end of our street: seriously though, if we don't reach our goal we will continue with other events until we do! and get to Prague by hook or by crook!
  The Impact We have to be honest and say that Serbia is not the richest country in the world, and that opportunities to travel, be creative, develop our creative ideas are not overflowing: which is why we are making things happen ourselves. We have already made many shows, been on tours and entertained hundreds of people with our own brand of particular theatre, and we hope that our efforts will not only inspire others to do the same but will also inspire us to go as far as we can with out own creative potentials.    Risks & Challenges  The only risk in this project is not doing it, and that is not an option. Some people think it is scary to stand up in front of people, in your second language and improvise, to perform without a safety net: and in some ways this is true, but it is not as scary as being too scared to.
    Other Ways You Can Help Just because you can't contribute financially, doesn't mean you can't help us by spreading the word about our campaign, so please share any material from here that you like the look of.

story:
Miss Chthonic Star Dream Pageant;

A Spectacular Convulsion of the Sublime 

It's the newest project from Ric Royer and his Psychic Readings Company, who have brought you many marvels of weird drama including Fête of Mistakes, The 50 Greatest Ladies and Gentlemen, and Hystery of Heat! 

  Miss Chthonic Star Dream Pageant is a beauty pageant fashion show, a monstrous parade of internal realities fueled by sacrifice, which thrusts labor, exploitation, and sexual/economic oppression onto the catwalk. Braiding pleasure with the abject and spiking it with a heavy dose of buffoonery, the dream pageant will entertain, amaze, and delightfully frustrate you!

WANT TO BE A STAR? 

In every city that the show will be produced, locals will be invited to participate as contestants in the pageant. But the experience is not what one would expect from a normal beauty pageant, if there is such a thing. Miss Chthonic is stress dream starring all of your anxieties!   

The Dream Pageant features a solid cast featuring members from three New York experimental theatre companies: Title:Point, Object Collection and the Psychic Readings Company.  

Psychic Readings will be bringing the show to AS220 in Providence, RI in July; EMP Collective in Baltimore, MD in September; and back to NYC for a full run in November.  If you don't live in any of these cities -- contribute! and we might come to yours.   

WE NEED:

Money is an important subject to us. It often ends up in the content of our plays, and informs our style of work. As we state in our mission statement, one of our primary goals is to keep our tickets costs low -- both to prevent our shows from being financially prohibitive to attend, as well as to dispel the myth that theatre tickets need to be expensive because it is expensive to create theatre. Because of our advanced skills in stealing, begging, borrowing, dumpster diving and making shit out of garbage, your money will be an investment in PEOPLE and not in Joanne's Fabrics or props that will eventually become useless or a set that will get torn down and thrown away at the end of the show.

Be a patron! Some of the funds raised will go towards transportation, space rentals, and equipment, but most of the money will go towards paying our actors, video editors, technicians, and staff. Be a patron! It's a rarity for theatre artists to consider the worth of their own time and energy. 

ABOUT CO: 

Psychic Readings Company (b. 1999) 

www.psychicreadings.church

is dedicated to the advancement of a higher histrionics through exaggerated examples of life and death. The work created by Psychic Readings are explorations of wonderful and sometimes terrifying mysteries for which there are no logical conclusions.
Psychic Readings is Ric Royer (artistic director), G Lucas Crane (sound designer), Catrin Lloyd-Bollard, Emma Reaves, Jesse Heffler and Bonnie Jones. They are joined in this piece by Tavish Miller, Daniel Nelson, Ryan Downey, Crystal Kovac, Adam Endres and Caitlin Bebb. With video by Jessica Ciocci.

TESTIMONIALS:

Psychic Readings recently staged a first draft of Miss Chthonic at Silent Barn (Brooklyn) on March 7th, and it was a hit! Read below to see what strangers said to us after the show: 

  • A guy named David said, "That was a masterpiece...the veil was lifted."
  • Some guy named Wayne said, "Really outstanding work...I'll be keeping my eye out for you guys." 
  •   A young woman came up to us and was like, "Experimental theatre is not dead in New York! This piece made me feel like it was very much alive!"
  • Another girl was like, “I saw Bjork earlier today, and this was just as good!”

story:
Welcome! We're Fresh Ink.

Fresh Ink Theatre is committed to developing new work with theatre artists in the New England area. Big things are on the horizon for Season 5.
After the Factory Theatre closed, we weren't sure where to go. Like many other small theatre companies in Boston, we struggled to find appropriate and affordable performance space. While we're far from finding a forever home, Fresh Ink is taking a leap of faith for our fifth birthday, and...

We are excited to announce our first ever production at the Boston Center for the Arts.

This is where you come in. We need your help to make this space a reality. 

The Nitty-Gritty

Theatre-making is expensive! 
Your tax deductible donation goes to putting local playwrights to work and local artists on stage.
Donations also help cover the cost of...
  • Renting performance space
  • Renting lighting and sound equipment
  • Building sets, props, and costumes

There's something in it for you, too.

We know you're not supporting us because of the perks, but we still want to say thank you. Check out our great list of perks on the side of the page for more information.

The Next Step

For the first time ever, Fresh Ink is asking friends, supporters, and lovers of new work to help fund our space. In exchange, we promise to give you more of the exciting, innovative, local new plays that you love.

Any amount brings us closer to our goal.

And coming soon... an announcement of our Season 5 productions! Supporters will be the first to know which new play will receive a production at the BCA in fall 2015.

Let's Get Social

Here's some other ways you can help:

  • Share our campaign on your outlets - and let the world know why you support new work development and local artists
  • Join us for The Clytemnestriad April 10 - 18 - tickets here:  https://www.vendini.com/ticket-software.html?t=...
  • Like us on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/FreshInkTheatre?fref=ts
  • Follow us on Twitter - https://twitter.com/FreshInkTheatre 
  • Check out our NEW website - http://www.freshinktheatre.org/
Thank you, in advance, for helping to fund Fresh Ink's space.

story:
Building Babel

WT and Jeremy started this project in the fall of 2013 by inviting some really talented performers in the room to start building structures with each others' bodies.  This building let us to build other things- like residencies to support our work in collaboration with Flushing Town Hall in Queens through their generous space grant and with TheaterLab in Manhattan in their pilot program that invited audiences into the creative process with us.  We've had several invited showings along the way and have built quite a community of people who want to build Babel with us.  

We hope that you will want to help us build!  The plan is to make a show that performs in NYC as well as touring around the world- partnering with different communities and exploring different ways we can learn communicate with each other through our bodies and imaginations.  Babel is the story of us- of why we build and rebuild and build again.  It is the story of overcoming obstacles of moving beyond differences to find a common language.  It's about what happens after the tower falls down: we build.

What We Need & What You Get

We don't need a lot of things, but what we do need is super important!  We've had some great help along the way including free and reduced-cost rehearsal space.  Now we're ramping up for a big rehearsal process and a first showing followed by a series of production residencies at Adelphi University Flushing Town Hall.  

$15,000 broken down:

  • $6000 will go towards our April 11th showing at Gibney Dance.  It will pay for rehearsal space, small artist stipends for our company of 20 performers, and for video & photo documentation.
  • $4000 will go towards our summer work which includes another round of Revealing Dances with our partners Kinesis Project dance theater and a production residency and presentation at Adelphi University . It will pay for rehearsal space, travel for the company to Garden City, Long Island, and to start our sound and costume design.
  • $5000 will go towards our fall work which includes a final production residency and presentation at Flushing Town Hall where we'll put all of the movement and story together with the design elements: lights, sound, & costumes!   It will pay small artist stipends and for our design elements.
This $15,000 will get us ready to premiere Babel in January 2016!
Each of the perks offers a unique experience with Babel.  We want to find ways for you to be a part of this incredible experience.

Other What happens if we don't meet our goal?

That would be a bummer, but we'll keep building!  Every dollar put towards Babel will get us one step closer.  WT, Jeremy, and the whole team have a lot of experience creating new work.  We know we can do it and we hope you want to join us!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you're asked to contribute to many awesome projects and causes.  Any amount helps.  You know what else helps?  Sharing this campaign with your friends and network- and that's free!  Word of mouth goes a long way and will definitely help us build Babel.
