story:
Our Project:

Seventeen years ago, Dean decided to die. Now, somehow, he has been brought back to life by Carrie, a fraudulent psychic with plenty of demons of her own. Desperate to rid herself of her unwanted guest, Carrie calls on her estranged sister Mary, an exorcist whose extreme views stem from the same root as her sister's: the suicide of their mother during their teenage years. Dean seems at home in the present day, but as his memories return he is drawn back to the past - and is there any point in living when he's not truly alive? Meanwhile, Mary and Carrie are forced to face their own past, and Mary's daughter Jess is about to get involved...


Our Team:
Butterfly with a Bomb is a Glasgow theatre company based on the principle of collaboration. We produced 'Rewrite', our first full length play, in 2013 and followed this up with a work in progress presentation of our current project, 'Giving up the Ghost', in 2014. Our work as individuals and as a company has also been seen at events including 'Crossing the Lines', 'Stage to Page' and 'Scottish Screenwriters'. Now we are taking our first Edinburgh journey for 6 performances of the redeveloped 'Giving up the Ghost' in August 2015. We are:

Mary Jo Hastie

Mary Jo is a busy actor, director and mother. Her business brain, experience at getting the best out of performers, and love of experimenting with text and form help ensure that our work is always heading for new and interesting places. As well as co-directing Giving up the Ghost, Mary Jo plays strict evangelical Mary, a part which allows her to draw on her Catholic childhood and early desire to become a nun.

Anna Blainey

Anna is Butterfly with a Bomb's playwright and co-director. In her day job she works at a music and performance venue, and she got the idea for Giving up the Ghost after watching one too many psychic shows. When not working or writing, Anna enjoys cats and wine, and keeps a plentiful supply of both in her flat. 

Claudette Baker-Park

Claudette is an experienced performer in theatre, film and television, and plays Carrie in Giving up the Ghost. When we perform in Edinburgh, she will be 6 months pregnant with her second child, which has been written into the script and added a whole new dimension to Carrie's character. As a colleague of Anna's, Claudie has also seen plenty of convincing and less than convincing psychic performances in her time, providing her with plenty of inspiration for her role.


Jay Newton

Giving up the Ghost is Jay's first project with Butterfly with a Bomb, and he was recruited to play the part of Dean after Claudette was blown away by his performance in Larry Kramer's The Normal Heart. Jay might only have been born halfway through the nineties, but he can rock a Harrington jacket and rock out to Britpop as well as anyone. 

Alice Restrick

Alice has just finished her Advanced Highers and, alongside playing Jess in Giving up the Ghost, is beginning to pursue a career in film making. As Claudette's daughter she has been part of the Butterfly with a Bomb family from the beginning, and has worked alongside us in Blooded (Crossing the Lines at the Arches) and in our series of performances for Carers Week 2015.

Amelia Hastie

Mary-Jo's oldest daughter Amelia also joined the Butterfly with a Bomb family for Crossing the Lines and our Carers Week 2015 performances. As well as helping with promotion during the Fringe, she will be understudying the part of Jess.

Tess Hastie-McMonagle

Tess is Mary-Jo's younger daughter, and the youngest member of our team. As a keen performer, she has already joined us for Carers Week 2015 and will be a part of our front of house and promotion team in Edinburgh.

Philip Barratt

Anna's partner Phil is a professional graphic artist and art director working in film and TV. He has designed all our marketing material for the Fringe and saved us a lot of money through agreeing to be paid in cheese and tea.


What we need: 
As you may know, the Fringe is a fantastic platform for new work, but not a very cheap one.  Currently our Edinburgh adventure is being paid for by Anna's holiday fund, however in order that we can pay this back and avoid ending up out of pocket, we really need £1800. At the very least, we need to pay for the following:

Venue: We are performing at TheSpace UK @ Jury's Inn, an intimate studio space that nevertheless is costing us a total of £744.00 for our 6 day run.

Programme: The Fringe programme is the Fringe-goers Bible, and if you're not listed, you may as well not exist. A listing in the programme costs £204.00.

Insurance: We don't plan on hurting ourselves or our audience, but just in case we need to take out public liability insurance for the week. This is costing £84.99

Posters/Flyers: Anyone who's been to Edinburgh in August will already know and hate the art of Fringe flyering. Nevertheless, it is a necessary evil,  and in order to get all those bits of paper printed we need £95.00

Transport: Most of the time we love living in Glasgow, but for the purposes of this week it's going to be a bit of a pain. Although there are nights we can stay in Edinburgh, for various boring purposes we can't do this every night. Our company's travel costs will therefore come to £450.00

Food/ Drink: Ideally we would like to pay our actors and crew for their hard work, but the next best thing we can do is to feed them. To keep everyone fed and watered over performance week will cost £200.00
If we're lucky enough to make any more than this, it will be a huge help in marketing our show in one or more of the Fringe publications doing the rounds in August. Anything else left over will be used to update our costume and props and reduce the amount of begging and borrowing we have to do. 

The Impact

Giving up the Ghost is a story, and a comedy, so we hope you are engaged by it and find it funny - but we also want to raise awareness. The rate of male suicide in the UK is currently at its highest since 2001, and three and a half times that of women. As with anything, there are plenty of theories about why this is (men, ever been told to 'man up' when you're feeling down?) but as with anything, the first step to understanding is awareness. For this reason, we think it is tremendously important that we begin to see more stories which acknowledge men experiencing and dealing with severe depression and suicide. 

This didn't start out as a issue based piece; Dean isn't all about his suicide. Like many other suicidal men you're likely to meet, he makes jokes, plays music, flirts with girls. We want to put this piece on to show the normality in mental illness, the everyday person who exists alongside it. We want to raise awareness that this man who finds his life inexplicably pointless may be just like someone you know - or even just like you.

Risks & Challenges

The first thing we always have to consider when starting a project is that we may not raise enough money to cover everything we would like to. In this case, the risk is less than usual for our funders because all the essentials are already paid for. If we don't raise enough money, Anna won't have a holiday this year, but the show won't suffer. We will need to rely more on the generosity of our actors and crew by asking them to fund their own travel and meals, but we will still have a venue, a programme entry and a great production to share.

Other Ways You Can Help

We wholeheartedly agree that paying the bills comes before giving us your pennies and pounds. So if you can't contribute financially to our campaign, there are still plenty of ways you can show your support and give us a boost. The average adult Facebook user has 338 friends, meaning that every share really does help get our campaign out there. And if you have anything you'd like to ask us about our project, our company or anything else, find us at www.facebook.com/butterflybombco or www.twitter.com/butterflybombco and ask away. We'll publish as many questions and answers on our profiles as possible and give you a mention at the same time. Finally, if you or anyone you know is in Edinburgh in the last week of August, please do come and see the show - we'll even stay and have a drink with you afterwards.

Although there are nights we can stay in Edinburgh, for various boring purposes we can't do this every night. Our company's travel costs will therefore come to £450.00Food/ Drink: Ideally we would like to pay our actors and crew for their hard work, but the next best thing we can do is to feed them. To keep everyone fed and watered over performance week will cost £200.00
If we're lucky enough to make any more than this, it will be a huge help in marketing our show in one or more of the Fringe publications doing the rounds in August. Anything else left over will be used to update our costume and props and reduce the amount of begging and borrowing we have to do.   The Impact Giving up the Ghost is a story, and a comedy, so we hope you are engaged by it and find it funny - but we also want to raise awareness. The rate of male suicide in the UK is currently at its highest since 2001, and three and a half times that of women. As with anything, there are plenty of theories about why this is (men, ever been told to 'man up' when you're feeling down?) but as with anything, the first step to understanding is awareness. For this reason, we think it is tremendously important that we begin to see more stories which acknowledge men experiencing and dealing with severe depression and suicide. 
This didn't start out as a issue based piece; Dean isn't all about his suicide. Like many other suicidal men you're likely to meet, he makes jokes, plays music, flirts with girls. We want to put this piece on to show the normality in mental illness, the everyday person who exists alongside it. We want to raise awareness that this man who finds his life inexplicably pointless may be just like someone you know - or even just like you.   Risks & Challenges The first thing we always have to consider when starting a project is that we may not raise enough money to cover everything we would like to. In this case, the risk is less than usual for our funders because all the essentials are already paid for. If we don't raise enough money, Anna won't have a holiday this year, but the show won't suffer. We will need to rely more on the generosity of our actors and crew by asking them to fund their own travel and meals, but we will still have a venue, a programme entry and a great production to share.

Other Ways You Can Help We wholeheartedly agree that paying the bills comes before giving us your pennies and pounds. So if you can't contribute financially to our campaign, there are still plenty of ways you can show your support and give us a boost. The average adult Facebook user has 338 friends, meaning that every share really does help get our campaign out there. And if you have anything you'd like to ask us about our project, our company or anything else, find us at www.facebook.com/butterflybombco or www.twitter.com/butterflybombco and ask away. We'll publish as many questions and answers on our profiles as possible and give you a mention at the same time. Finally, if you or anyone you know is in Edinburgh in the last week of August, please do come and see the show - we'll even stay and have a drink with you afterwards.

story:
I cannot forget my mother, she is my bridge: however, the mother-daughter relationship is the most complex one. This show reflects and discusses these concepts in a dark comedy.


Have you ever lost someone you were close to?

Me too, lets do something about that.

I am Janine Evans Pollard, a London based theatre maker and artist making my Edinburgh Fringe debut this Summer with my first solo show, but I can't do it alone.  

The story demands a space and audiences so I am able to tell my mum and my, story a compelling, in a touching funny one in a creative and different way. My mother died in 2013 and this theatre piece is as much my story as it is hers because I cannot forget my mother she had the biggest impact on my life, she is my bridge. The mother-daughter relationship is the most complex one touching on the issues of mental illness, family expectation and freedom of expression. This show makes this in an accessible, grass-roots performance work worked on since 2013. It is a passionate project which I worked so hard and see future opportunities to perform and do artistic work at a later stage in my life, as I am nearly 40! There isn't much funding for my age group out there! This is a big risk for me to follow my dream to be a full time artist. Come with me on the journey and make it happen! Contribute, support and share. Contribute, support and share. 


Summary of the story

‘After the loss of her Mother, Ginny struggles for survival in an emotional landscape turning to the inanimate mannequin Tracy for comfort and Tracy’s left hand.  ‘Left hand’s’ tales tell of adventure during the travels to India, with Stacey: Tracy’s Girlfriend.   These left hand tales suggest ideas about a need to escape and not deal with the loss explored during Ginny's story: when we lose someone do we run and hide or do we weather the 'emotional' storm? 

 By touching on the issues of different expectations of the mothers for who they think their daughters are and who they will become; and it is an opportunity to create a space for how these vast gaps in understanding create conflict in relationships. This narrative is a shared experience of many mother-daughter relationships and is a dialogue about the dreams not always materialising into real happenings. Told mainly from the perspective of the daughter: 65 days of Tracy the Marquis Mannequin explores isolation, loss and metamorphosis as Ginny transfers her emotional world into her relationship with the mannequin. Ginny searches through her childhood through to adulthood to resolve her complex relationship with her Mother in this intimate comedy.’ 

My show 65 Days of Tracy, The Marquis Mannequin is based on true events in my life following the death of my Mother. I had bought a mannequin and to use in an art project, a friend: Katherine: challenged me to produce something artistic with the mannequin every day for a year. So here are the photos: https://instagram.com/jevanspollard/ and Poems and spoken word: https://soundcloud.com/janine-evans-pollard/sets/65-days-of-marquees-the

Well, I didn't quite follow the rules but managed to make something with Tracy the mannequin every day for 65 days, and I am now making a show with Tracy, and Left Hand, which reflects on loss, isolation and transformation. 

The show is a quirky dark comedy using spoken word, moving image and object-theatre to tell a story that everyone can relate to from their own experiences.  If you have ever had wanderlust, needed company, felt misunderstood or lost your left hand please support my show!

Janine Evans Pollard is an interdisciplinary artist and maker with an interest in identity and the power of narrative to affect personal change. She has studied performance and created theatre in the UK and internationally and brings multi perspectivism to her practice. She works with a process of comprehensive documentation culminating in accessible, grass-roots performance work. 65 days of Tracy the Marquis Mannequin is her first solo performance work.  


What We Need & What You Get

Going to Edinburgh unfortunately costs artists quite a bit of money, but its an essential step for my show! Here is what we are looking at raising. We have dreamed up some unique perks, check them out to your right. 

Strategic planning for artist, media campaign and promotional materials including producer fees £500

Sound designer expenses £300

Director fees £300

Film and visual effects expenses £300

Theatre hire and space in Edinburgh £1200

Rehearsal space £400

Photography production shoot and promo images  £400

Film campaign and documentation £300

Poster, flyers and show programme design and printing £450

Travel to Edinburgh and rehearsals £350

Festival accommodation £700

The Impact

The show is based on true life events that I experienced after the death of my Mother. Exploring the universal themes of love, loss and moving on in a personal way; having come in as strangers, the audience will leave as a community. I hope the show will touch people personally, as everyone can relate to losing someone, feeling alone but braving the storm to make a new life for themselves. 

Risks & Challenges

The Edinburgh Fringe is a challenging environment for any artist to show work in, but I am working on a strategy to get people to the show, both audience and important people who can help the show grow in the future. The venue is confirmed and I will make the best of the time I have there, so don't worry about that. 

Other Ways You Can Help

It would be so helpful if you could share this crowdfunding page on social media or the links to the show https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/65-days-o...

2015 marks our 4th Annual Shakespeare-in-the-Park Youth Theatre program!  Please visit RondoutRep.com for galleries of previous performances and upcoming events!

story:
When the writer set out to write this play she wanted it to ask questions about identity, and family, and love and relationships.  What makes you 'you'?  What makes you love someone?  And what happens when something comes along that changes those things almost beyond recognition?     Dementia is a marauder - it can destroy everything in its path - and it's a scary, scary thing.  But it's not the end of the world.  There can be a future, and people and families can go on, despite this - diminished, maybe; changed, certainly; but still together; here's certainly What makes you 'you'?  What makes you love someone?

"If you love someone, you stick by them, no matter how hard it gets.  Because that's the deal.  Isn't it?" (Cathy)

Rob and Cathy are ready for the next phase of their lives now that their daughter Nicola has grown up and left home.  But when Rob starts to develop early-onset dementia, they're suddenly facing a very different future.  Reluctant to face the truth, and refusing to let Nicola help, they find themselves caught in a spiral of fear and denial which threatens to tear the family apart.

hurt and desperation in this situation, there's  hope and humanity in it, too. 

The Story So Far

Descent started life as a platform production at A Play, A Pie and A Pint  (lunchtime theatre at Oran Mor in Glasgow, and Traverse Theatre Edinburgh) in Oct 2015.  In early 2017 it toured Scotland, and then it most recently was performed for a short run at the Edinburgh Fringe.  It's garnered rave reviews throughout, was nominated for Best New Play at the CATS (Critics' Award for Theatre in Scotland) in 2016, and won a Spirit of the Fringe Award at the Festival.   A selection of reviews:

'Beautifully and skilfully made... an absolute gem.' Broadway Baby

Powerful and touching... profoundly authentic.' The List

'Straightforwardly powerful and heartbreaking' Scotsman

'A magnificent portrayal' Fringe Guru

But the most important thing for us is the audience reaction.  Everywhere we've played, audiences have come up after the show, sharing their reactions to the play and their experiences with us and with each other.  It's been a profound and humbling experience to listen to the stories they've told, and it's borne in on us just how important it is that people have a chance to talk about this.  That's why we think it's so important that we carry on the conversation by touring the play as widely as possible.

The Planned Tour

During the Fringe we had interest from venues and promoters in various areas of the UK, US and Australia in taking the show.  Only some of these are able to offer any funding, however.  We will make application to UK funding organisations for support for a tour, but the current funding climate means that we have to try to raise as much of the costs as we can from other sources.  We already have a fully developed and designed play.  If we can raise enough to undertake a small-scale UK tour in late Spring on 2018, we are hopeful that we can build on that to take the play out further, perhaps even internationally at a later date. The costs involved  at this stage are therefore mostly transport, accommodation and wages for the actors and stage management, and fees or royalties for the creative team.   

Our hope is that touring the play widely will help people to talk about and share their experiences, bring this issue to wider attention, and help, eventually, to fuel the search for an effective treatment - or even, who knows? a cure.  And funding for the first phase of the tour will help greatly in bringing this about.

story:
WHAT

#CASTE is an investigation into what it means to be an ethnic minority actor in the arts today, specifically the expectations in the casting room that have given birth to BAME character archetypes. 

A recent article revealed that more than half the UK's leading theatre companies are employing less than 5% BAME artists in their professional work (2013/14 ACE Diversity Report).

Casting calls on a daily basis specify their parts as “Caucasian” vs. “Other Ethnicities.” What exactly are the differences expected by these two contrasting roles in the casting process, and why has it come to the point where quotas are a necessity to allow for equality? These are the questions that we will investigate, through an ensemble of black and/or mixed race actors; with the aim to spotlight other ethnic groups in future explorations.

WHERE

The Arcola Theatre, London, UK.

HOW

Through an Research and Development week as part of the Arcola LABS programme, #CASTE will generate a working script and rehearsal structure working with black and mixed race actors between 18-30. We have the space confirmed, and we want your help to be able to:

  • Give our performers and creative team a fee
  • Hire a videographer to make a docu-trailer 

That's it.

THE IMPACT

Our main project aim is to engage with as much young or emerging BAME talent as possible, and numbers will depend on the amount we can raise. This will be the first round of this project, with the objective of creating a working rehearsal format and structure for repeated #CASTE projects around the UK (and perhaps even further).

The outputs we desire from this project, and the reason we are crowdfunding is so we can:

  • Provide paid opportunities for emerging BAME theatremakers
  • Present two feedback showcases for industry and invited guests
  • Create a press pack and publicity material for marketing future projects
  • Create a working script and repeatable rehearsal format

Risks & Challenges

With the arts being at risk of additional cuts in the UK right now, the longevity of any theatre works and productions are uncertain. Crowdfunding is one of the only ways a new project can get off the ground. That being said, one thing we can ensure is to ingest everything we can from our experience, with the following evaluative  means:

  • Feedback and invited audience discussions
  • Consistent document tracking and record keeping
  • Observation and monitoring of artist's personal growth
  • Qualitative and quantitative data collection through questionnaires for artists and audience

And making sure that we are achieving our project aim by asking the following questions:

  • Have we been successful in achieving our project objectives?
  • Have we been successful in reaching our target groups for casting and potential audience?
  • To what extent have we explored the BAME trends and patterns in the arts?
  • How have we creatively applied the skillsets and capacities available to us?
  • What impact has the process had on the development of the project?

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, Like, Talk, Change. 

The amount of projects that would never have seen the light of day if it wasn't for sites like this and people like you to help goes into the millions. And that's all down to word of mouth. The world is online, so do us a favour and help us talk to it by speaking our language and sharing as much as you possible can. 

 

 

https://igg.me/at/CASTE

story:
The Story

Social dances are a remarkable phenomenon. These are dances (such as Salsa, Bachata, Kizomba, Tango, Swing, etc.) that give you the opportunity to learn some basic steps and movement, and to dance with people from all over the world. No choreography, no ostentation, just for fun.

People feel good, toned, refreshed and filled with energy, especially when attending any of the specially organized for this purpose parties or festivals. Well, such events are happening continuously every day worldwide. Anyone who has experienced them, whether or not being able to dance, always remained impressed, inspired, full of positive energy. And the truth is that nowadays, when the whole world is stressed up, busy solving problems, we have got almost no time to stop and rest, to unload the burden from our shoulders.

The problem is that there are many people around the world, who want to learn to dance, but can’t afford financially or time-wise to do so. A one-hour dance lesson, currently costs between 5 and 20 dollars. Furthermore, it requires a physical presence at a specific time slot. Of course, one lesson is barely enough though. People need somewhere between 10 and 15 lessons to grasp the basic idea of ​​the dance. This makes about roughly $ 100 and 15 hours of your free time, which we all know is often missing. And when a person is introduced to salsa for example, he wants to learn more new things and to attend more parties and festivals. Why? Because it is a passion, something like a drug but with positive side effects only.

 

Our Mission: 

More people from around the world, no matter whether they are from poor or rich countries, whether or not they have free time, to feel that emotion and energy coming from social dancing. We strongly believe that in this way we will give our little spark to make the world a better place, and people happier and smiling.

 

Why are we asking for your support?

Our aim is to create an online platform enabling anyone to learn how to dance, no matter where this person lives or what kind of financial resource they have. The Platform will provide video tutorials (Full HD or higher quality) on different types of social dances from different instructors worldwide. We will start with dance types like Salsa, Bachata, Kizomba, Cha Cha followed shortly thereafter by Tango, Swing and other dances. The lessons will be explained easily, so that absolutely everyone (regardless of the personal level) can understand them in short time. They will be available to watch any time and will be organized by the level of dancing. We plan also live lessons, where people can ask questions. There will be workshops in a specially arranged section by world-famous instructors from various events, also arranged by the level of difficulty. And all this will be at a very symbolic price.

Support us. Choose one of the Perks and get your pre-launched package.

Perks Description

If you have any questions, just click "Ask a question" and we will be glad to talk with you.

Here is a 30sec preview from one cha-cha lesson to give you an idea of the lessons:

 

 

You can watch this lesson in full version, as well as two other lessons (salsa on 2 intermediate level and bachata intermediate level) in the gallery tab.

 

About the Authors

Thea: "My first touch with salsa was while I was living in Kuwait. That's right - there IS salsa in Kuwait ☺ There I made my first steps in a dance that later became a passion. It's been 13 years since then and it is still giving me the same positive emotion, as it did when I first started dancing. Through the years I have attended more than 20 festivals, congresses and similar salsa events in various ​countries around the world. Currently I'm a marketing director of Be-dance.net - online dance place with over 300,000 views per month."

 

Deni: "I started dancing when I was 5 years old. Since then I’ve been competing and teaching Latin-American and ballroom until 2011, when I met my new passion – salsa. At the end of the same year I started dancing professionally, competing, teaching, traveling for festivals. Salsa for me became not only a hobby, not only a profession, but a way of life. Now I’m teaching in my own school "Let’s Dance", as well as travelling abroad for workshops, performances and mostly having fun."

 

 

How We Are Going to Use the Budget

 

 

Timeline of the Project

Risks and Challenges

- We already have a domain: danceacademia.com

- We already have prepared a design;

- We signed a contract with the developer and the work on the platform began in December 2016;

- We have secured first 12 instructors;

- We have agreements with popular websites, festivals and events organizers to promote the project;

- We have agreements with videographers and editors.

The success of this campaign will allow us to move on to its physical implementation, to reach our target of minimum 2000 lessons and 200 instructors and to share this passion for dancing with many people around the world and teach them to dance and have fun.

Support us. Choose one of the Perks and get your pre-launched package.

If you have any questions, just click "Ask a question" and we will be glad to talk with you.

Here is the design of the Platform's Home Page:
story_txt:
The Story
Social dances are a remarkable phenomenon. These are dances (such as Salsa, Bachata, Kizomba, Tango, Swing, etc.) that give you the opportunity to learn some basic steps and movement, and to dance with people from all over the world. No choreography, no ostentation, just for fun.

People feel good, toned, refreshed and filled with energy, especially when attending any of the specially organized for this purpose parties or festivals. Well, such events are happening continuously every day worldwide. Anyone who has experienced them, whether or not being able to dance, always remained impressed, inspired, full of positive energy. And the truth is that nowadays, when the whole world is stressed up, busy solving problems, we have got almost no time to stop and rest, to unload the burden from our shoulders.

The problem is that there are many people around the world, who want to learn to dance, but can’t afford financially or time-wise to do so. A one-hour dance lesson, currently costs between 5 and 20 dollars. Furthermore, it requires a physical presence at a specific time slot. Of course, one lesson is barely enough though. People need somewhere between 10 and 15 lessons to grasp the basic idea of ​​the dance. This makes about roughly $ 100 and 15 hours of your free time, which we all know is often missing. And when a person is introduced to salsa for example, he wants to learn more new things and to attend more parties and festivals. Why? Because it is a passion, something like a drug but with positive side effects only.

 
Our Mission: 
More people from around the world, no matter whether they are from poor or rich countries, whether or not they have free time, to feel that emotion and energy coming from social dancing. We strongly believe that in this way we will give our little spark to make the world a better place, and people happier and smiling.

 
Why are we asking for your support?
Our aim is to create an online platform enabling anyone to learn how to dance, no matter where this person lives or what kind of financial resource they have. The Platform will provide video tutorials (Full HD or higher quality) on different types of social dances from different instructors worldwide. We will start with dance types like Salsa, Bachata, Kizomba, Cha Cha followed shortly thereafter by Tango, Swing and other dances. The lessons will be explained easily, so that absolutely everyone (regardless of the personal level) can understand them in short time. They will be available to watch any time and will be organized by the level of dancing. We plan also live lessons, where people can ask questions. There will be workshops in a specially arranged section by world-famous instructors from various events, also arranged by the level of difficulty. And all this will be at a very symbolic price.Support us. Choose one of the Perks and get your pre-launched package.Perks DescriptionIf you have any questions, just click "Ask a question" and we will be glad to talk with you.Here is a 30sec preview from one cha-cha lesson to give you an idea of the lessons:
 


 

You can watch this lesson in full version, as well as two other lessons (salsa on 2 intermediate level and bachata intermediate level) in the gallery tab.
 About the AuthorsThea: "My first touch with salsa was while I was living in Kuwait. That's right - there IS salsa in Kuwait ☺ There I made my first steps in a dance that later became a passion. It's been 13 years since then and it is still giving me the same positive emotion, as it did when I first started dancing. Through the years I have attended more than 20 festivals, congresses and similar salsa events in various ​countries around the world. Currently I'm a marketing director of Be-dance.net - online dance place with over 300,000 views per month." Deni: "I started dancing when I was 5 years old. Since then I’ve been competing and teaching Latin-American and ballroom until 2011, when I met my new passion – salsa. At the end of the same year I started dancing professionally, competing, teaching, traveling for festivals. Salsa for me became not only a hobby, not only a profession, but a way of life. Now I’m teaching in my own school "Let’s Dance", as well as travelling abroad for workshops, performances and mostly having fun."  How We Are Going to Use the Budget  Timeline of the ProjectRisks and Challenges- We already have a domain: danceacademia.com- We already have prepared a design;- We signed a contract with the developer and the work on the platform began in December 2016;- We have secured first 12 instructors;- We have agreements with popular websites, festivals and events organizers to promote the project;- We have agreements with videographers and editors.The success of this campaign will allow us to move on to its physical implementation, to reach our target of minimum 2000 lessons and 200 instructors and to share this passion for dancing with many people around the world and teach them to dance and have fun.Support us. Choose one of the Perks and get your pre-launched package.If you have any questions, just click "Ask a question" and we will be glad to talk with you.Here is the design of the Platform's Home Page:

story:
IT COMES IN WAVES

bluemouth inc. creates original, immersive performance events in alternative spaces and this summer, we are excited to bring our newest creation, IT COMES IN WAVES to Toronto audiences in co-production with Necessary Angel Theatre Company. The performance will be a part of PANAMANIA, presented by CIBC, the 35-day arts and cultural festival that will enrich the TORONTO 2015 Pan Am/Parapan Am Games experience.

IT COMES IN WAVES is an exploratory theatrical performance on Toronto Island. Before sunset you board a canoe and row to an island. He is waiting for you on the dock, and leads you through fields and forest clearings until you arrive at a party hall. You help him get ready for the big surprise - but when it arrives, it’s clear no amount of planning can prepare for what lies ahead. A hybrid of dance, opera, theatre, and installation, IT COMES IN WAVES is an extraordinary immersive performance about embracing the unknown. The piece is devised by bluemouth inc. in collaboration with director Jennifer Tarver and Governor General Award winning playwright Jordan Tannahill.

What We Need

We need your help to make this incredible project a reality. Your contribution will go towards:

  • Talent - You'll help support our award-winning playwright, Jordan Tannahill and celebrated director Jennifer Tarver as well as our core blumouth inc performers
  • You’ll also help with production costs including canoe rentals, outdoor supplies like firewood and candles, and equipment like lights (hung from trees), speakers and projectors
  • Venue rental – Artscape Gibraltar Point, an incredible venue to make the magic happen

What You Get

  • Your selection of perks, including tax receipts (who doesn't love a tax receipt!), a video postcard and tickets to the show
  • The satisfaction of supporting a great local initiative and becoming a part of the bluemouth inc. community

Your support is incredibly important.  Your donation inspires others to donate. When you forward this campaign to friends and family, you help us reach our goal quicker and more surely.

The Impact

Since 1998, bluemouth inc. has created a variety of groundbreaking performances for audiences in Montreal, Toronto, Vancouver, Halifax, NYC, the U.K., and Australia. Our most recent work, DANCE MARATHON, has garnered the company international acclaim and continues to tour the globe.

“★★★★★ Beg, borrow or steal a ticket for this life affirming show.”- London Telegraph (DANCE MARATHON)

“★★★★★ Completely immersive…delivers something very rare: pure enjoyment.” - Broadway Baby (DANCE MARATHON)

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Post this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, etc. and help us spread the word about IT COMES IN WAVES
  • Tell your friends and family, coworkers and strangers about the project
  • And if you're free in July make sure to book yourself a ticket to the show – you don’t want to miss it!  Click here to get tickets.

We are grateful to IT COMES IN WAVES supporters, which includes Necessary Angel, Canada Council for the Arts, Ontario Arts Council, Toronto Arts Council and PANAMANIA, presented by CIBC.

story:
Breaking Waves Festival

The Breaking Waves Festival, presented by Actors Alliance of San Diego and San Diego Playwrights, is in its second year of new play creation. The goal of this festival is to team playwrights, directors, and actors together to collaborate on the creation of brand new works written by, directed by, and starring San Diego artists.

In 2014 we saw the creation of 6 brand new plays (a segment is featured in our video here) which all had their World Premiers at the 2014 San Diego International Fringe Festival.

This year we are working exclusively with three playwrights to develop brand new works that demonstrate the phenomenal work that comes out of San Diego, California. 

2015 Breaking Waves Festival Plays:

Quarantine- Wesley Mullins
Turbulence- Katie Brady
Kidnapping- Michael Vegas Mussman

Directed by Patricia Collins

The total amount needed for the Breaking Waves Festival is $2,500. Here on Indiegogo, we hope to reach a goal of between $1,500-$2,000. But in order to do so, we need your help! Come ride the wave with us and help make these productions remarkable. No amount is too small or too large. We sincerely appreciate your support!
Everyone one who donates will not only have our eternal gratitude but will have helped contribute to the movement of our growing playwright community in San Diego.  Our total budget of $2,500 will cover San Diego International Fringe Festival Registration Fees, props, set pieces, costume pieces, and marketing materials.
--No one will be paid from this investment.--
Our team is so focused on the collaborative effort of creation an agreement has been made that all actors, directors, and playwrights will be paid from the ticket sales made at the box office for the fringe festival. No set salaries are created. Each person involved will split the box office sales evenly. 
ABOUT THE PROJECT
The Breaking Waves Festival is the culmating performance of Actors Alliance of San Diego and San Diego Playwrights' Artist Development Program. This program was created to foster a strong environment focused on collaborating to create new works in San Diego. Actors Alliance of San Diego has the goal of creating exposure for San Diego Actors. We do this by collaborating with other facets of the theatre community, including playwrights and directors, to create more opportunity for local actors to be seen. By donating to this project you are making a stand that you want to see more local actors on local stages.
ABOUT ACTORS ALLIANCE OF SAN DIEGO

Actors Alliance of San Diego is a 501(c)3 non-profit, membership-based service organization dedicated to the advancement, exposure and education of the theatre artist in San Diego and enhancing the good of the community through the medium of theatre. The last 28 years we have strived to bring strong talent to San Diego stages. www.actorsalliance.org

ABOUT SAN DIEGO PLAYWRIGHTS

San Diego Playwrights is a network working to promote San Diego playwrights and the theatres and organizations that support them. We engage the community in the process of getting local playwrights produced in San Diego.

story:
My name is Kate Bell and I write plays.  (You can check out more about me here: www.katebell.info)

I've been working on a series of plays set during blackouts in New York City, and the first production from that series is happening this spring: Blackout03  at HERE Arts Center, produced as a part of the 2015 Downtown Urban Theater Festival.  The entire series of THE BLACKOUT PLAYS seeks to explore black/white racial relations over the course of thirty-eight years of New York City history and an imagined future.

Blackout03  focuses on gentrification, the desire to be creative, and the struggle to become fully adult in your twenties.
By making a contribution to this first production of Blackout03, you're offering support to my amazing director Sara Lyons (theatricator.com) and a wonderful team of actors (Lindse Austen, Alex Major, LaTonia Phipps, and Chinaza Uche), as well as showing confidence in me and the overall vision of THE BLACKOUT PLAYS.  I believe more creative projects need to be looking closely at how we're divided by race and class, and how to communicate across these lines.  Blackout03 seeks to spark those kinds of conversations.
 
I'm thrilled to have Blackout03 be a part of the prestigious Downtown Urban Theater Festival (www.dutfnyc.com) for its first production.  The play has also received development support from Red Fern Theatre Company (a very special thank you to Melanie Moyer Williams) and Random Access Theatre. 
I have fifteen years of experience as a playwright, director, producer, and teaching artist, and I'm entering a new phase of commitment to actualizing my work,  I couldn't be more prepared and excited! Thank you for being a part of it.
Any contribution makes a big difference...but if you can't afford to financially support Blackout03 at this time, please connect to us on social media and help us get the word out.  I'm planning on developing and producing the entire series of THE BLACKOUT PLAYS over the next couple years.  By offering any kind of support right now, you're helping me to actualize this important project.

story:
The Bridge Initiative:  Women in Arizona Theatre 

The theatre has long been dominated by men.  Male writers, directors, executive leadership... serving up entertainment to an audience that is mostly women.  Seems odd, no?  Several cities across the country have started to address the issue of gender disparity, but there has been no formal effort here, in the Valley of the Sun. We've decided that needs to change!   

                                        

In January, The Bridge Initiative was awarded a $6,000 seed funding grant by the Arizona Arts Commission, recognizing the need for this project, and providing the financial backing to launch.  We are thrilled that Mesa Encore Theatre is on board as our fiscal sponsor, giving us reduced rental costs for programming, and offering guidance along the way.  They also enable our nonprofit status, so your donation is 100% tax deductible!  And your receipt for your donation will come under their name.

We have a support structure in place to get started! 

So... what are we going to DO??

A lot!  We're planning quarterly networking events, press outreach, an annual contest to award Playwright and Director of the Year, and a symposium with master classes, panel discussions, play readings, and a full production of our awarded new play, directed by our awarded director.  

But we need more $$$.  So we're trying to match our Arts Tank grant!

...which is where you come in!  Our seed grant is fantastic, but to become the professional organization we aspire to be, we need additional funds.  Here's what your money will go toward:  

  1. Artist salaries (instead of stipends)... we want to pay all of our artists (designers, stage managers, actors, etc.) a professional wage.
  2. Production values.  We really want our set, costume, lighting and sound designers to have good budgets for their work.
  3. All of our programming (except for the fully-produced play) will be open and free to the public.  We need to subsidize the rental space and leader stipends.
  4. Publicity/marketing.  Printing costs for fliers and postcards, playbills, and maybe we can even hire a PR expert!

We have further grand designs and projects up our sleeves so if we're in the astoundingly blessed position of having our funding target exceeded, we'll unveil our stretch goals.

The Bridge has HUGE potential!

One component of our mission is connecting students and professionals, so the next generation of theatre artists will find local mentors and role models.  Also, by identifying and giving a showcase to female practitioners, we'll remind all the established producers in the Valley of the talent in their own backyard.  Beginning a conversation on gender parity can only help artistic directors and audiences become mindful of their choices going forward.  And we will be birthing a new play by a female playwright into the world, hopefully launching its journey beyond Arizona and into the American playwriting canon.

Who we are

                                       

Founders Brenda Jean Foley and Tracy Liz Miller are have extensive theatrical experience in performing, producing, writing, directing, managing, and teaching.  Since arriving in the Phoenix area, we have worked with companies from Southwest Shakespeare Company to iTheatre Collaborative to Mesa Encore Theatre to Class 6 to Chandler-Gilbert Community College.  Both of us spent many years living in New York City, so our skills and contacts both nationally as well as right here in Arizona will shepherd our project to success. 

                                                      

We have also enlisted Lizz Reeves Fidler, a powerhouse in the Arizona theatre scene with corporate and financial savvy.  Her artistic and managerial expertise are phenomenal assets to our organization.

If you can't contribute $$$...

...that doesn't mean you can't help!  We need an audience for our events and performances.  We need your ideas and your ingenuity.  We need producers and box office personnel and Web guru types.  We need cheerleaders!  Tell everyone you know about our initiative and our fund-raising campaign.  Share it on social media and when you're having a glass of wine with friends.  Sign up for our newsletter.  

It takes a village.  We're glad you're part of ours.

(HUGE thanks to Debra Jo Davey, Becky Martinez, Brian Foley, Steven Ryan, and Travis Mills with Running Wild Films, Arizona Commission on the Arts, and Julia C. Patrick with Arizona Nonprofit Academy for their invaluable advice and support)

story:
Short Summary

BYTE stands for BackYardTheatreEnsemble.   They create mainly original theatre and give young performers an opportunity to expose their work to audiences around the world.  This current group of keen thespians are now in rehearsals for a show called Weight Of Time, which they will be taking around parts of Australia, then over to Europe, pausing in between shows to  try improve their skill base and knowledge with workshops and theatre experiences.

What We Need & What You Get

Our young thespians are hoping to raise $6,000 so the entire cast can have as many theatrical, cultural and educational experiences as possible in the 5 weeks of their tour of Europe.  Each cast member has funded their own way on the trip but we want them all, regardless of their personal circumstances, to be exposed to as many opportunities as possible.  Raising this money will allow them access to opportunities such as behind the scenes theatre tours & workshops with professional actors and directors.  All of this will impact positively on their work - Weight of Time, as well as future works.

We have some excellent incentives for you to get involved with these passionate performers.  From tickets to the show (or other BYTE shows) to a personal thank you from a cast member to your name/logo on the Weight of Time programme, there are some nice rewards for your generosity.

The Impact

These are passionate young people who are keen to learn as much about their craft as they can.  They were chosen via an audition process and each brings something wonderful to the piece, from our youngest performer of 13 years to our oldest actor in her twenties.  The experiences they have whilst touring Weight of Time will make for more mature performers going forward.  These are future stars of tomorrow, who are eager for opportunities to improve.  You are helping fund the improvement of our artistic future in Australia.

Risks & Challenges

Our young thespians are being proactive in raising the funds so that each cast member has the same opportunity.  As well as funds we raise through this campaign, the cast will be holding a sausage sizzle and chocolate drive.  Time is against us as we need to lock in these overseas opportunities however all are confident we can do it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps, each $1 adds up.  We appreciate every bit of support we are shown.  Even if you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help us by sharing this link with your friends, family and associates, spreading the word to a wider audience.

BYTE stands for BackYardTheatreEnsemble.   They create mainly original theatre and give young performers an opportunity to expose their work to audiences around the world.  This current group of keen thespians are now in rehearsals for a show called Weight Of Time, which they will be taking around parts of Australia, then over to Europe, pausing in between shows to  try improve their skill base and knowledge with workshops and theatre experiences. What We Need & What You Get
Our young thespians are hoping to raise $6,000 so the entire cast can have as many theatrical, cultural and educational experiences as possible in the 5 weeks of their tour of Europe.  Each cast member has funded their own way on the trip but we want them all, regardless of their personal circumstances, to be exposed to as many opportunities as possible.  Raising this money will allow them access to opportunities such as behind the scenes theatre tours & workshops with professional actors and directors.  All of this will impact positively on their work - Weight of Time, as well as future works.
We have some excellent incentives for you to get involved with these passionate performers.  From tickets to the show (or other BYTE shows) to a personal thank you from a cast member to your name/logo on the Weight of Time programme, there are some nice rewards for your generosity.
The Impact
These are passionate young people who are keen to learn as much about their craft as they can.  They were chosen via an audition process and each brings something wonderful to the piece, from our youngest performer of 13 years to our oldest actor in her twenties.  The experiences they have whilst touring Weight of Time will make for more mature performers going forward.  These are future stars of tomorrow, who are eager for opportunities to improve.  You are helping fund the improvement of our artistic future in Australia. Risks & Challenges
Our young thespians are being proactive in raising the funds so that each cast member has the same opportunity.  As well as funds we raise through this campaign, the cast will be holding a sausage sizzle and chocolate drive.  Time is against us as we need to lock in these overseas opportunities however all are confident we can do it.
 Other Ways You Can Help
 Every little bit helps, each $1 adds up.  We appreciate every bit of support we are shown.  Even if you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help us by sharing this link with your friends, family and associates, spreading the word to a wider audience.
